Also note that the steamed mussels and clams, although nicely presented, were not "meat-plentiful" - so if you order this, don't expect to get "bite-size chunks of seafood jewels" not so with these dishes.

We also ordered the seafood paella.  Now, I've had paella, and so the expectations were high.  With that said, although this dish was spectacular in presentation with assortment of (large) shrimps, mussels (small), clams (small) red peppers, peas etc - and the flavor was good.  The biggest question stood out.  WHERE WAS THE SOCCARAT?!  

Overall - I'd rate this a 3.5 - with a creeping 4, solely because they seated us right away, the price point with the food, the tasty eats - not to mention -  a parking garage conveniently located 1 block from the restaurant (on 21st street).  So, Would I come again?  Sure.
author: Lyn A.

description: Had lunch here with my BFF a couple of weeks ago!! Great food and sangria! Note: Paella for two is made for four. Needless to say, we were stuffed and took leftovers home! Patatas Bravas was delish!
author: Neni E.

description: My favorite Spanish restaurant ! Their flavors are amazing ! Reminds me of Barcelona, Catalan cooking. Order my favs, Croquetas, campanallitos, boucarones, calamare, seats, and more !
author: Eddie I.

description: Loved the tapas... Great food.. Our friends who were a long time sanfranciscoan suggested this place and I was grateful.. We tried first 3 in veg tapas and everything was yummy.. :)
author: Ankita J.

description: Was in the city and felt like trying out a Spanish tapas restaurant. The place is small, the staff was friendly, a good selection of tapas with reasonable prices. Th location is not ideal...hold on to your purses ladies.
author: Raquel V.

description: One of the best tapas restaurant, service was quick, food sooooo delicious and reasonable prices. Must try patatas bravas,
author: Lorlie C.

description: One of my favorite spots in the city, great Spanish food with really affordable prices. Totally recommended. I like their fried Calamari.
author: Mohanad E.

description:
This was one of my top three restaurants but  after tonight's experience I'm not sure if I will be back. The Sangria was still as delicious and so was the garlic shrimp. But the service was awful. 

My fiancé and I came around 7:30 pm and signed OURSELVES in the waiting list. There was a party of nine ahead of us and a couple as well. We were there at least 10 minutes and no one came out the restaurant to tell us that it would be a while for us to be seated. The couple ahead of us left, the party of nine were complaining because they had made reservations and they had been waiting an hour. On top of that while all of this is happening there were two table available and no one cared to seat us until I decided to ask why were there tables available and no one was sitting us down. The waiter waited 20 minutes to come get our order and brought us the wrong plate and I said it was ok since we didn't want to waste food. Awful service, the waitresses look young and lazy. I remember when they actually cared about customers and the type of service they provided. So disappointed.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Woohoo!  Great paella!  I felt like I was in Spain!  I had lunch with my friend Joe and he picked the place.  It was packed with people eating paella.  We shared the Paella de Mariscos(seafood).  It was so good and so much food.  We each had a glass of wonderful Spanish wine.  Life is good.  Salud!
author: Blondie R.

description:
The first two times I went here it was delicious!   The last three times we went the service was terrible & we waited for a long time. The last visit, service was terrible, long wait and there was curly hair in my food - Yuk!!
There is a lot I can deal with, but hair in my food isn't one of them and they had the nerve to blame me!!  Not cool
author: Pat H.

description: Probably should get 4.5, so I flipped a coin.Had an amazing meal here before a night on the town - under $45 including wine. Best deal in the city. Will be back
author: Michael V.

description: Worst service ever.. We were on the waiting list to be seated.. Few people went ahead and seated in front of us ... We complained about that we have been waiting for 15 minutes and the guy said if you don't want to wait you don't have to and u can leave.. That was the manager telling us that.. .. I am so glad that I didn't spend my money on this establishment.. Now I know why they are 3 stars ..
author: Mohini S.

description: The food is delicous, however they have the worst service ever! Been to this place numerous times,  because we like the food but can't beat the rudeness of the servers no longer. Over the years, spent good money here, but year after year, the waiter and waitress quality went down the hill. The last visit we asked water twice and both times, our request had been ignored.  So I did write on the check "thanks for water, asked twice " and didn't tip yet they went ahead and charged my card $5 tip without my authorization.  I will call my bank for this illegal activity.
author: Di S.

description:
I really like Spanish food, so am always on the lookout for less expensive Spanish restaurants. This one is a little pricey, but satisfies the craving. We always seem to find ourselves here when we're starving ( which adds to the bill.)

I usually get the grilled vegetable platter which comes with lemon and aoli (which I think is really mayo..at least that's what it tastes like, so I skip it.) This is a pretty good dish overall. It comes with broccoli, cabbage, zucchini and peppers. 

I also get fried calamari with aoli ( again skip the 'mayoili' )... I love calamari so am generally satisfied with this. 

Finally,  I get a cazuela with clams and fish and a side of rice. The rice is pretty salty but I need rice so there it is. The  cazuela has good flavor, but is not a big portion.

I generally end up spending a fair amount here, but could probably better satisfy my seafood/rice needs by ordering the paella, which  always looks fantastic on other peoples tables, and end up paying a lot less.  Next time I will try and plan ahead (paella takes a while) to do that. 

Service is usually friendly and prompt. Tonight was a little strange and I think an aberration. They sat us right away, and then maybe 15 minutes later came and asked my husband to move farther away from the table next to us. Huh... So husband slid his chair in and squeezed closer to the kid, but I guess that wasn't enough. So now you are thinking husband is a big guy who needs a bunch of space...and actually no he isn't at all, and there was a ton of room....it seemed like they squished him in for no reason. Then a few minutes later they came back as it was determined that husband hadn't moved enough...so they had us move to another table altogether.

Strange, right? They were not rude about moving us or anything, it was just sort of perplexing and didn't feel very welcoming.
author: El B.

description:
Awesome tapas and paella. Today we had a variety of tapas including green beans, patatas bravas our favorite, clams in butter garlic and parsley, shrimp, Spanish rice and others. The surprise favorite was the grilled cabbage. Wonderful flavored and textures to complement the other tapas. 

Wonderful experience.
author: Thomas L.

description: Had a wonderful lunch today, the combination plate, garlic shrimp with potatoes and cabbage.  This place has been in business at this location for over 25 years and it is in the heart of the trendy Mission district in San Francisco. Authentic and delicious Spanish food at a very reasonable price with good size portions. The total tab for two for lunch was $20. and we would both definitely return, hopefully soon.
author: Gloria J.

description: The food is good, i cant complain, but the service is unacceptable. For a party of 4 they hand wrote an 19% tip on the receipt. If the service would have been good maybe it would have been ok, but 2 dishes never showed and the response was "we don't have that one and you didn't order the other". I am always happy to leave a 18-20% tip when the service calls for it, but i do not appreciate someone hand-writing in a 19%tip, much less when its not deserved.
author: carmen i.

description: The two stars is for the service. It sucks, they need more staff.  For lunch time they had two people serving and helping seat people down and sometimes no where to be found. The girl was friendly but she seem distracted with everything else she had to do.
author: Fabbie B.

description:
If I could give 0 start I will give it. It is the most unorganized restaurant that I have ever been. We arrived and they had a paper to sign your name in ana the number of people (no pen to be seen).

We signed our names and there were a couple of groups ahead of us. No one came to check or talk to us. After 10 minutos a group of three people came in an signed, then they decided that wanted be sited right away and went to talked to the host. The host started to sit people without looking at the list. We ended up without a table, he offered us a table upstairs but they were dirty..... After this whole incident we decided to leave.

If you are going to put a list for people to sign to be sited , you should make sure to follow the order and respect all the parties. I think this place needs a better organization.
author: Ana C.

description:
San Francisco is a hub of many cultures and traditions. With such ethnic diversity, there is always an opportunity to experience many ethnic cuisines. Over the past several weeks, I have been sampling ethnic restaurants with a friend and have been trying to find hidden culinary gems in San Francisco. One of such hidden gems is the Esperpento.

Concealed in the Mission District, Esperpento is Tapas Bar providing enriching Spanish food and drinks. This restaurant is located about 2 blocks from the 22nd Street Bart Station and opens 7 days a week, from 11 am (except Saturday and Sunday at midday) to 10pm (except Friday and Saturday when it closes at 11pm).
The restaurant has a typically Spanish ambience and has a décor featuring many tantalizing artifacts and posters teleporting you back to Spain. We arrived without reservation, my friend had arrived before me and managed to get a table.

We had arrived 3 hours after opening on a not-so-busy Saturday afternoon, and were very disappointed when we were told they were already out of Rabbit stew. Instead we had the Ropa Vieja Stew, featuring a tasty mix of beer, chicken, and chorizo. This was a delightful dish with a side of roasted potatoes and cabbage sautéed with garlic and paprika.

The pitcher of Sangria was equally tasty. Mixed to a blend of orange and apple bits, the Sangria was fresh, fruity, and refreshing. An ideal choice for a sweltering Saturday extravaganza.

Although, a little disappointed with not being able to try the Rabbit soup we left happy knowing that we would be back to try our luck again with the Rabbit and hopefully we will discover more hidden secrets of this Spanish culinary gem, Esperpento.
author: Sunny E.

description:
My wife and I chose this establishment as our go to Tapas place whenever we were in the city, and we always felt it was a great value for the quality and variety of tapas available. We've  burned through most items on their menu and they are generally pretty good, including the paellas, however during this last visit on Saturday (12/20) evening around 5-6, we had another good meal, and took home paella left overs as usual, however this time when we went to eat it the day after, we found a fingernail clipping and a piece a milky white round plastic tube in the paella. 

This is very unfortunate, we actually liked the place, but we'll never go back. I tried calling the establishment on both Monday and Tuesday afterwards during the lunch service and in between their services,  but the phone either just continues to ring with no answer or if you leave a message for the manager, there is no call response. Very irresponsible, and a bit of a shame. 

Beware! 

We won't be going back, not sanitary in our minds.
author: Michael H.

description:
This is my second time eating here and both experiences were pretty much the same as far as the food goes. It was good. Nothing great. The service though... I thought the first time was bad but my experience last night was BAD. It took the server 15 minutes just to approach the table for drinks. She didn't seem too happy to be there and was giving everyone dirty looks. She also appeared to have a case of tunnel vision. When she was helping another table, she didn't for a second look around to see if any other tables needed anything before walking to the back to disappear for another 10 minutes. I spent many years as a waiter when I was in college, so I get it, and it really is a rare occasion that I leave a poor tip, but this experience definitely warranted that. But wait...I just checked my credit card statement and apparently she didn't feel the same and seemed to think she deserved more so added another $10 to the tip I wrote in. Now I'll be calling tomorrow and making sure she gets nothing.


Edit: I've gone in 3 times and probably called a dozen times and have been unable to get ahold of a manager and have not received a call back. If you choose to eat here, which you totally shouldn't at this point, make sure you check your statement afterwards!
author: Justin W.

description:
If "Cha Cha Cha's" had a mother  - it would be Esperpento!

i like to think of this place as a home cook version of cha cha cha's. Don't get me wrong i love cha cha cha, but they get really busy. This place is much slower and intimate. You can bring a date here, whereas you go to cha cha cha to get drinks and get drunk.

The food menu is very cha cha cha's. it is slightly more expensive here, but i think you can taste the differences in authenticity. Here you can tell its work has been put into these dishes. Paella is always a favorite for big groups as well as the potatoes. 

I do prefer the sangria from cha cha cha, its not as sweet as it is from here. Overall i like this place better. I highly recommend it if your looking for a good tapas place in the mission.
author: Ryan R.

description:
My cousin and husband from Australia were both visiting the states. I've never met them before and they've never been to United States so I wanted to make sure their time in San Francisco was incredibly memorable. They wanted Latin American food so I suggested Esperpento. Couple months ago, my roommate brought home leftovers and I thought it was delicious. If the leftovers are good, the food fresh from the restaurant HAS to be good! Right?! So it was a huge family gathering with several other relatives, and none of us have ever met each other. You can imagine how much catching up we had to do. Decades worth of catching up! We ordered several tapas, sangria, and everything was delicious, and then.. 

the FREAKEN MARIACHI band. I understand you want to set a romantic and authentic atmosphere, but it makes it extremely difficult for groups to talk to each other. In order to be heard I felt like I was shouting across our table. The place is just too small to be having a mariachi band playing the whole night.

All the tapas we ordered were excellent, but I was very disappointed with the seafood and meat paella. They were not meager with the seafood or meat, but everything was overcooked and the flavor was mediocre. The shrimp, clams, and chicken were incredibly dry. I ended up just taking bites out of the rice.
author: Cindy A.

description:
I came here because my parents had just gotten back from Spain and my sister kept informing us that this was as close as she found so far to Barcelona food, so we took my mom here for her birthday.

Parking: Street Parking, it's the Mission District, I believe there's a parking lot across the street.

From what I noticed, no A/C (It's SF so no surprise here), but if it's a hot day, drink lots of Sangria!

The food? It was really good, actually one of the better Spanish restaurants i've been to and the Sangria was good too, we had two pitchers.  Was it worth it? Definitely, even after a plate of Blood Sausages, my hands looked swollen from all that cholesterol the next day (but totally worth it). :)
author: Omar L.

description:
This place has great tasting food, but the space is very small and the service is lacking.

I don't expect a restaurant in the Mission to have a whole lot of space, but this place is obviously on the cramped side. You'll have to weave your way around tables and wedge yourself into your seat. Even when you get to your seat, there's not a lot of table room, so sharing plates may actually work to your advantage. On this note, it's not a great place for groups of over 6 people and even seating 6 people can be a challenge.

The food is great! Every tapas dish we got was enough for 2-3 people (our group of 5 ordered 4 tapas plates and that was plenty for us!) and the paella plate that we ordered for 4 people could have easily fed 6-7 people. The food was very flavorful (not bland or salty) and was cooked perfectly (none of the meat was over or under done and the potato dishes were perfectly soft and not under cooked). 

The service was spotty and the servers seldom passed by our table which was in the corner on the top floor. As a result, it was hard to flag down any servers without physically going downstairs and confronting them. I also wondered if the servers seldom passed through the top floor in general because another group seated on the top floor complained about the water service being lacking (which was the case for our table, too) and how no one came to pick up their tab when they were ready to pay. Both that table and our table eventually had to take our tab downstairs and hand it to a server when we were ready to pay. 

Thumbs up for the great food, but there is a lot of room for improvement on the service side.
author: Nirel R.

description:
cozy atmosphere with friendly service, AWESOME SANGRIA, but i can't say as much for the actual food.

Spicy potatoes - cooked well, sauce was not very addictive

Garlic creamy mashed potatoes - i wish the garlic flavor was stronger, this one was quite bland

Seafood paella - you can taste the seafood broth and it was decent, but nowhere near as good as Pasion's

Squid Ink paella - very bland and you have to fully peel the shrimp.  it gets pretty messy considering its a rice dish

Sangria - was awesomely sweet and strong! just how i like it.  unfortunately it would probably all i would come back for
author: Tina A.

description:
Thanks to Marti L, I was very happy to return to Esperpento with fellow Yelpers that included her, Maybelline C, Danny L, Jonathan W, Karen Y and her boyfriend. The décor hasn't changed from the previous visit but the early evening sunlight filtering through the windows had kept the interior colorfully vibrant while the evening crowd was just beginning to grow. Our server, Eric, was very friendly and enthusiastic in providing a list of recommendations to consider, and we ordered six forms of tapas with a pitcher of sangria ($17) to share.

The major highlights of the meal included Patatas Bravas ($4.75) which arrived with delicious serving of potatoes with a layer of spicy sauce. We all loved this dish has it came with major wow factor which was consistent with my previous visit. The Rabo Toro ($7.50) came with tender oxtail s served in a stew and it was so tender the meat was falling off the bones. The sauces from both dishes were fantastic for bread dipping, and one can never leave here without trying their delightful sangria which was a major hit.

I really wanted to try their Lobster Paella for the longest time ($50).  It came with seven half pieces of juicy lobster tails with large calamari rings, shrimps and clams to induce an aromatic lobster seafood flavor which was steeped into the rice. I really enjoyed this dish and servings were enough for everyone to get a nice portion. If there is a place to have paella in the City, Esperpento would be the restaurant to consider.

The Calamares Frito ($6.75) was decently fried but nothing special or tender like the ones at Blue. The Gamba Al Ajillo ($7) provided a sizable amount of jumbo shrimps with a hint of garlic, and Jamon Serrano ($6) served with Spanish cured ham on toasted French bread with touches of ripe tomatoes and olive oil were very good too.

Service was excellent! We were attended to frequently at the right moments and Eric was very responsive to our requests. The atmosphere was great throughout the night and it was another fine dining experience with San Francisco Yelpers. I expect to return for many more visits in the near future.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Overall, the food is not bad, but really greasy, menu is quite authentic, but uninspired, and the decor is nice, but dated.

The service, on the other hand, was by far the worst of any restaurant I've ever been in. It was almost impressive - simultaneously rude, dismissive, and painfully slow. The owner literally walked away from the table in the middle of taking our order and didn't come back for several minutes. They ran out of bread - which I only found out after the 3rd time I asked.

Also, The gambas al ajillo gave my girlfriend and I mild food poisoning, so nice cherry on top there. We are absolutely never coming back - and you shouldn't either.
author: Kyle H.

description: Update:   Just talked with my friend who refused to leave a tip, the restaurant charged her 28% tip on her credit card without authorization.  Yes, that's right, after she signed her credit card bill, the restaurant changed the total.  Anyone else who has experienced this please message me.  Thanks.
author: Molly M.

description: Patatas Bravas, Patatas Bravas, Patatas Bravas! Is basically all I ate when I came here with my family from San Jose. I did however try other yummy plates, but all my attention was on the Patatas Bravas! The Sangria's were amazing as well! Definitely helped digest to allow me to eat more of the Patatas Bravas. Next time I come here, I'll request 3 order fulls of the Patatas Bravas on a large plate with a side of the delicious sauce! There's a parking garage right across from the restaurant which made it very convenient because I hate parking my vehicle on the San Francisco streets. The restrooms are very clean as well. Customer service was great, the waiter was attentive of our table. Will definitely be coming back here for dinner whenever I find myself near the area or after a Giants day game ;)
author: Eric B.

description: Our second visit, it is crowded, noisy, delicious and very affordable. Servers are nice and accommodating, even during a busy dinner hour.
author: Greg R.

description: Authentic tasting Spanish tapas place with unassuming decor and reasonable prices. The goods - red wine sangria (delicious & a bargain at $4.50 a glass), seafood paella (fresh, plump seafood, well done rice - the bad ones tend to be runny and rice is sometimes undercooked), black sausage and potatoes. Mediocre - cod croquettes were too creamy and didn't have a distinctive taste, flan and their version of cream brûlée were kind of similar and the cream brûlée was kind of grainy. The total came out to about $ 75 (without tips) - 5 tapas, paella for two, a sangria, two desserts and a coffee.
author: W H.

description:
*This review is just about the service we got.
I like the food and that's why we'll come back, just hope I don't get her as a waitress again!

There's obviously something wrong with the management of this place. 

Been at this place twice this month so far and both times had the same experience. Got there without reservation, had to wait a little bit it's ok, it was nice until we got sited and we were aware of the waiting. 
Cant believe why the older lady with the glasses (who didn't tell us her name) is still working here. She gives dirty looks to everyone, even her coworkers. Took her around 30 mins to come take our order. When she finally came we explained to her the food allergy my friend had, ordered some dishes and then asked if everything was safe for my friend to eat. She said "okay "and left. Obviously she didn't understand a word. 
When food arrived, I asked another waiter if food had nuts and he said yes. Thank god my friend didn't taste it. 
Then we told her about it but still didn't understand. After all, she didn't come not once to ask if we needed something or to give us our check.
Can't figure out why a company would keep her.
author: Mari Carmen M.

description: What a wonderful experience!! Friendly staff, and amazingly delicious food. My boyfriend is from Barcelona and I have had the pleasure to visit there. We both agree that Spain was well represented here. We shared several tapas and we're pleased with it all. You will love to come here.
author: Miss J.

description:
Service was garbage! At 9:30 the waitress told us they were closed and that we only had10 minutes to put in our order. WTF!!!!! Just change your ******* sign and say open until 9:30 rather than 10:00. 

Wasted my precious time here and would never go back! Did I mention garbage???
author: Maz G.

description: Great! The artichokes are super yummy! Lots of garlic! I got the Serrano appetizer and the artichokes and ate it as my lunch. They complimented each other great!
author: Alicia S.

description:
Went here for date night with the fiance on Thursday after going to the farmer's market. We got there around like 6:30ish and so and there clearly was going to be a seat open as another couple was about to leave. He had us put our name on the waiting list still - ok fine but like a minute latre the couple left. The guy that had us put our name on the list totally didn't come get us and another waitress was standing there and we were like 2 and she seated us immediately. We got the following:

- House Salad - pretty standard nothing special
- Grilled Eggplant - I'm a big eggplant fan and its a hard veggie to cook but they did a really good job. It was full of flavor and very soft. They mix it with bell peppers and onions and serve it with half a hard boiled egg. Its a bit oily but it was good
- Seafood Paella for 2 - This is a mix of clams, mussels, calamari, and shrimp. It takes about 30 minutes to make which is standard so if you happen to be waiting for a table and close to getting seated, would def order ahead of time. I wasn;t too impressed. For $26, you don't get that much of the clams, mussels, and shrimp. It also wasn't very flavorful. I feel like they could have def put in more flavors. 

Ambience is nice and the spanish band started playing in the middle. It's a small place and def no frills. They hae a lot of paella choices but wasn't overall that impressed.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: It is a solid place and portion sizes are ok I think (though we left a little hungry but maybe it is because wr had some vegetarians).  We went in a group and they had the second floor balcony area reserved for us.
author: Daniel Y.

description: I love this little place, food is delicious, servers are courteous and very affordable prices. Definitely recommend it.
author: Bibi G.

description: Very, very nice Spanish tapas restaurant in the Mission. Friendly, great service and food. Authentic tapas, large selection, well prepared and a real bargain.  Thought I was in Barcelona or Pamplona.  I strongly recommend this restaurant. Went for lunch without reservations and it was not a problem with seating. Would get a reservation for dinner.
author: Dan S.

description: My wife is hard to please and she loved the delicious food and the man who was playing guitar in the reataurant. I loved it too...we're definitely coming back!
author: Bladimir A.

description:
The paella was undercooked and the rice hard. Gave me stomachaches.

It also took forever to get our food.
author: Emma T.

description: Glassware and silverware was awfully dirty to the point I could not enjoy my lunch. The owner should spend money fixing the dish washer otherwise he will lose more clients.
author: Phillip H.

description: I went with some friends to this lively Mission restaurant - I hadn't eaten in a traditional Spanish restaurant in many years, so was anxious to try it out.  It was a Saturday night, but we arrived at 6 PM (with reservation) before it was too crowded.  Unfortunately, the kitchen seemed unable to handle all the orders!  We ordered some small plates and seafood/meat paella.  The plates came to the table quickly and were delicious.  However, we had to wait almost 1 1/2 hours for the paella to be served!  Waiter was very apologetic and gave us a small potato tapa - for that kind of wait we should have been given a carafe of sangria!  When the paella finally arrived, the 4 of us dug in and it was indeed very tasty.  However, their kitchen needs to either add more cooks or limit the amount of diners they can accommodate during busy weekend nights.  I will visit again, but this time go at 5 PM!
author: Debbie B.

description:
One of top 10 places to eat in the entire bay.
Great food every single time I've gone in the past 4+yrs.
Also, the service has been great as well.
I look forward to dining here every time!
author: Paul U.

description: Great place!  Quality food, great prices, and cheap sangria.  For the price, this place is excellent (i.e. around $30 - $35 for a carafe of sangria and 3 tapas).  Although, as some people mentioned, the service can sometimes be a bit slow paced, so do not come here if you are on a tight schedule.
author: Christen W.

description:
Esperpento had good food.  I had the Salmon combination plate with veggies.  The sauce for the bread was fantastic.  They also brought out some mushrooms in béchamel sauce with the bread. 

It had a great atmosphere, which was largely influenced by an impromptu visit from a guitarist off the street.

The service was good/fast service.  

The prices were very reasonable.
author: Ryan I.

description: It is a nice place, good service and the paella is ok, I asked for the seafood paella, for 2 is a good portion size, but this paella it's simply OK, I was expecting more from this place. Still for me so far the most acceptable paella in the Bay Area is in a Cuban restaurant in alameda called Habana
author: Myrna E.

description: Love love love the veggie paella !! The patata was also amazing as was the roasted eggplant tapas ! Flan was a good ending to the meal ! Definitely coming here again !
author: R P.

description:
A vibrant Spanish Tapas restaurant in the Mission district. If you decide on this adventure, be prepared to be assaulted with collage of colors, cacophony of sounds and explosions of flavors. Not a place for a quiet meal with your new squeeze but perfect for small get together of friends looking for a fun evening of good food and good drinks.

We made reservations for seven at 6:30pm and got seated just before the crowd. By 7pm the place was hoppin', between the people seated, the people waiting, the staff and the strolling musicians the evening's festivities had begun.  We started with a carafe of Sangria which was a jammy mixture of fruit and mellow wine. Some sangrias taste like fruit juice mixed with wine, Esperpento's was luscious and  fruity and fully amalgamated into its foundation delicious full body wine. Just a taste transports you to a summer night in Madrid. The Sangria was the complement for a selection of tapas:

Calamares Fritos-fried calamari $6.50
Morcilla-sauteed spanish blood sausage $5.50
Tortilla De Patata-potato and onion omelet $6.00

The prize goes to my nephew for choosing the delicious Tortilla De Patata which was more of a potato cake than a tortilla. The fried calamari was excellent when dipped into their creamy house hot sauce. Now you know I had to try the blood sausage; it was very good but not exciting.

For the main dish we ordered the Lobster Paella for six. A Saffron-flavored Rice dish cooked with a gaggle of slipper Lobsters, Seafood and Vegetables served in a Paellera, $76. The server assured us that we had ordered enough since we had also ordered tapas and only had 6 adults in our group of 7. If you had asked my doctor he would have also told you that I had ordered more than enough but for a foodie it was only just enough. Heck, it wasn't enough - not because I was still hungry - it was so good. I didn't want to stop eating. The rice, the lobster, and vegies all came together like a Miles Davis arrangement.

Esperpento is like the bull run in Pamplona but the servers were like the Catholic mass the next morning. The servers were way too somber for such a vibrant restaurant - what a drag on the festive atmosphere!

Next time? I am just going to get a bunch of their tapas and have at it, okay maybe I'll finished it all off with a Crema Catalana.
author: Eddie C.

description: Tapas from Spain. Grilled quail was perfect with the rosemary. Mussels were delicious. We arrived after the lunch crowd. Perfect Service was attentive and friendly. There is so much more I want to try. Going back for sure.
author: Leon L.

description: The food was really good....and a good price.  The sangria is also tastey! It's a little loud and crowded...but overall worth a visit.
author: Sydney S.

description:
Been here twice for dinner.  Had lots of Tappas to start while waiting for our Veggie & Seafood Paella. 

Had salad, garlic shrimp, Oxtail stew, cabbage, potatoes, mushrooms & Asparagus.  Then our Paella came.

Overall, the Paella was very very bland.  Disappointing.   The Various Tappas dishes  dishes were okay - not great.  

Service was poor.  We had to constantly wave down a server.  It's loud so don't expect to be able to carry on a conversation without shouting.

I'd suspect there are other better Spanish dining places.  I would not return.
author: Marie E.

description:
Definite fan. I adore spanish food, and esperpento hits the nail on the head. And it's much more fun, festive and attentive (in terms of the staff) environment than picaro on 16th and mission. 

A gal pal and I ordered some delish tapas and a carafe de sangria to share. We ordered the classics -- papas bravas, tortilla espanola, garlic shrimp and then went a little rogue and got the oxtail stew. 

Everything was delicious, especially the tortilla and papas. I haven't had tortilla that delish since I lived in Madrid. Hard to come by GOOD spanish food in SF. I wanted to try the chicken croquetas, but am currently on a diet and tried to avoid fried things. Next time for sure!!! 

OH and the sangria is strong. was definitely more than tipsy upon leaving... a good thing i'd say.

Can't wait to go back to esperpento!
author: Jennifer O.

description: Este lugar me encanta! This place is more authentic than others Ive been to.  Sometimes we order just tapas and other times we do tapas and paella. If you do paella the lobster and seafood paellas are great.  Tapas:  patatas bravas, almejas a la plancha, tortilla, gambas al ajillo, croquettas de pollo...is what we typically order and we devour every bit.  The sangria here is better than their competing restaurants.  If you dont want to wait call ahead.  If you just walk-in then make sure you write your name on the list asap.
author: G. T.

description:
geez...the service here was absolutely horrible!  we had a party of 5 and got a table immediately upstairs.  after receiving our menus, no one was to be found for the next 30 mins.  no water, no server, nothing...we had to walk downstairs and wave down a server.  

finally, someone brought us water and took our order...20 minutes later, we started getting our starters.  we had some chorizo, oxtail stew, mushrooms, and mussels.  out of the 4, the oxtail stew was the best.  it was perfect to dip your bread into...super delish.  the others were just meh...service was still super slow.

for our entree, we ordered the meat and seafood chorizo for 6...it had absolutely no flavor...no saffron...but it did have massive amounts of seafood.  the portion was huge...probably enough to feed more than 6.  worth the price?  yes...but worth ordering again?  no.  

the sangria was quite good...perfect balance of fruit punch and wine.  oh, and the mariachi was beautiful!

other than that, the service really screwed up our experience...and i wouldn't recommend coming back here again.
author: Jen W.

description:
Nice ambience. The food is so-so. Granted we didn't try the signature paella because of shellfish & swine allergies. The service is slow/inattentive (though I'm sure they are nice people). 

The fried snapper was too fishy. Tortilla is average. Pollo adobo is not bad, kinda too sweet. Patatas bravas were good but they went overboard with the garlic sauce, as on every dish we ordered. Decided to skip dessert :p. Sangria is also average. 

Meh.
author: Reem O.

description: Was turned off with the place, cockroach crawled at my friends arm and landed on the plate, told the front of the house manager and was told that they place was sprayed the other day. The point is the place is infested with cockroach, the health department should be told about this.... They should've at least gave us our dinner for free for that incident... The place should be clean and inspected.. Will not come back again ever.
author: Bella S.

description: I love this place.  I keep hearing about the amazing paella and have yet to try it.  But their potatos are great, the oxtail stew was fabulous as was their chirizo.
author: Kim C.

description: Good food (3 stars for that) but FYI they will charge you for bread without telling you, even if you have a large party (minus a star for that cheap move.)
author: Lucy F.

description: I was so exited when I saw a coupon at restaurant. Com. I bought the coupon and made my reservation. unfortunately the rest people said that Rest.com was not paying them. What ever that meant!! So my 25.00 coupon was not valid. They gave me the managers business card and said good bye. Have the website reimburse you. Not good business in my eyes. Any how service was ok food a little better.
author: julie a.

description:
Old fashioned, no frills, high quality tapas. Price is right.  Place is packed. No front greeting area, so if you have a table adjacent to the door, it could be annoying when people come in and out. 

One of my favorites in SF.
author: Dan K.

description:
Took friend here the other evening, for a late lunch/early dinner.


We had:

1- Chorizo salteado.
2- Croquetas de pollo.
3- Rabo de toro.
4- Calamares fritos.
5- Gambas al ajillo.
6- Una botella de Tapeña.
7- Another order of croquetas de pollo.

As always, service was competent and the food was delicious or (para chuparse los dedos o para ponerse las botas). 

Looking forward to my upcoming group visit.

Hasta pronto.
author: Anthony D.

description: I am a huge fan of this place.. Love the food and atmosphere for the most part, but the mariachi guys that come in kind of kill the mood. Since this is spanish food, they would be better off having light spanish guitar or flamenco music. Very irritating, but for the price, you can't beat their food in the mission.
author: matt a.

description:
This review is long overdue... Been coming here for years.  This place makes me happy: takes me back to Barcelona with all the art and the colors on the walls.  (I am not a fan of the modern day restaurant decors that tend to be steril, gray, cold and lifeless...)

*One of the best sangria in the city (and reasonably priced)
*Best stews: rabbit and oxtail
*Patatas Bravas (Bravas sauce is the bomb, ask for some while you wait for your food and dip your bread in it... but don't eat it if you are planning on kissing your date later.
*All their tapas are delicious (you better love garlic...)
*Chocolate mousse and flan for dessert

Great place for large groups and very affordable.  If you have a very large group I suggest you go to Picaro, the sister restaurant on 16th and Valencia although I tend to find the food better at Esperpento, servers are much nicer and the acoustics are better...Picaro is very loud.
I love this place because even on a budget you can eat/share amazing tasty food as well as drink to your heart's content.
Goodness.
author: Monkey B.

description:
It's such an odd name for a paella place. Granted it's a pretty name like "esperanza" (which means "hope"), I think "esperpento" refers to stories that exaggerate reality into grotesque images to highlight society's ills. Or if you type the word into Google's translator, it comes up as "gorgon" - or "terrifying female creature". Huh? Well, I guess it sounds more mysterious than "Carlos' Place". 

I was drawn to the place on Friday because I was perusing Yelp to see what kind of culinary adventure Jamie W. and I could be up for. When I read you could have Lobster Paella for two for $26, I was hooked, and we came early enough to beat most of the crowds there. The vibe is pure Mission...a bit dark, a bit crowded, a bit loud. And all those traits intensified as the evening rolled on. The service was fast and solicitous - which I find refreshing in an otherwise indifferent neighborhood of hipsterdom. 

We went for the $4.50 Patatas Bravas, which were billed as "spicy potatoes", and they weren't kidding. They had a nice crispiness and were definitely pan-fried hot. My one problem with them is that they ladled some kind of sauce that looked a bit like Velveeta but tasted - true to their word - kick-ass spicy with what I assume to be some jalapeno peppers mixed in (see photo). This was the preface, of course, to the Lobster Paella - which came steaming in a traditional paella pan. 

Now I'm no paella snob, but I have been to (ahem) Barcelona where I went to (ahem) 7 Portes Restaurant, the birthplace of paella in (gasp) 1836. But y'know what...they weren't that great at it either. I just think it's a dish best served at home one pan at a time rather than commoditizing it badly (...did you hear that, B44?). Esperpento's paella was certainly decent enough with plenty of ingredients - but no one can seem to escape the inevitable mushiness of the rice. At least they had the semi-burnt crust to chew on toward the end. There were two lobster tails to unshell, about a half-dozen clams, peas and tomatoes, and lots of big calamari rings (see photo). 

It was all pretty good, certainly better than the much louder Picaro a few blocks away, and you can't beat a price like that for fresh lobster tails. But it does make me think I should wipe the dust off my old paella pan and try to make this dish this myself. Hey, I took a cooking class in Barcelona in May - but I was relegated to crema catalunya because I likes me the torch. Oh, who am I kidding? I'll probably come back here when I get the craving, but I'm open to other suggestions. 

FOOD - 3 stars...pretty decent paella for a fair price, especially when they offer lobster tails 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pure Mission bustle with hipsters and yupsters rubbing elbows in a cacophony of tapa-tude 
SERVICE - 4 stars...here's where they excel next to their paella brethren and sistren 
TOTAL - 3.5 stars...still looking for the ultimate paella, so the search continues...until I get off my tookis and make some myself, I guess
author: Ed U.

description: Love this place, their seafood paella is awesome! Also don't forget to order Red Sangria
author: EM R.

description:
This review has been coming for a while. I've eaten here for a range of occasions, most recently my wife's birthday. 7 of us sat downstairs in what is a very lively restaurant. We ordered 2 jugs of sangria (delicious by the way) and proceeded to pick around 20 tapas dishes as well as the paella for 2. 
Each dish, whether the gambas a la plancha or the stewed cabbage, every single item was delicious. 
We sat there for around 2 hours drinking, eating and laughing and then bill came to $36/person - tip included because we were a large group. 
The staff are super friendly so go check it out.
author: Max R.

description: Lunch time is probably the best time to go, you get more food for what you already don't pay much for and the service is at it's best around that time. Even though the service can be on the downside on Fridays and Saturday nights, since the place is so crowded, it still doesn't hinder the food. My meal always comes out quick, steaming hot, and so delicious, not to mention crazy affordable for a restaurant in the city. This place will always be one of my favorite restaurants in the city, I will always take family and friends here if they've never been or new in town! Go tapas!
author: Suria S.

description:
I have been coming here since I was very young because my dad loves their paella.

Absolutely amazing tapas, sangria and paella. I almost never order outside of that because I can't get over how amazing those plates are.

I have travelled Spain, and let me tell you, these guys got it down, 

Best place: for foodies, pre party bites, big family gatherings

Not good for: hyper active children, a quiet environment, anything intimate 

It's pretty loud inside, and it's a tight space. Make a reservation for sure for anything 2+
author: Jacqueline Z.

description: Hmm never mind not so good anymore. Ordered some sausage and it was clearly just spam. Can't pull that trick on me.
author: greg s.

description: I Always have a great experience at this restaurant.   Food is consistent, people are pleasant, pricing is reasonable and Cava is refreshing.  I always look forward in dining here and bring my friends.  I've been coming here for a while now and never once I'm disappointed.
author: Cielo E.

description: Don't eat here! They added extra money to the tip! Be careful and check your bank statement!
author: LoveFood W.

description: Underwhelmed here for sure. Perhaps the issue is a identity crisis. A Spanish tapas place in the heart of Latin Mission. Throwing saffron into everything doesn't make it taste Spanish. Albondigas were bland with a gelatenous yellow sauce, side of potatoes without season, sauteed calamari also bland. Perhaps the dinner menu is more exciting
author: Matt A.

description:
Delicious tapas, you can't go wrong here! Astounded by the quality and price. I've defaulted in the past to cha cha cha, but they definitely have some competition now! 

Good sangria. Tapas we tried and loved: patatas with aioli, gambas a la plancha, clams in spanish marinara, Serrano ham with Spanish style bread and tomato spread, quail, and scallops over rice. 

Portions are solid..6 tapas for the both of us and we were stuffed. Just waiting for the flan now. Every plate we ordered was under $7. WOW!!

The service is super friendly and quick. Can't wait to come back to try their paella!!
author: Liz L.

description:
I came here on a birthday dinner a few weekends ago. On a Saturday night, in a hip place, its going to get busy.

We were a party of 10, so we made a reservation for 7:30 pm. After waiting 10 minutes for them to set up the table and then we were there for another 10 minutes-- they came after we had started drinking our waters and said "There must be some mistake- did you cancel your reservation? because it is crossed out in the book." It turns out, they though we were a different party of 10, which had apparently arrived to be seated. They then also asked if we could sit downstairs, as for they had mistaken us for the other party.  We denied their request, it was cozier and quieter upstairs, and they were nice about it.

now, onto the food:

Sangria is great, not too sweet.
1 pitcher will yield 4 large glasses, 6 small glasses. 

paella: soo good. Make sure to order it first, it takes 30 minutes to make. 
In addition,if you plan on eating a wide selection of food, and have 4 people- get the 2 person paella- or just anticipate leftovers.

Our party wasn't very organized so I don't really remember what we ordered. I had some roasted potatoes, which was very good. Well cooked but not as crispy on the outside as I would have liked.

We also ordered some jamon. I know most people must stray away from it because of the price, but don't. Its worth every last fatty, oily, bite. 

The place is VERY small, so be prepared to get intimate with all of your fellow diners--even if you didn't come with them.

Everyone seems to look onto each others tables, commenting on the different array of dishes that people were ordering, which I kind of liked- but yes, they might be listening in on your very private conversation. 

I will return, but maybe with a smaller group.
author: Michele W.

description:
Why the 2 stars? here's the story.

I knew it was going to be a typical Friday night in the Mission.  Packed. Loud. No parking.

I called 3 days ahead for a reservation at 8 pm for 9 people.  Ideally, everybody should be there on time.  But there's always a lagger.  So we were all present 15 mins. after our reservation time. 

Mike, the host, was professional.  Even though we kept following up (i.e. bugging him) he didn't get his feathers ruffled.  

We also didn't get seated until 45 mins. AFTER our reservation time.  Why even take reservations then?!

Once seated, we were given our water and handed menus.  Our waitress, who SHALL remain nameless, was not a happy camper.  Lady, I know it sucks working on a Friday night -- I work swing shift and there were many, many Friday nights when I'm stuck at work and all my friends were out partying.  Please.  Whatever her problem was it showed on her face and carried onto her attitude. 

The menu is quite varied and for vegetarians, I'm happy to report that there are more than a few options available.

A few yelpers also recommended the paella. The special for that night was lobster and calamari paella, we went with the $48 portion which serves 4 people (instead of the $68 for 6). We also wanted to try the meat paella. But got talked out of it.

Our waitress puts in her "helpful" suggestion and says, "well, are you sure you want ALL that pella?"

"Well, you haven't seen my brother eat."  I jokingly said while pointing to my 6 foot, 200 lb. sibling. 

Her: "yeah, but you'll be ordering tapas. That would be a lot of food"

Me: "we would like to try a different paella too. Can't we just box the leftovers to go?"

Her: "yeah. sure."

At this point, I felt like I was arguing with our server so I just dropped it. 

The whole table shared and enjoyed every bite of these delicious tapas:

3 plates of spicy patatas bravas, jamon serrano, oxtail stew, grilled asparagus, 3 plates of calamares fritos, 2 plates of gambas al ajillo, grilled salmon and our paella. 

Esperpento's sangria isn't as fruity or chilled like cha cha cha's.  I obviously prefer cha cha cha's version but it still gave me the wicked buzz I needed. 

You should've seen my bro's face when they brought out the tapas though. 

"this is it??" he almost looked panicky.

To be fair, the portions are priced right and generous than most tapas places (ahem, Medjool) with plates ranging from $4-$10.   My bro just has a big appetite.  So that was a bad decision on my part. I should've ordered that second paella because I know my brother more than our waitress.  She did check up on us, but quite frankly, we saw the busboy more often.  BTW, we didn't even get offered dessert!  hmmph.

Solid food at Esperpento.  

If you don't mind the wait, even with a reservation.

And just hope that you end up with a better server than we did.
author: Janice C.

description: We were brought by the wrist to Esperpento by a vegetarian. Yet another average tapas restaurant. The price/quality ratio just wasn't there. Serves your average watery juicy sangria. Esperpento is designed for the undiscerning diner. The only decent part of the meal was the paella. Moral of the story, don't let a vegetarian choose what tapas restaurant you should go to.
author: Michael C.

description:
I went here with a friend because it was the first place we found the second we got hungry (being in the Mission that meant we didn't have to be hungry for too long, haha). We didn't expect much--there were maybe 3 other tables taken, it seemed pretty quiet and homey, menus were outside and it was seat-yourself.

The lunch specials looked incredibly affordable so we weren't sure how much we'd actually get, and were THRILLED with the bang we got for our buck. We each got a lunch special--she got the grilled trout and I decided on the garlic shrimp, and not only did we get that, but the lunch special came with two sides (cabbage + salad for both of us, the cabbage was considerably better and it was silly of us to order 2 of pretty much the same things, the salad was a little too oily), surprise soup, and bread. The shrimp dish actually came with a whole small plateful of shrimp, and was very flavorful. Only downside to the food was that to me it was all a little too oily, but some people love that and it was still overall good, so I still really enjoyed my experience.

People were very nice and service was suuuper fast. Would eat here again!
author: Katie V.

description: Super friendly staff, place is cute and we got the little nuck seat for 2 :) The food was incredible - ordered the tapas which was the potatoes with spicy sauce, so so good and the cabbage...oh, being Polish I was very excited about the cabbage and it was incredible with olive oil, garlic and paprika. Sangria is yummy with a hint of sweetness.
author: Magda G.

description: They have the best Sangria in the Bay Area. The Mucilla , Griled Shrimp, Artichoke are the also awesome.
author: Sam M.

description: I would definitely come back to try their paella and have a glass of that amazing sangria that I'm drinking right now :)
author: Fedor T.

description:
A FANTASTIC Spanish tapas restaurant. Having traveled to Spain, I have high standards that often leave me comparing the food in the states to what I enjoyed there.

I started with the Gambas Al Ajillo, based on other Yelp reviews. At $7, this dish is a hidden gem. The plate held about 10 Jumbo shrimp, swimming in a delicious pool of garlic and olive oil, seasoned perfectly and not overcooked. I decided I needed some carbs to compliment the protein, so faithful to my Yelpers, I tried the Patatas Bravas. 

Let me just say OH MY GOD. I was in heaven. The cubes of lightly fried potatoes was dressed with the most yummy sauce I have ever experienced. Spicy and creamy, I was double-dipping every potato in it, and then the bread too. I was trying to break  down the ingredients in my head so I could re-create it at home. Priced at $4.50, they are giving it away. It was large enough to share, considering the 'tapas' description. 

Finally, the Sangria was good. Not as memorable as those damn potatoes. But good enough to be a companion to one of the most amazing meals I've ever had. 

Service was good. Waitress was nice and accommodating, but the host, not so friendly. I sat outside, cafe-style, to enjoy the people watching.. so I cant comment on the interior. But no wait and good neighborhood.
author: Debra C.

description: We had our company Christmas dinner here for the second year in a row, and it was again fabulous.  The large sized paella's are perfect for a big group of hungry people!  And the tapas we ordered for appetizers were equally delicious.  We tried all of the different paellas, and they were all extremely tasty with generous portions of seafood and meat in them, even lobster tails.  The service was friendly and prompt.  We love the atmosphere here- very laid back and european feeling.  Couldn't find a nicer place to celebrate the holidays at!
author: Sam M.

description: Worst restaurant in the east bay. If u plan on going don't!!! Order the paella. Took over an hour. Okay that's long but what came out the kitchen wasn't paella. Overcooked rice. Old prawns and fish that had basically seen better days. I'm shocked people were queueing to get in! Crazy.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Came here on two separate occasions. First time was with a big group for a birthday and second time for a smaller-ish group dinner. Had a great experience both tines. Drinks and food are top notch.

Get pitchers of sangria. Gets you to a happy place at minimal expense. Paella is another cheap way to fill up, plus delicious too. Other tapas were delicious also. Can't remember specifics (probably because of the sangria) but I guarantee that it was delicious!
author: Sherry L.

description:
**Be sure to thoroughly look over your check before paying!*

I really don't know if it's all servers here or just this one, but we were almost charged a gratuity without knowing.  Had we not figured out that our male server added a gratuity of 20%, we would have paid that PLUS regular tip over the whole amount.  Checks are hand written, so it's difficult to catch.

Needless to say, dude was not happy that he got caught.  He doesn't speak english very well, so I spoke with one of his colleagues and asked if this is a common practice  to add 20% gratuity on a 4 top table at their restaurant. He said no, and this is the only server that does it.  He also said that they don't take things like this off the check unless someone catches it and complains, so I don't know how legal that is.  

Either way, I'm super peeved and will never be coming here again.  Sad day, I loved this place and came here quite often.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Took a friend here from out of town a couple of weeks ago.  Had the artichokes.  They're sliced thin on a mandolin and fried (not breaded), fantastic!  The whole fried anchovies were great as well.  Not salted like the fillets.  While we have our favorites, we always like to add something new to the menu. Definitely make reservations! My son, an SFSU student at the time first found Esperpento on Yelp.
It's a fun place with great food!
author: Casey T.

description: Great food and definitely a solid choice for happy hour. Get the sangria, Patras bravas and the artichokes, you won't be disappointed.
author: E S.

description:
To summarize...the tapas here desperately lack flavor (although they are very moderately priced), so they come with Aioli on the side on every plate to add a little something...little do they know that their Aioli lacks any garlic flavor so it's really just mayonnaise which sucks too! Sorry!

We stayed safe and ordered basics stuff...Patatas Bravas were very unseasoned BUT they were cooked/fried very well (they came with the "aioli"). Fried Calamari was in thick rings with very bland batter (it also came with the "aioli"). The Deep Fried Snapper was...in big chunks, very bland and unseasoned, oh and it came with the "aioli"!! The grilled asparagus spears...surprise - came with "aioli"!! Oh but the sauteed mushrooms were pretty delicious. 

I didn't mind the lack of flavor in almost every dish because I was ravenous (also buzzed) and at least everything was cooked well and tasted how I would expect it to taste (minus being bland of course). And sometimes plain food isn't a bad thing...plain and predictable is better than fancy and nasty.

I was also very satisfied after eating an entire basket of French Bread which comes with salted butter!!...which they rarely give you at restaurants. It's usually always sweet cream butter (boo to that!).
author: Jessica C.

description:
I think Esperpento rightfully has a 3-3.5 star rating. Most their dishes are good but nothing spectacular, including their calamari, shrimp, and oxtail. (It's oxtail soup, not stew, mind you.)

Their best dishes were their clams and patatas bravos. Something heavenly is in that spicy potato sauce!! Their service is very fast, but attention to the tables is kind of sparse, and their sangria is tasty, but a bit watered-down.

I had a good time here, I won't lie... so maybe in my drunkeness I liked the place more than expected. But all in all, just A-OK. Good, but it won't necessarily win me back for another round...
author: Joanne Y.

description: This place is changing, we ordered the parrillada and it's less meat then few years back. The chairs of the restaurant are very uncomfortable, the space is very small and very, very, very loud, you cannot have a normal conversation. We spilled a glass of sangria on top of the table and go to my friend suit. We got help from the people on the other table that they run to an empty table to pick up napkins.... Finally we got more napkins from a waiter, then when I asked him if they have a mop to dry the floor... He stated: "we do not have a mop", so he give us more napkins, maybe 20 to dry the floor... HELLO!!! What kind the place is this???? We sat the rest of the diner above a Matt of red and white napkins and pieces of Apple. Sad costumer service.
author: Joe V.

description:
Great sangria...don't remember the food.

I think there was...
Sausage
Lobster
Clam
Artichoke
author: Margaret R.

description: One of my favorite tapa places in the city!!! Always fresh food, great service and people watching spot. I bring all my friends that visit SF to this place and they all love it. sangria, Garlic shrimp, mushrooms and scallops are my favorite. :)
author: Masha S.

description:
In one word, underwhelming. I came to Esperpento for a birthday dinner. The restaurant was pretty accommodating with our party of 8. There was also live music, which was fun but just a tad too loud for me. I had to shout to my friend who was sitting right next to me.

We shared the paella with mixed seafood--which was really bland in flavor. I took leftovers home and just doused it in sriracha. That seemed to do the trick. I also had the potatoes with aioli and the calamari. The staff was really friendly, and the food came out really quickly, but that's really all the praise that I can give.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
MAKE RESERVATIONS.... or prepare to stand in line (even on a Thursday evening!!)

The food is aight....

The LOBSTER PAELLA was not as good as I thought it was going to be. Lacked the right flavor, was a little soggy, and too stingy on the seafood.

The famous SPICY POTATOES tasted like potato wedges with a tangier buffalo sauce.

The GARLIC SHRIMP APPETIZER  was good, but if you like that, maybe you should come over to my place for dinner because I'll give you a better deal.

Esperpento is decent, but I don't agree with the "Michelin Recommended" award.
author: Jess C.

description: Place has outstanding paellas and sangrias!  It's a father and son owned with authentic taste of Spain. This place is small so definitely call ahead or you'll be waiting to get seated. The place can get very loud so if you're looking for a quiet and relaxing place, this is not the right place. Place is vibrant, lots of energy, and everyone is enjoying their delisioso food!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Went here to celebrate my August bday fds. Glad that we made a resevation a day ahead. There was a line when we got there around 7pm. This place was pretty big and well designed. There was a guy playing guitar, but it was loud for us because what we really wanted was enjoy the food and talk. 

Anyways, the food was pretty good. We had spicy potatoes, fried calamri, Almejas A La Marinera, oyster, some sausage, and the seafood Paella. Highly recommend the spicy potato and seafood Paella. Portion was kinda small. Good service and nice environment for groups.
author: Suki W.

description:
Terrible, terrible service. Won't be coming back here for mediocre food because the service makes the experience ten times worse.

A friend had made a reservation for our party, but when we arrived they said that someone had called and changed our reservation completely (I'm certain it's more like they didn't write down the reservation at all).... so we had to wait an hour to be seated even though the waiter kept saying it would just be '5 minutes!"

We sat down and ordered everything at once, but one of our dishes took an hour to get onto the table, and when it finally arrived it was the wrong order. We tried to send it back but the waitress acted as if it were a big deal, rolled her eyes, told us we should just eat it anyways. We couldn't because we had friends with food allergies.

When we were asked how everything was, we said we were disappointed that one of our dishes took so long. We were met with hostility and the waiter seemed to think we were lying, so we all had to verify with him that yes, indeed, it took that long. 

No apologies, no comps, nothing but rude and hostile comments. 
Sangria was good, the spicy potatoes were okay. Really, nothing to write home about so don't bother with this place. Go across the street to the Latin American Club and order a strong margarita instead.
author: Tara R.

description: Wow amazing! Came here on a Monday night (re-opens at 5) for dinner and to our surprise they had a special on paellas! Yum the special came with sangria, main course and flan for dessert for only $28 for 2! We  added the potato's with salsa brava mmmmm!! So good! Our bill was only $35 and was completely satisfied! 5 stars well deserved!
author: Cesar R.

description:
Every time I pass this place, there is a crowd waiting outside. I usually take that as a mental note that the food must be good. So this weekend, I finally got to try Esperpento. The decor is bright and festive. I like how they use alternating jewel toned and brick colors throughout. 

My husband and I shared:
- Ropa vieja (beef) with rice
- Gambas Al Ajillo garlic shrimp
- Patatas bravas (spicy potatoes)

I also had the sangria which was delicious. It had fresh bits of apple and orange in it. Mmm :) My only critique about the food is that the beef was a bit tough and the shrimp were drowning in butter. The shrimp were delicious, don't get me wrong. But butter does not agree with my hips.

I wasn't blown away, but I have a feeling maybe this is the kind of place that will grow on me over time.
author: Mariela D.

description: The atmosphere is casual, they have random musicians walking in and playing for customers.  Outside seating of 2 tables, inside seating is a bit crowded and lighting inside is low, but that is what makes the atmosphere different. Ordered Sangria and to my surprise it didn't have an after taste of bitterness that I've tasted in other places, it was sweet and very good! We ordered the paella mix or meat and seafood, it took 30 minutes to get our order but we were warned since it states this on the menu. Once our paella arrived it was very warm since it came straight out the oven. The food was very good and didn't have many spices like others I've tasted.  Shrimp poop was not removed a bit of the down side, mussels and clams were baked, it also had pieces of chicken and pork mixed. Overall the food was good!
author: Erika P.

description: Good food, reasonable prices. Service is  OK, this place gets really crowded, so get early if you want a table.
author: Nath P.

description:
This is the place I go to for a nice lunch with my parents, or my parents and their friends. 

The waiters are very friendly, and even when it was busy one afternoon and they took FOREVER, they were apologetic, still friendly, with no attitude. I've only managed to remember Lucero's name, shes one of our usual waitresses. She already knows all of our usual orders by heart. 

She just sees us and says, "Gambas al ajillo, salad-with no onions- and stewed zucchini?" 
Me: Yes
(then looks at my mom) Lucero: Red Snapper with papas, and rice?
Mom: Si.

I'm in LOVE with their GAMBAS AJILLO SHRIMP! If you order the lunch combo, you get the gambas ajillo shrimp (or a bunch of other choices) with your choice of two sides.  AND You also get a cup of the soup of the day!  The soup of the day is always delicious and tastes like fresh soup your grandma would make just for you. 

The Gambas ajillo shrimp has the most delicious garlic sauce on it, that makes my mouth water. I would always take the complementary bread, soak it in the sauce and eat it along with the shrimp.
author: Sophia G.

description:
Tip: Especially if you're in a big group, pick a tapas buddy among your crew. Most tapa dishes here are perfect to split between two people.

Definitely on the pricey end of things, but everything was acceptably tasty. Brocheta de vieiras (scallops on a brochette (see: stick)) was good, as was the tortilla de patata and the champinones al ajillo (mushrooms in garlic sauce). Estofado de conejo (rabbit stew) was a little underwhelming since it just tasted like dry turkey. Sangria selection was nice, but nothing special.

Highlight of the meal was the squid ink paella. Blackest blackness ever, and it'll stain your teeth for a day. Rumor is that it comes out the other end the same way... :P
author: Kevin L.

description: Meat paella is the bomb. Enjoy with a friend over good conversation. I use the dressing that comes with the bread on the house salad. That's my pro tip
author: Angela O.

description: Easily the BEST tapas I've ever had. That being said, I haven't been to Spain yet but I'm pretty sure it wouldn't beat this place. I randomly came here for take out at the end of a long work day. My friends were at the bar across the street but they didn't serve food, so some people on the street raved about Esperpento. It's adorable inside, and I would have loved to go back to dine in! Service was warm, my food came quickly, THE GARLIC SHRIMP WAS AMAZING and it was a great value. I had the shrimp, a side of cabbage and their potatoes. Everything was SO tasty. I'm definitely going back next time I'm in town!
author: Kalong W.

description: This is a fun place to eat. The food is delicious, and the service is friendly. We've had many wonderful tapas here including the grilled asparagus, bacalao croquettes, chicken croquettes, fried anchovies, shrimp in garlic, clam stew, fried peppers, patatas bravas, and patatas aioli. The only thing we haven't been fond is the spinach béchamel (too much béchamel, not enough spinach). The seafood paella is excellent and an excellent value. On weekends, neighborhood musicians wander through from time to time, playing latin music (and taking donations). It's a fun, lively, not-fancy place we'll go back to again and again.
author: David K.

description:
This place is great for tapas. Grilled artichoke and ox tail stew with dipping sauce was amazing. 
Their host is fantastic lady!
author: Sabina A.

description:
An interesting little tapas place in the Mission.  For those of you who haven't been but have had tapas in Spain, let me first lay out some important differences in how stuff goes down:

- When you order drinks, don't expect tapas to come for free along with it.  You will be greatly disappointed.

- When you order your tapas, don't expect there to be one for everyone, it usually comes as a lump item that you divvy up.

- Don't expect traditional tapas (for better of for worse).  They definitely make food following their own flair at this place.

We rocked up a few minutes late with a group of 6 when we went to the restaurant Friday night.  There was a birthday or 2 there, and the place was PACKED.  I'm honestly not sure how they meet fire code, but whatever.  After a semi-short wait, we got seated at an awkward round + square table, before requesting to move to a different round + square table combination that seemed to have more space.  While a little awkward for our group, we ended up making it work well enough.

Our waiter was nice enough, though he seemed a little stressed; likely due to the MASSES of people in the restaurant.  We ordered 3 rounds of Sangria, which was good, in addition to the following food items:

+ Garlic chicken (decent)
+ Pollo Adobo (boring, don't get it)
+ Both kinds of potato dishes (which were amazing)
+ Asparagus (good)
+ Mushrooms (good, but tasted kind of like Chinese food)

and some other items I didn't try... (shrimp, other seafood, etc).  Everyone seemed pretty happy with our meal, but we definitely ordered a few rounds of potatoes as they were clearly superior to everything else on the menu.

In summary, the place was fun and interesting.  I don't know that I'd go back under my own plans, but I wouldn't argue if a friend suggested it.  

The waiter split our bill 5 ways, which was nice of him not to complain about it too much.  They added an automatic (18%, I assume) tip for our large-ish group.
author: Brian B.

description: Esperpento is the closest I've come to authentic Spanish food in the Bay Area. My all-time favorite dish of theirs is the tortilla de patata or their jamon serrano plate. I love that their menu reflects traditional home-cooked meals and that their decor reflects the food and Spanish culture. Everything I've ordered there has been delicious. This is my go-to place if I'm every craving Spanish food. They won't disappoint.
author: Maya R.

description:
PROS: Esperpento is a place worthy of repeat visits. The food was delicious, authentic Spanish cuisine made with fresh quality ingredients. The night we ate at Esperpento, they had musicians playing Spanish tunes, which lent to an authentic experience. 

Our group ordered the Gambas Al Ajillos (Garlic Shrimp), Jamon and Queso, Tortilla De Patata (potato and onion omelete), Paella De Mariscos Or Seafood, and Paella with Black Squid Ink. All the dishes were absolutely delicious!

CONS: The noise level is off the charts. It's a small place so seating is limited, a long wait could be in your cards. 

BOTTOM LINE: The food is most definitely worth overlooking the noise level.
author: Malia C.

description:
My aunt called for a reservation and by the time we got there, apparently they didn't have it listed. We ended up waiting outside for quite a while before being seated upstairs. We were a party of like 10 and it was cramped and dark upstairs.

The service was horrible, they barely attended to our needs and it took a VERY long while to catch their attention. 

The food however, was thankfully superb. The potatoes are highly recommended. The paella is a far cry from the ones I've tried in Spain but it was really good. 

When we got our bill (after a long time) they charged 20% for service charge. I honestly thought that they didn't deserve that much, so when I complained the waitress gave me a look and was completely rude about it. Let it be known that it doesn't matter how damn good the food was, if your service is horrible, that will HIGHLY impact the customer's perception. Good to try, don't think I'm coming back again.
author: Angela L.

description:
Vegetarian POV: 3.5 STARs

Came here with some friends for Friday Night dinner and I was pleasantly suprised(call ahead and make reservations). Service can be slow at times, but the food made up for that.

They have a lot of options for veggie tapas as well as a veggie paella too.

Drinks: We (the ladies) ordered the Sangria (it was light and refreshing...there wasn't much alcohol in it...sad). -1 star

Appetizers: Some cabbage, eggplant, potatoes, and another tapas..all were very yummie

Entree: Vegetarian Paella - so good, it was very hot, but now that I think back, we should've eatten the tappas and mixed it with the paella...more textural contrast. This Paella is very buttery not spicey at all (which i was sad about) -0.5 star

It was overall awesome and I'd definitely come here again because they have an awesome variety of Tapas that I haven't seen anywhere else.
author: Navdha V.

description:
I've wanted to come here ever since seeing it on Check Please years ago, so I was delighted to find out this was our Valentine's Day destination. The place got pretty full but the host was very polite and accommodating about everyone's needs. 

I'd really liked the looks of the menu, as it's quite broad and had a lot of options, for tapas, paellas, and dinner plates. We had the pan con tomate, patatas bravas, estofado e conejo, and carne paella. 

The rabbit stew may have been the best dish. The meat was succulent and tender, and all of the broth was delicious with the complimentary bread. The cooked carrots had absorbed the flavor as well. The patatas bravas were less fried than they tend to be at a lot of places, which I enjoyed. If you have these, make sure everyone at the table has them, as the sauce is tasty but bracingly redolent of garlic. The paella was a pretty large amount for two people ( in addition to the tapas beforehand). There was a lot of meat - the darkest sausage was pretty strong. 

I was impressed that the prices were so low given that each portion was quite large (at the price, I was expecting something tiny). My only complaint was that the wine, while priced cheaply, also tasted a bit cheap. This was the first time I'd ever wished for more expensive wine options in a restaurant (in SF at least).
author: Lisa K.

description: Seafood paella is great and wasn't salty. That is a plus. Ordered the meat platter and was yummy. Wasn't salty. Rabbit stew is great and goes well with. Ate with 5 peope.
author: Justin C.

description:
People who like this place fall into one of three categories: never had decent tapas, just stupid, all of the above. A hint this was going to be a less-than-stellar experience was the grimy, sticky table. We.should.have.left.then. We didn't. 

Let's go straight to the food. Chicken croquettes. Four on the plate. The first one was cold in the center. They took the remaining three back, somehow warmed them up and brought them back. The centers were now at least room temperature and of course the four were now just three. I suppose if really hungry I could have gone back to the picked-apart cold one left on my plate. I shouldn't fail to mention they were served with a gelatinous goo that was actually intentionally put on the plate. Disgusting. 

Next course - Jamon Serrano canapes of spanish cured ham on toasted french bread served with ripe tomatoes and olive oil. The bread was just the typical low-cost, airy commodity type of bread you might find in a discount grocery store. I took one bite and left the rest of the dish on the dish. Nest came the Stew Of White Beans And Clams. The clams were over cooked and rubbery. The grilled asparagus, eaten by just my guest, seemed OK. Later in the afternoon she was lying down with an upset stomach. Coincidence? Who knows. The Patatas Bravas never arrived. They forgot.

I'm warning you. Stay away. Do not encourage them to attempt cooking...it can only end badly. You've been warned.
author: Gary C.

description:
This place gets packed, as in packed, by 6 pm.  We just made it in time to even choose our table.  

We started off with a pitcher of Sangria.  I had 4 glasses, so that says a lot.

Appetizers of anchovies in olive oil and the Jamon serrano, which was cured ham on french bread.  Both were really good, super yummy.  If you're on a date and you order the Jamon serrano, make sure you cut it with your knife.  It's pretty challenging to bite both the meat and the bread with your teeth :)

We had the seafood paella and soup.  I wasn't a fan of the soup but the paella was super.  And I kept digging in.  It was so good!  And was actually a big portion.  But at $23, good for 2, I thought the paella was a little expensive. 

Desserts of course!  We ordered crema catalana and chocolate mousse - both were winners!

Oh and did I tell you about the man with his guitar who serenaded our table?  Good times!
author: Pam S.

description: My co worker turned me on this this place 6 years ago and I've never went to another tapas place after. Must haves: Lobster Tails, Grilled Artichokes, Spicy Potates, Morcilla (blood sausage).
author: Charlie T.

description:
