We had (ordered most fave to least fave): patatas bravas, Catalonian sausage, garlic chicken, fried calamari and the tortilla de patata (aka spanish omelette with potato).  Now even though I list these from most favorite to least favorite, they were ALL great!  The sauce on the patatas bravas was amazing the potatoes were cooked perfectly.  The Catalonian sausage slices were served on pieces of french bread, which was a great combination.  The garlic chicken was flavorful & moist.  The calamari was fried perfectly, not too chewy and had a tasty aioli dipping sauce.  Finally, the tortilla really brought be back to visiting Spain and felt lighter than the other dishes we had.

All in all, the food and service were fantastic.  Both the hostess who seated us and our waitress were really friendly and attentive.  Our food came out amazingly fast and   was, as described, delicious.  I will definitely be back to Esperpento to try more of their tapas and perhaps the paella!

P.S. They serve Torres wine here (Sangre de Toro) and everyone should drink it because it's awesome :)
author: Liz H.

description:
I have been going to this restaurant for at least 5 times with friends and coworkers. At first I really liked it because of the atmosphere, paella and especially their sangria. But then I realized that all they serve is actually frozen food or lets say pre-prepared food and all they do is put it in the microwave. 

The paella takes like 30 minutes which is ok since that is what it normally takes anywhere, the paella is not good. Compared to others that I have tried in Spain and Puerto Rico, not good. But I guess people don't really care much. I also order croquetas and all those small portions or tapas that there is which is pretty ok since they are like fried little empanadas, not bad. 

But when it comes to ordering those dinner combinations in the middle of the menu you must know the following. For instance, I ordered the Garlic Shrimp with rice and salad. They DO NOT clean the shrimp, plus they are the same size than the ones you can buy in a baggy in Safeway, not even jumpo real shrimps plus dirty as hell, they don't cut them open. So I had to one by one cut them open, clean them and then eat. This was a turn off, why? because if you are offering the same shrimps that you can buy in Sakeway special baggies, at least get the ones that are clean, which by they way are the same price. 

The rice, not even start with that. Completely rice from the box, Their yellow rice is totally one of those Hambuger Helper rice boxes. Not kidding! When the server comes to check on everything I kindly tell him that the shrimps were not cleaned that I wasn't just letting him know so that he can pass it to the manager, he says "I guess the germs or dirt goes away when you cook them"  not an excused! 

Sangria is always really good. That is all I can say. Oh! and I don't think I am bringing anyone else to this restaurant! Too expensive for just FROZEN FOOD :(
author: Ibelig V.

description:
had a dinner party for 12 the other night and the place was PACKED!

Esperpento has an awesome vibe, a friendly staff, and a mariachi trio walking around all night...

VERY LOUD RESTAURANT

food was pretty good all around. good selection of tapas and paellas

being that we had 12 people at the table, we ordered 3 paellas...1 large Paella De Mariscos and 2 smaller paellas...1 Paella De Carne and 1 squid ink seafood paella...perfect amount for 12 hungry people...

the rest of the dinner was filled with different tapas (my 3 favorites were the Oxtail stew, Gambas Al Ajillo, garlic shrimp and the Chorizo Salteado "Cantimpalitos" sauteed spanish sausage) and lots of sangria and beer...

definitely recommend you go to Esperpento to try their paellas and tapas...all the paellas were nice and crispy on the bottom of the pan and seasoned pretty well too.

the paellas take 30 minutes or so to come out so make sure you order your paella as soon as youre seated, then, order the rest of your meal...

price wise...i thought the paellas were a bit expensive...i mean cmon, its just rice and stuff right? definitely recommend coming with a larger group so you can share this and that with everyone...either way, regardless of the price...the food definitely makes up for it.
author: Kyu L.

description: I went here with my sparring partners and his wife on 12-15-13 5:20pm'sh.  I ordered the meatball stew with salad and zucchini, the servers brought out bread, butter and water.  One of them ordered chicken adobo, I think the other partner and his wife ordered the salmon and two glasses of red wine.  I thought the food was pretty good, I used the bread to soak up rest of the stew, service was attentive.
author: Jer W.

description:
Despite the crowded restaurant and its small space, the four of us were seated promptly (we made a reservation prior). I thought the service was efficient and food came out really quick, as though they have it prepared already. Nevertheless, everything was quite fresh as they seem to be.

We ordered:

Sauteed Mushrooms
(great, nice char)

Grilled Artichokes
(thinly sliced for chewing convenience. They were roasted perfectly)

Garlic Shrimps
(It's alright. Nothing great, really. Small shrimps, not quite the chunk)

Fried Calamari
(As always, 99% can never mess up deep-fried food)

Chicken Croquettes
(Fabulous! Crispy on the outside and tender, creamy in the inside. Comes 4pieces an order with a spinach bechamel dip on side)

Clams + Snapper
(Seems soupy. This dish is alright, nothing wrong, nothing too great)

Zucchini with house marinara (or something)
(Mushy, so stay away if you are not into mushy vegetables)

Arroz con Leche
(meh-it's on the light side. A little water)

Flan
(Excellent. I almost never order flan anywhere because I felt that it's usually too sweet or too egg-y. So I'm quite surprised with the one here)

Would probably come back for their extensive tapas variety and affordable price. I still need to try their patatas bravas.
author: Rika P.

description:
Wonderful!  Would go back in a second.  Super reasonable! We had a party of 7 - all ages and food preferences....including on vegetarians and serious meat eaters and seafood eaters.  All loved it!  We had heard that downstairs is quite noisy...so we made a reservation for upstairs...which was a little more quiet.  The service was very good and the food was really delicious.  Can't believe how inexpensive it was!!
Also...they had really affordable bottles of good wine.  Super casual and warm vibe.
Love this place.
author: Shelby C.

description:
I used to like this place, but not so much anymore.

First of all, the waiter messed up on our order. We wanted the grilled prawns - but before we ordered it, I clearly asked the waiter if the prawns were cleaned, head off, shell off, etc. "Yes", said he - but when the prawns arrived, head shell tail and eyes were all still on. My sister was none to pleased. We asked if the heads could be removed but the manager said that the cook was too busy. Yes, too busy because there was 3 tables full at the restaurant. Then she said that we should have checked with the water before ordering. Hello?

We had also ordered clams with garlic sauce. But, lo and behold, out came clams with marinara sauce. Hmmm. 

Food was also not as good as I remember. The fried anchovies were soggy. 

But the Patas Bravas were good - love the spicy sauce.
author: Nick K.

description:
Meat and Seafood paella mmm mmm goood!!
The grilled artichokes were delicious!!! Great amount of flavor!
I would come back here again!
author: Annie H.

description:
I rarely ever have Spanish food, the last time I had it was almost 7-8 years ago. 
I don't know much about Spanish food except for paella, but I went here with my family and we ordered tapas that the kind waitress suggested and what sounded good to us.
My favorites include garlic shrimp, grilled artichokes, and sauteed calamari (we ordered it twice bc it was soooo good).
My brother got seared scallops which were also very delicious.
We also ordered paella but I'm not a big fan in general and can't really judge it.
I recommend this place to anyone willing to try Spanish food, I was super full and didn't want to stop eating!
author: Kathleen H.

description: Best Lobster Paella on God's green earth. The steamed mussels and clams are fantastic too! Generous portions of lobster tails in the paella. The rice is cooked perfectly and not mushy. The paella is made to order and can take up to 20 minutes. The paella is big enough to share between 3-4 people but do get a couple appetizers to start. You wont regret it.  Esperpento has set the standard for Latin tapas in my book. Paella at Picaro, Julian Serrano and Cha Cha Cha tries but falls short. Genuine, down to earth service. A very satisfying dinner indeed. I'm taking my mom here, she's a seafood fanatic and will absolutely love everything here!
author: Thuy M.

description:
3.5 star review.

1st time at a tapas restaurant and it won't be the last!  (even tho the b/f was a lil bitter about me choosing a SPANISH place since his Mexican pride was hurt (yea yea put history behind Spanish took over Mexico awhile ago)).  

ANYWHO...  onto the PROS:
1. environment-  i liked the vibe/decor lots of ppl chatting
2. decent prices-tapas are between $4-9
3. satisfying tapas w. perfect, if not a lil large than expected portions
4. decent service- attentive enough esp. since it was busy

CONS:
1. disappointed w/ portion for grilled artichokes 
($5.5 maybe 8 2cm thick slices)

2. Sangria-  IMO tasted like red wine; lacked fruitiness- but really, everyone else on Yelp seemed to like it, so it could be just me.  i like mine fruity n chilled.

WHAT I CONSUMED:
1. Garlic Shrimp- so simple yet good.  the garlic & red pepper infused oil goes perfectly w/the bread that comes w/all tapas  

2. Potatas Bravas- sauce reminds me of La Vics!  ya'll SJ ppl know what im talking about.  cubed fried potatoes were good, not great.

3. Fried Calamari-  small portion for the price $6.5. 8 pieces at most.  glistening in grease which inevitably made them soggy in no time (and hey, i do like grease but not this)

4. Grilled Salmon w. Aioli-  nice portion ~6 thin strips and i loved the grilled red onions that came with it

5. Grilled Artichokes w. garlic & parsley- scrumptious yet the outer edges are rough n can't be eaten so have fun spitting them out while ur eating!  but it's worth the effort.

DAMAGE:  5 tapas, 1 glass of Sangria, 1 coke= $40 + tip  ... NOT bad.

OVERALL,  I would come back..  I want the paella, but for $26 for 2 ppl (plus everything else i wanna order)?  i'll have to hold off on that for a month!  In conclusion, Yes, it is loud.  Yes, service isn't the best , but WTH, it IS a low-key place, and the tapas come at great price.
author: Kimberly C.

description: A friend celebrated their birthday here. I came a bit late because it's a pain in the behind to find good parking around that area. With two floors for seating, the place was buzzin' like bees. Once I was settled in my spot around our huge table, some of the tapas that were ordered began to arrive. I tried the chicken croquettes, garlic shrimp, grilled mussels, fried calamari, Jamon Serrano, chorizo, sauteed mushrooms, spicy potatoes, and the meat and seafood paella. Everything was great. I even think their sangria tastes much better than the one from another tapas place I've tried in SF. I would love to come back here again with a smaller group.
author: Rhia R.

description:
I came here to have dinner with a close friend. I hadn't dabbled much in Spanish food so I really wanted to try it.
I never realized how much they love their oil! The food all had great flavors except I'm not a big fan of oil so it was a bit too much for me to handle.

Here's what we got... the seared calamari... this was amazing! Cooked to perfection, not chewy at all, just nice and tender. The grilled Salmon was also very good but I ate a piece that was too oily for my liking but it was still very good. And we shared their garlic chicken entree with rice and cabbage. The flavors were amazing.. so much garlic! I love garlic! And their cabbage was perfect. 
Everything was very flavorful. Next time, if I go I want to try more of their seafood options. They had a very impressive seafood tapas menu!
author: Debbie P.

description:
This is my favorite place for tapas in the city.  It seems pretty authentic to me because it reminds me of having tapas in Spain.  The paella is good too and the prices are reasonable.

I went there a few weeks ago with some friends and we had the gambas, meatballs, asparagus, calamari, tortilla with potatoes, and the mixed paella.  Everything was delicious. For dessert we had the chocolate mousse and the flan.  The chocolate mousse was amazing!

The only negative thing I can say is it tends to get loud.
author: Sylvie P.

description:
What the hell happened to this place? I went there tonight and left sad...so, so sad. It really pains me to leave this review, but people need to know. This is NOT the Esperpento of old. I haven't been here in 3-4 years, and it's really changed.  I don't know if they've changed owners or what, but it was pretty bad.

A little background: I've been coming here for years. This used to be my favorite place for reasonably-priced Spanish food. I can't say it was the best Spanish food in the Bay Area, but I always felt it was very solid for the price. And the informal, lively atmosphere really reminded me of the tapas bars of Spain. I've been to Spain numerous times, and my girlfriend's family is from Galicia. I've had amazing Spanish food, and I've been to just about every Spanish place in the Bay Area. I know it will never be the same over here in the US, but I've had solid renditions of classic dishes at other restaurants (Zarzuela, for example).

Ugh...so where to start with this place. The food was so sub-par, it was embarrassing. I actually picked up the tab for my party of 5, because I felt ashamed for having suggested the place. So here's my take on the dishes:

--pimientos de padron: decent, but not great. I've had better in the Bay Area (let alone Spain).
--ensalada mixta: again decent, but not great. Definitely smaller portion than before.
--calamares a la plancha: absolutely horrible! This used to be my favorite dish there. But it was chewy and bland. The calamari were clearly frozen. Nobody at my table liked it.
--judias verdes rebozadas: stringy and inedible. How the hell do you screw up green beans?
--paella de mariscos: horrible. Oily and with the same, disgusting calamari as mentioned above. My girlfriend and I looked, and could not find a single strand of saffron in the dish. 
--patatas bravas that were mediocre
--some chicken dish that was not memorable
--some mushroom dish that was dialed-in

Sorry, but I just can't give a damn about this place anymore. The best part was that they had some decent Galician white wines (including a good Albarino). I was excited about the Godello, but they were out of it....at 8 pm on a Friday. Whatever.

The service was ok, but that really doesn't matter when the food is so bad. They actually took a half-finished dish away from us when the paella arrived. We felt rushed. I get that this is the Mission and you want to turn over tables quickly, but don't take our food away. That just makes me growly.

Goodbye, Esperpento...never again! You make me sad with your "Spanish" food.
author: Brett L.

description:
Best tapas in SF!!!

The lobster tail paella is my favorite. The lobster meat is succulent and the other seafood in the dish blends so perfectly with the baked rice.

The service is amazing! The waitresses are gorgeous as well as attentive, and the owner Carlos is always at the door greeting and seating customers as they arrive! How many restaurants can you say that for? 

The sangria does its job and does it well. It'll get you hammered while tasting like fruity alcoholic heaven.

Carlos (AKA) Big Pappi Ortiz will give you the food and service you've been itching for, and if you're still itching after then you should probably see a physician.
author: ngozi g.

description:
I have never felt so discriminated in my life, and I understand why this place has such low ratings despite the fact that this place seems popular.

This is just such a sad story, but here was my experience between me, some dude who worked there (who might be the owner.. I was told he dresses unprofessional and looks around 30-40), and a random couple that walked in shortly after I was turned away by the employee.

Me:  Hi could I get a table for 1.
Employee: Just one?  Do you have a reservation?

Me: Yeah, just me.. Sorry, no reservation.. heh
Employee:  Oh.. hmm.. it's going to be a while.. 

Me: Okay. that is fine. I can wait.. (Thinking, hmm, I'm staying about a block away, and I could come back in a little bit)
Employee: Oh, actually... yeah..  We are full for the night.. and.. uh.. we are booked.

Me: Looking at a few empty tables, I said.. ok.. really?
Employee: Yeah. It's busy.. we are totally booked for the night.

I looked around the restaurant in confusion, because something didn't feel right... I felt like he was discriminating against me because I was alone, and he was thinking he could make more money if he were to sit more people at a single table, but I ruled that out, because I saw other people who had a table for one.

(a couple walks in within 5-10 seconds)

Couple: Hi, table for 2?
Employee: Oh.. do you have a reservation?

Couple: No
Employee: well it's going to be a while, maybe 45 minutes.. is that okay?

Couple: that's fine
Employee: okay, well let me get your name and number (he then took their name and number)

So the couple asked me how long my wait was, and I told them.. "well he refused to sit me".. they looked surprised, and said.. "hey! maybe we should eat together -- table for 3! :D". I totally wanted to, because I was so excited to try this place, but they looked like they were on a date-night thing, so as friendly and awesome as they seemed, I decided to just eat somewhere else, in fear that.. they might serve all of us some tainted food.

Then, right after _that_ couple walked in.. another party came in.. i think for a party of 3.. and the dude got THEIR number and information and told them it would be about 45 minutes!!

I then asked the employee:  So, are you still booked?  Because you just told that couple it would be 45 minutes.
Employee: Yeah, we're booked, we have another restaurant on 6 blocks from here.. i can give you their card... 

Me:  No. No thanks.. I think I'll just find somewhere else to eat.

So unhappy, and quite honestly, just disappointed that I had to encounter someone like that while on my vacation.  I've eaten everywhere from side-walk-street food to exclusive fine dining locations.. and I don't think I've ever felt this disrespected.
author: John W.

description: Had dinner here with two friends last night, the food was mediocre and the service was awful. One friend ordered her own meal while the other friend and I decided to share four tapas. Two came out right away, then...nothing. I flagged down our waiter-literally had to flag him down, no one had been back to check on us to see if we wanted more sangria or anything-he said they were on the way. The table next to us had been sat, ordered and received their meal during this time. We waited awhile longer, ate some bread, drank our sangria and finally asked for the check. The real surprise was that no one seemed to care that we never got half our meal! Thankfully there are better options for dining in the neighborhood.
author: Hannah S.

description: I have been to many tapas places in SF. In comparison to the rest, this was just ok. I came here for my friend's birthday. The first thing I noticed when I went into the restaurant is that it was hot and all the tables were close together. It felt like a melting pot in the restaurant. The food was pretty good. We had the lobster paella, mushrooms, garlic shrimp, and quail. We also got a few pitchers of sangria. The lobster paella was my favorite dish of the night! It was amazing. The other dishes were ok. What added to the mediocrity of the restaurant was the service. The waiters never seemed to attend to our requests. We probably asked for water like 5 times before we got it. And it didn't help that it was really warm in the restaurant. It might have been because we were seated upstairs, and waiters did not come around as much. Overall, the experience was just ok.
author: Rebecca D.

description: This place is the best place in the City for paella that I've been to, but I still think that it falls a bit short.  That being said, it can be pretty fun to go to with a big group and order a bunch of different paellas to sample.  Just make sure you are not in a hurry, because it takes a while to cook (not their fault, that's just how paella is).
author: Scott E.

description: Food is decent. The appetizers are really good. The pallea was great the first time I went but this last time it wasn't very good. The wait is awful so do yourself a favor and make reservations. The sangria is amazing. The wait stuff isn't very friendly.
author: Shanna M.

description:
Garlic Mushrooms - Love! I typically don't care for mushrooms much but these were great.
Garlic Chicken - Tender flavorful chunks of chicken. A lot of bone and pretty greasy though.
Grilled Asparagus - I like mine to have more of a crunch but my partner liked how they were cooked
Grilled Jumbo Shrimp - Nothing special, just 4 big grilled shrimp.
Steamed Mussels - Couldn't really taste the vinaigrette because the mussels were pretty fishy. Undercooked and sandy. Ick.

Paella Special with Lobster, Clams and Calamari - Pretty good but not the best I've had. Lobster was perfectly cooked but the calamari could have been cooked a little less.

Chocolate Mousse - Light and very rich. Loved it!
Flan - Very light and delicate; perfect after stuffing ourselves silly.

Friendly service, but it was hard to understand them at times. I'd definitely come back but I'll skip the mussels and grilled shrimp next time.
author: Kim V.

description:
(See pics)

I love tapas, especially if you want to sample out a lot of food and not get overloaded. Eggplants, grilled shrimps and potato cakes were all so good!

The paellas properly sealed at the top to keep them all moist. I did not know they can be this tasty. We had the seafood (lots of it!) and another one which I can't remember and both were very delicious.

Sangria, on the other hand, was so so.

And all these are very decently priced, probably because it is in the Mission, and with a touch of Valencia style -- colourful, cute and warm ambiance.
author: T L.

description:
Such a cute restaurant! The only clock in Esperpento tells the time in Spain. The tables are kinda close to each other in the middle area, but everyone's nice there so it's okay. Plus you get to peek at what yummies other people are eating.

You must try their paella! It's a really big wok and they bring it out straight from the stove top. It's nicely flavored, crispy on the outside and super moist on the inside. It'll serve 4-5 people perfectly.

Their sangria is also really nice. Sweet and fruity, and you can't taste the tartness of red wine!

Get some tapas dishes to share! Everything is delicious and reasonably priced. This place is amazing.
author: Erica L.

description: Essential! Whenever I can provide friends and family with a San Francisco trip, this stop is a must. I have found myself wanting to make the trip from the South Bay just so was can have their wonderful tapas, excellent sangria and tasty paella! Check it out.
author: Michael C.

description:
Disclaimer - I visited this amazing place while on business last week.  I am reviewing dishes based off of memory.

Setting: My coworkers and I met up with a mutual friend in San Francisco for dinner.  We had already had 3 IPAs prior to meeting up so any where would've been fine.  As luck would have it the decided restaurant was effing amazing!

General Thoughts: Slight higher than average price wise but WELL WORTH IT.

Detail Thoughts: 4 of had a reservation for 8:30 PM PST.  We arrived and were almost promptly seated (slightly delayed due to high demand on a Wednesday evening).  Upon sitting we ordered a few tapas to hold us over along with a bottle of Cava and I also ordered a side brew...Estrella Damm and yes it was necessary!  As far as the tapas were concerned we ordered some churizos, abondigas, shrimp and a few others that I can not remember (apologies).  In any case they were all AMAZING.  My wife and recently went to Barcelona and as such I am a bit of an expert here.  The abondigas generally my favorite tapas were fantastic.  The churizos which I rarely order might be my new favorite, well at least at Esperpento!  In any case as the night progressed so did our buzz.  What a great night so far.  To cap off the night we ordered a bottle of sangria and a huge bowl of seafood paella.  The sangria was a bit too sweet for me so I won't comment much there but it did the job.  It kept me occupied for the required 45 minutes before the paella arrived.  Boy did it arrive in style.  I'm talking a HUGE pan roughly a foot and a half in diameter which lots of fresh seafood on top.  From the clams, to the shrimp, to the scallops this thing was a marvel and guess what it was DELICIOUS TOO!  All in all, I highly recommend this place.  My friends and I had a great evening filled with good drink, great conversation and UH-MAZING food.

Final Thoughts: This will be a staple visit every subsequent time I go to SF.
author: Vinay K.

description: Excellent food, and great service. The sangria was tasty, strong, and reasonably priced. The padrón peppers were perfect, and the blood sausage reminded me of my family's Christmas recipe.
author: N V.

description: I love this place. I'm not a native to SF but my girlfriend was born & raised and this place is a must every time I come & visit. The food is delicious. The sangria is some of the best I've had. The decor is lovely and if you're fortunate, the Mariachis will come and perform for you. And the food choices are very authentic.
author: Jacinda S.

description:
The sangria here is dangerous.  Its *that* good.  You have been warned.

The food is great!  We got seafood paella, rabbit, chicken, clams, artichokes, and all sorts of other tapas.  Everything was delicious and I don't have a single complaint.  God, that sangria was good...

The bill came out to about $20/person and we (about 8 of us) all had a really big meal!  Its great for groups and people who like trying a little bit of everything.
author: richard d.

description:
Been here a couple times and this is a great solid happy hour spot. The Sangria is delicious! Just remember if you are pouring, that all the fruit will pour out so it looks like the first cup gets all the fruit! My friend used a knife to prevent all the fruit from pouring out and we distributed the fruit accordingly! :) 

This place is packed on the weekends. Even at 9 or 10 pm there is a a line out the door waiting to get in. Get here early or make a reservation in advance!

Be aware that its crowded here and loud as you can hear everyone's conversations and also sometimes they let street performers inside to do their thang and allow them to go around asking for tips. 

On two occasions, there as has been a man who sang opera -_-

On to the food! 
It's spanish tapas = sharing plates. The sharing plates are tiny but really if you have a big group and have pitchers of sangria, tapas are the best way to go. 

Tapas
Grilled artichokes - AMAZing! these are delish! A lil salty but great flavor
calamari - mmmmMMM yeah itts good and not too rubbery
patatas bravas - get the spicy ones as they have more flavor. These are delish potatoes with a great aioli dipping sauce
croquette - also a solid tapa

Entree
I shared a lobster paella with a friend of mine and it was delicious. It reminded me of a risotto meets fried rice kind of texture but was full or seafood flavor. I think there were like 4 lobsters tails too which were cooked beautifully!

Great place to catch up or celebrate good times over sangria and great food in the Mission. I'll be going here soon :)
author: Christine W.

description:
I have never liked sangria. I don't really like crowded restaurants. Small tables make me feel cramped. 

Esperpento has changed my opinions about all of these things. We drank a pitcher of sangria...delicious! We sat at a teeny table in the middle of a hundred voices. It felt lively and romantic! Total transformation! All of the items we enjoyed were absolutely amazing. The flavors of each piece were very bold. The calamari was my favorite, sauteed and served beautifully. The patatas bravas were spicy and delivious. The clams were juicy and the whole night was perfect.

I smile just thinking about it...pure bliss :)
author: Emily H.

description:
Absolute favorite Spanish tapas location in the city. I highly recommend the grilled artichokes. Sangria is a must, as is their Paella.

This is the sister restaurant as Picaro's on 16th and I switch between the two depending on how I'm feeling.
author: Johanna W.

description: Live the gambas and the fish clam stew!   The lobster paella is good but I think zarzuela is better
author: Gino C.

description:
Not the best tapas restaurant in the city but it's pretty damn good. 

The service was great and most importantly, they kept the sangria flowing. Good place to bring a large group. Had a blast on my birthday.
author: Alicia V.

description:
My family is from Spain and finding Spanish restaurants that actually serve Spanish cuisine is hard to find. This restaurant is amazing!!!!

It is very easy to find and there is a parking garage across the street with plenty of parking and good prices so that's a plus for San Francisco. 

The restaurant is dark and romantic with Spanish decor adorning the walls. The staff is very friendly and attentive. There was alot of other diners in the restaurant with us but the staff always made sure we had what we needed. 

Now for the food, it was nothing short of amazing. Just like my grandma used to make. I felt like I was in Spain not SF. We ordered the croquetas de pollo, potatas bravas, calamari, and the Paella De Mariscos. It was great. I had the flan for dessert. Not only is the food great so are the prices. You can feel free to order as much as you want without burning a hole in your pocket. The paella, which was the most expensive thing, was $26.00 for two people but it was big. My husband and I couldn't finish it so we had a great lunch the next day. 

If you are looking for great food, great service, and ambiance this is a great place to try. This place is great for a large group or a romantic date. It is great to get away and have something different. I will be back.
author: Sarah M.

description: I was really excited for this place but the most horrible service I have ever had living in sf for 7 years. We arrived at 8.30 and chose to sit outside even though it was cold to get seated faster. The waiter didn't arrive for 40 minutes . Then we ordered everything at the same Tim ( two dishes croquet  sand pallea) and it didn't come out till 10.20!!!!!!! We asked them 5 x and still the same amount of time. That was around 2 hours waiting for food - wow. No comps or even a sorry once after reminding them 5x to bring the food.
author: Nicole W.

description:
One of the best tapas place I have ever been to! 

We arrived on time for our 8:00 reservations but of course our table was not ready. The place was packed (Saturday night) and we waited outside for about thirty minutes. It was a nice warmish night and i had great company so really did not mind. 

The tables were a bit too close together and every time the couple sitting behind me shared a kiss or a hug I felt like i was part of it. and It was weird to say the least. After a couple of glasses of Sangria we all found it pretty hysterical though. 

OK here I go: 
- Sangria: not the best I've had. When it comes to Sangria I will stick to Dali (Boston). The sangria at Esperpento was not cold enough to my liking and did not have fruits - at least not the pitchers we got. 

We went there with another couple so I got to sample a few treats: 

- Patatas Bravas: these were addictive. WOW the couple we went here with recommended we tried them and they did not disappoint! one of my favorite plates there. 

- Another favorite was the Grilled Trout. The seasoning was amazing and the fish was cooked to perfection. 

- Next I tried a combination plate which included Beef Cutlet Milanesa 
with a side of rice and salad. This was also exquisite. 

Having been to multiple tapas places in the Boston area, I was really impressed with Esperpento. The food tasted amazing, and the prices extremely reasonable. I definitively want to go back!
author: Melina C.

description:
Another awesome find credited to V. 

Morcilla, rabbit stew, sangria,patatas bravas and many more. All tapas are properly portioned and delicious. Sometimes gets pretty crowded and there's a wait, also the acoustics make it hard for you to hear someone who's not sitting right next to you.

http://www.esperpentorestaurant.com/?q=node/7
author: Oleg H.

description:
My friend booked a reservation for 20 people at 8:30pm on a Saturday Night. Once we got there, they said 15 minutes. 8:45pm came and they said another 15 minutes. We were finally seated upstairs at 9pm. Pretty much had the whole upstairs to ourselves. The décor and feel was nice. However, it was HOT and HUMID...felt like we were eating in South America..
My friend did all the ordering. I have no idea what I ate but it was good. The prices were fair. They charged us a $1 cake fee/per person (we brought our own plates and forks)...and they didn't serve us the cake!
author: Christopher L.

description: Great food, sangria and service. First time I ate here I had maybe six plates and they were all fantastic. The next day I went back and had six completely different plates and they too were fantastic. A frequent haunt. I sometime stop by just for a Spanish tortilla pending what time I fall out of bed.
author: Jasper W.

description:
Esperpento is one of the best tapas restaurants I have been to. 

I hosted my wife's birthday party dinner there and they were able to keep us well fed and flowing with Sangria until we screamed, "no mas!" We had a total of seven adults and two little ones and they were very accommodating with the kids and special menu requirements. 

Perfect place for a small to mid-sized group. Money was not an issue that night and the food drinks came out without a hitch. Damage... $370 with tip which comes out to roughly $53/person for lobster paella, all you can drink sangria and enough tapas plates to cover the tables. Money well spent. 

Our server Kim was one of the best around. No wait for a party of 8 with reservations with 48 hours notice.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Apparently I'm late to the party. Why have I never been to Esperpento? 

The menu is overwhelming, as I typically find w/ tapas restaurants. And, tapas doesn't really lend itself to a party of 20 in the "private" room (that honestly should only be seating 10).  

With all that said, I will happily eat over and over and over again:

Patatas Bravas - spicy potatoes
Alcachofas a la plancha - sliced artichokes grilled with garlic & parsley
Gambas Al Ajillo - garlic shrimp
Tortilla De Patata - potato and onion omelet
Seafood Paella

In all honesty, though, I don't think I'm cut out for tapas. The food is yummy...but the plates are just too dang small for my big appetite!
author: Susan L.

description:
I REALLY enjoyed the Lobster/Seafood Paella dish here.  

The Adobo Pollo was pretty good (exotic spicy chicken) and it actually was not spicy at all for me.

The sangria here is much better than Cha Cha Cha's.  There were definitely more dishes on the menu at this place to choose from so I didn't feel so limited.

This place is a little small but it wasn't so bad.  

They also let a Latino guy come in from the streets during dinner time and sing some Spanish songs with his guitar and then he goes around the tables putting a gift bag in your face at the end.  I was thrown off by that a little bit because we didn't realize he was asking for a tip and not handing us something from his goodies bag or something.  

So...just a heads up, have some cash to tip the guy so you don't look like an ass...? 

A bit of an awkward moment.
author: Wendy T.

description: Really well portioned and not too costly yet not a steal!  The food is good enough to fill one up sans the feeling of feeling "Stuff"
author: R C.

description:
My wife says it was the most wonderful Mother's Day lunch she's ever had, so I thank Yelp and "Check Please, Bay Area.".  It was one of the rare times we dropped off the kids at her parents' SF house to share a simple lunch for two.  So I recalled my wife's raised eyebrows while watching Esperpento featured on the above mentioned TV show.

The fact that Valencia Street was closed to vehicular traffic and paved the way for street musicians seemed to set the scene for a perfect seating of tapas and paella.  Yes, order your paella early because the prep and cook time understandably takes 30 minutes, but to us it was worth it.

So we ordered the same tapas we've ordered in Marbella, Madrid, and SF restaurants for years:  a carafe of sangria, white anchovy in garlic and olive oil, roasted artichokes, calamari, and enough bread to sop up all the tasty sauces or olive oil.  This time we we added Esperpento's well known spicy potatoes (patatas bravas).  The spice was mild to medium but has a slow warming effect causing the eventual napkin-to-brow maneuver.  Everything else was well presented, served in timely waves, and certainly brought us back to another time and Spanish or Algarve Region place.  I'm certain the third glass of Sangria helped, too.

We were so full after we polished off our tapas plates that we politely asked our table service team (primo service btw) to package our "turist" mixed chicken and seafood paella to take home.  So we missed out on the owner's paella pan presentation, as we witnessed at other tables, but were not disappointed when we got home.  The 10x14x5 inch foil tin was still piping hot when we got to our kids and their grandparents.  So as you can imagine, we had a quick second-wind lunch, and the kids and my in-laws were well fed!

I should mention that the lady with the castanets was a charming touch in setting the atmosphere, so I'm glad I had a few bucks in my pocket.

No complaints from a very happy mom and her loving husband!
author: Rudy P.

description: The service and food is always great. I always come for the paella and sangria. The table in the front is the best! Will be back
author: Bunny B.

description:
Second time coming here.
Always busy, either make reservations and wait about 10 minutes. Or don't bother wait because it'll take at least 40 minutes.

Love the selection of Tapas here, Real Spain food, it was a group of 8 people with about 8 different little foods to try out.
Patatas bravas
Chorizos
Calamari
little meat balls with sauce (good to dip with bread... yum!)
Sangria
and Best at last.... PAELLA!

This place is good for friends to mingle and party. No good for dates since it's a small place and loud.

Service is Descent since it's only 3-4 people working and can't have more than that otherwise it'll be too crowded.
author: Helena H.

description:
Love all the seafood tapas.  My favorite is the fried mussels.  Yummm!  The calamari needs to be eaten right away or it'll turn chewy and incredibly inedible anymore though.  Shrimp/prawn Paellas--say no more!  We always end up sopping our table bread in all the sauces in the different tapas. :)

Waiters are always polite.  Can be crowded at times, but it's a fun atmosphere to have a yummy meal.
author: Kay T.

description:
There is no shortage of spanish tapas in San Francisco.  However, Esperpento sets itself apart because their tapas is pretty darn good and the prices are below average by far.

The restaurant is tucked into a small storefront on 22nd street just a couple blocks up from Mission Street.  They've packed a bunch of tables into the cozy, authentic space, but even so, you might have to wait for a bit on a weekend night before getting a table.  Calling ahead is definitely recommended.

The tapas menu is BIG compared to some of the other tapas places in the city.  There's ton's of choice.   Everything we ordered was really good:  I'd highly recommend the Patatas Bravas (can't ever go wrong), the vegetable paella, and the fried calamari.  Also, the grilled artichokes were very tasty and very original too.  I'd never had artichokes in this form and I was pleased.

The real kicker was that our group of 5 was in and out of the place with a bill well under $100 total, this after 5 or 6 tapas dishes and a couple pitchers of sangria.  That in itself is commendable, because it is not easy to do that at some of the other tapas places in this city.
author: Tim N.

description:
This is one of my favourite restaurants in San Francisco, very simple place with wonderful and friendly service. 

The menu is pretty much all you could wish from Spanish cuisine, excellent dishes, great portions and most importantly very well priced. 

The sangria is a must!

The only reason why I'm not giving them a 5 star review, is due to the occasional intrusion of street performers from the mission, they break the charm of the place and it's not very cool...

Other than that Esperpento has really won my heart. 

y Ole!

-FIN
author: Javier B.

description:
We were greeted by a very friendly host.  He was probably the best part of the night, IMO.  After the anxiety and irritation from the noise and the loud singer started to subside, and the food started coming out, I was pleasantly surprised by the simple, yet delicious grilled asparagus and spicy potatoes dishes.  So my hopes were high for the lobster paella.  Too high?  I don't know, I think I was tricked by Danny L.  When it came out, it looked good.  The portion size was large. I was excited because I hadn't had paella since the paella lady left Oakland.  But the rice was soggy, and you couldn't taste the elements of seafood that was in there.  In fact, you couldn't taste much at all.  The the little garlic shrimp dish came out.  Hmm...garlic taste?  Where?  

Once the host passed us off to the servers, I was even more disappointed as I started intently at my empty glass of water.  The highlight of the night was the cool host and when the singer (who did have a good voice) stopped and I was able to hear myself think again.  Otherwise, sorry, I probably won't venture out to the City for this place again.
author: Kim L.

description:
This place is crazy delicious.  Tapas can get really repetitious for a vegetarian some times (more potatoes!?) but here the menu is extensive and the food is sooo good.  A white bean salad, green beans drenched in garlic and fried on a grill, of course the patatas bravas are to die for.  Mr Mo loves the garlic shrimp, like he goes insane for them and talks about them in his sleep....  It's also pretty cheap, tapas for $4-5 like it SHOULD be!  Too many places in SF charge $10-12 for a tiny plate of food.  Total bullshit.  This place is cheap and tasty and I get regular cravings for it.    Last time I was there I had a party of four and the total bill was $100 + tip!  And were were stuffed!!  The sangria is also totally awesome.

I'm only docking a star because it's an absolute zoo in there.  Tables crammed next to tables, your chair getting bumped, drunk people shouting, singers coming in off the street performing over you...  That can be fun on a weekend night, with a group of friends, but definitely not a place for a quiet, romantic meal.  You'll be yelling at your dinner companion.  Just as an FYI.
author: Monica R.

description:
Just went here to celebrate a friend's birthday and the food definitely held up to the previous reviews!  

We weren't up for yelling at each other over the table so we opted for an early dinner at 5:30pm.  The bonus for us was that parking was way easier to get and the paella that usually takes 40 min, was ready in 20min because they weren't too busy.  

Everything except for the croquettes were awesome.
Spicy potatoes, fried calamari, pork kabobs, garlic mushrooms, cheese - yum.  The highlight was the paella (meat and seafood) which was creamy, perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked.  

The price for 3 gals was around $60 - lots of leftovers.  
We will definitely be back!
author: Kim K.

description:
This place charges an automatic 22% gratuity to your bill, yet does not explain that for parties of 6 or more, including infants and kids.
They then get upset when you ask any questions regarding the amount. 
when emailing the OWNER, about the tip and what is the normal tip charged for parties of 6 or more he responded with:
"curiousity killed the cat."  
Yes no joke. That was the owners response, i did say in my email i was curious.
So there is my most professional asnwer. thinking now, this place is  front for something else. Illegal perhaps? Money laundrying?
I will be contacting Check please, BBB, SF weekly and the like to post HIS email on their websites.
Hey, btw, I want my freaking 22% tip back, the service sucked as did the food. No flavor, no taste.
Shrimp is disgusting at best. 

Curious? What business owner responds to a legitimate email with 
Curiousity killed the cat? maybe that was a threat from the mob boss himself?

Hmmm, im beginning to think i need to call authorities and report this threat...

odd, very odd. Did this owner just threaten me in some out of the way way? yeah think so.........dialing police now

correction; 24%
author: Mel S.

description:
Besties and I wanted to try something new. Made reservations at 730p for a Friday night for a party of 3. Place was packed - as expected. Our table was located right at the door. Luckily it wasn't windy! We ordered:

Patatas Bravas (spicy potatoes) - Thanks for the suggestion Heidi L.!

Calamari - OK

Lobster Paella - they have a $28 for two people special, but we opted for the $50 for 4 :) we was hungry.  This dish was deeeelish! Had about 4 lobster tails in the entire dish. I wish there was more of the
crunchy rice on the bottom but the lobsters more than made up for it.

The sangria here was sooooo gooood. We ordered two carafes, it was that yummy! As others have mentioned, there are people that come in to perform and ask for tips. They weren't aggressive this night (thank god). Don't expect to come here for a quiet evening or plan on taking a date here. It's LOUD. I was practically yelling at my BFFs just to have a conversation! That plus the music...you can imagine! Next time i'll try and ask to be seated not so close to the door. Having waiting patrons gawk at you to finish up was the only irk I had. Also, parking can be a problem around the area.

They are open for lunch, so may have to try that one day. I'm sure it's
much quieter :)

EDIT: We're going for my BFF's birthday dinner on a Monday. Will see how the crowd is then, too.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
After going into Ti Couz & discovering that they are not open for lunch on Thursday (a very abbreviated menu doesn't count as "open for lunch") we strolled down to Esperpento for tapas. 

It was not crowded, and we got a nice window table. Service is slow. Don't go to lunch here if you are in a hurry. Good luck if you run out of water, because getting a refill takes a long time. 

The food for the most part did not disappoint. We had several dishes, and most of them were good. The eggplant especially stands out in my mind, and the mussels. The garlic shrimp was good and the spicy potatoes. I thought the calamari was undercooked and under seasoned, and a bit rubbery. 

The prices are cheap and three of us ate plenty of food for not a lot of cash. I would probably try this place again, just not when I am in a hurry to eat.  Oh, by the way, don't try to pay with American Express, they won't take your AMEX card.
author: Rocky F.

description: Esperpento is indeed my favorite Spanish restaurant in the Bay Area. Their tapas are delicious, flavorful and authentic. Bacalao Croquetas and Fried Artichokes are some of my picks. Paella, just the way I cook it, moist and filled with goodies ! I could eat here everyday !
author: Eddie I.

description: The food is decent, but the mariachi dude(s) who always comes in with a detuned guitar and off pitch voice singing literally 8" from my ear makes me never want to come back.  Happens every time I go too.  Skip.
author: David S.

description: Enjoyed the sangria and the carne Asada with a side of sautéed mushrooms! Absolutely delicious! Did I mention the delicious sangria??? Yum!
author: Adi A.

description: I came here for the first time about a month ago with a coworker. We were here for a going away. They ordered sangria and the veggie Paella and the mixed Paella. They were Delicious! I ended up taking the left overs home and had dinner the following night. I want to go back to try other items on their menu. It all looked really good.
author: Reyna V.

description:
Great tapas place. A little bit loud, but a fun atmosphere with good food and friendly service.

- Salt Cod Salad: refreshing, not enough cod, salad was good
- Rabbit Stew: heavy, lots of small bones so watch out, good tomato sauce
- Potato Egg pancake: okay very eggy/potatoey 
- Chorizo: skin a little too crispy, like little weiners, salty
- Oysters: not that fresh but cooked nicely with tons of grilled onions, yum!

Sangria was not as good as last time. Seemed like it need to be soaked a little longer, but still better than some I've had.
author: Linda C.

description:
Been going to this place forever and never needed to write a yelp...until now. 

My wife surprised me at this great establishment for my 30th birthday with a party of 30 of my most beloved family and friends. The food came out a few minutes after we were sat, and it was paced very nicely. Plates were never crowded, the sangria pitchers and water was always refilled. Most impressively though was that the food had the same crazy-to-the-bone chomping, plate licking after it's all gone taste. 

And that my friends deserves my patronage for a long time! Usually food and service take a dive with a big party like that in a busy restaurant, but I'm happy to say that the great owners, servers, cooks, bussers, etc. of Esperpento executed perfectly. All was happy, and great times were had. 

Now most of us haven't had the luxury of having paella with the Mediterranean sea shining brightly through our YSL sunglasses at a table in Spain, but a place like this in the Mission that's close to home will always have a place in my heart.
author: Jon F.

description: While visiting this spectacular city of San Francisco I thought for the last night in town to go eat spanish food. One of my friends recommended Esperpento, after checking a few reviews on this site I decided to go eat paella and tapas on my last saturday night here. We ordered Paella as we sat down since it takes about fifty minutes to cook and while waiting we ordered Papas Bravas, Chorizo and Camarones al Ajillo, they were all yummy, we also had an very good house red wine and bread. The ambiance was lively, the service was very good and we had Mariachis singing in the background for a while. Oh yes and the the Paella was delicious!
author: Lilian Y.

description:
Sangria, I need cha-you're so good, sweet, yet tangy, you roll off my tonge and into my belly. Oh sangria, how I love thee. 

Also inexpensive tapas in a friendly, rowdy environment. Mariachi--what?! This is Espana, not Mexico? But when you're having a good time, who really cares where the music's cultural orientations are from.
author: Shira O.

description:
The cold gazpacho soup was pretty good. Made of tomato, vinegar, garlic, lemon 

The staff was really nice and responsive. They said it would take 20-30 min but it was much faster
author: John S.

description:
The Caveman and I have eaten here half a dozen times; Sunday being the most recent occasion, as we were taking The Niece around town.  We found ourselves in The Mission and hungry... at kind of an odd/late-ish lunch hour, this is where we ended up.

I always try to drink the young Spanish vino here because it seems like the right place to ingest alcohol.  And then I remember that I'm (a) an Asian chick who (b) cannot metabolize alcohol and (c) weighs a buck and change - far too late and my cheeks are flushed, my head is spinning and I'm always on the cusp of doing something regrettable that might return, captured on film to haunt me.  So, this is the closest I ever feel to living my life as Darin I. for a few hours.  

Forgive the brusque run down; the menu is rather large and we've sampled a fair number of their staples.  Anyhoo:

The patatas alioli - wish they were crispier and the garlicky mayo served on the side... but that doesn't stop me from shoveling them into my mouth.  But it's definitely a brush-and-floss as soon as you can situation; best to pack some breath mints.

Manchego - served COLD in a drizzle of olive oil with a resigned marinated pepper in the middle.  Disappointing, because this cheese really is delicious - I prefer to eat it with membrillo, which they do not offer, which is a pity.

Albondigas - we like to scoop the saffron-jacked sauce up with pieces of bread; the meatballs themselves, not so much.  I think they are heavy and dense for my taste.

Alcochofas (artichokes) a la plancha:  these are actually special; thin sliced baby artichokes with garlic and olive oil... we order these every time; they're lovely.

Calamares fritos: this dish is delicately battered and served with a big side of alioli.  The Caveman never regrets putting tentacles in his mouth when this plate arrives at the table.  (I said tentacles, not testicles, Darin!)

Chorizo Salteado "Cantimpalitos" - ordered it once and hardly touched it; refer to my pic - they looked like smoky links and tasted very much like something my WASPy Mother would try to pass off as an actual appetizer after zapping a package in the microwave.  Icky.  

Gambas al Ajillo:  The shrimp was frozen and/or waaaaay overcooked, drowned in garlic and olive oil.  This is a very simple dish that can be such an epiphany with fresh ingredients; a real disappointment.  

Ropa Vieja... the ingredients in this stew were overcooked and their flavors muddled; the beef component was tough and made it difficult to enjoy the dish.  Ditto for the adobo stew we had a few visits back.

Quail a la plancha - I was really looking forward to this tapa, but the quail was so small and... not plump; I had a difficult time attempting to cut any of the meat off the bird.  I felt almost defeated because I hardly got a taste of the actual dish; it was kind of an exercise in futility.  

The portions are generous and it's best to go with a group so that you can share.  It's emotionally difficult for me to concede that the food is pretty middle of the road because they don't feature seasonal specialties, which is what I'd rather have them do.  Smaller menu, with in-season highlights, instead of a vast selection that depends upon frozen and otherwise stabilized ingredients.  

I'm skewing high in my rating of this place; I'm a bit sentimental about it.  This was the first restaurant that the Caveman and I ate up here together, before we signed the papers for our loft (and just a few weeks before we got hitched)... So... there you go.  I have exposed my soft, sentimental, [full] underbelly.  Don't hate me; I'm feeling vulnerable today.  Seriously.

*big sigh*
author: Kim D.

description:
Came here on a Friday night with a group of four around 7:30pm and was worried that the place was surprisingly empty. We got a nice seat next to the window and proceeded with an pitcher of Sangria.

Girls: "I like this Sangria, it's nice and sweet"
Guys: "I'm not sure there's enough booze, but it's still pretty good"

8:00pm rolls around and suddenly the place is packed. So much so that they are taking tables to a small place two doors down, like someone's apartment or something, and people are eating there. As our food is coming in waves,  we start eating and it's so crowded that some chicks ass is practically in my face cause I'm sitting next to the door. The place is insane now however the bulk of the food is here and I concentrate on that.

The memorables:

Tortilla Espanola - best I've had yet of the number of times I've had this
Oxtail Stew
Rabbit Stew
Grilled Artichokes
Albondigas

The decents:

Paellas Mariscos
Eggplant
Grilled Asparagus
Spinach bechamel 

So overall the veggie dishes weren't as good as the others. The old guy who was our waiter seemed a bit aloof too but the other staff were pretty friendly. The place is definitely cheaper than most places I've been so it's a good value. With the dearth of Tapas places in the Mission, Esperpento makes for another choice in the quiver. Just get there early!
author: Kim N.

description:
Some coworkers and I were in the mood for Taco Tuesday, but it was later in the evening, so we knew the tables at every type of place would be crowded, so we headed to 22nd and Valencia with the intention of margaritas at Latin American Club, yet remembering that we were still hungry for some food. Voila we ended up at Esperento.

- Patatas Aioli
potatoes were nicely cooked, bite sized, aioli sauce was yummy

- Tortilla de Patata
potato and omelet delicious combo with more aioli-like sauce on top, tasty

- Champinones al Ajillo
mushrooms were perfectly cooked in garlic for eating on their own or combining with other tapas, oh so tasty

- Ensalada Judias Blanca
nicely seasoned white bean salad, quite tasty

- Alcachofas a la plancha
WOW! This may be one of the best ways to eat artichokes, a bit crispy yet still soft, SO tasty!

- Almejas a la Marinera
Clams bathing in a lovely marinera sauce, which was also great for dipping bits of baguette in of course, very tasty!

- Sangria
Yummy, personally I would have liked larger bits of fruit, though very refresing!


Overall, everything was tasty, I will be returning for this reason.  I also enjoyed the mix and match plates that everyone got, I hate when things are too orderly with tapas.
author: Natalia M.

description: Great food and service! I'm usually not a big fan of sea food, but the sea food paellas was very flavorful! There were 8 of us and we could barely finish the serving for 6. The sangria was very good too! It wasn't watered down like most places. Looking forward to come back to this place!
author: Monica C.

description:
Ohhhh... me like.
Always so good, always so cheap, great location, great vibe, great sangria, great tapas! Always busy though... and they take forever... and having a reservation and showing up on time don't mean much there... but who cares!
author: Feliz L.

description:
We had high hopes for this place after seeing it reviewed on 'Check Please, Bay Area', but were pretty let down, almost from the moment we walked in. The decor seemed somewhat dull, dark and dated. The servers looked like they'd rather be elsewhere. The complimentary French bread was nothing fancy, although the Salsa Brava they served it with was good. The Jamon Serrano en Pan con Tomate was more like 'Sin Tomate'. It was a slice of prosciutto laid on top of the same dull French bread with a thin, flavorless olive oil spread, no tomatoes in sight and a red bell pepper on top. When I mentioned my confusion to the server at not seeing any tomatoes (and being surprised at the strong red pepper taste instead -of which I'm not a huge fan), she mentioned that they stopped serving the tomato part of the dish over a year ago. Then, she must've chatted with her fellow server about it, because he, too, came over to try to tell me the tomatoes were in the thin, flavorless olive oil spread. 

The Ropa Vieja was slightly better, but nothing to write home about. I ended up dipping all of my bread in its sauce, because I was pretty desperate for something with flavor at this point. The mushrooms were pretty good, but again, the presentation was nonexistent. Just mushrooms in a bowl. 

Lastly, we ordered the seafood paella, which we thought might make up for the mediocrity we'd experienced so far. We had to wait 30 minutes for it, so it must be good, right? Nope. It was completely flavorless. Sticky, saffron rice with a couple of peas and some seafood that all tasted as bland as the rice. 

The only good thing about our experience was that it didn't break the bank. For a tapas place, it was very reasonably priced. 

Our meal was topped off by us getting to watch our server drag on a cigarette on the sidewalk outside our window seat. Check Please, Bay Area let us down.
author: B F.

description:
Came here again for a party organized by Grace K.  It was a larger group but it was in the same upstairs area.  It has been about 15 months since I was in Spain, but for whatever reason the tapas really reminded me of that trip.  I wasn't having much of the paella, but I think it's because we were so stuffed.  Looking back at my old review, I think it was better this time.

Nevertheless, it was a fun time to see some friends, old and new.
author: Dave K.

description:
Amazing & Authentic Spanish Food.

We came here with a large group to celebrate my friend's birthday and had the BEST time. The ambiance was energetic, service was perfect, and most of the all the food was incredible. Here are my favorites:

- Paella: We tried the seafood and the meat paellas and both were incredible. The rice was crisp on the outside, perfect flavorings, and it was a huge portion!

- Artichokes: sliced super thin and grilled with garlic. So good!

- Mushrooms: amazing flavor. garlic! yum

We also had the garlic shrimp, calamari, and tons of the bread with the delicious red sauce. Everything was so good. I woke up the next day craving all the dishes we ate.
author: Janelle R.

description:
Ruined by excellent Ibiza paella.

Or maybe this one just wasn't very good. Crusted rice at the bottom, lack of flavor in the seafood and expensive. All together disappointing.

Better luck was had elsewhere, though my favorite dish, the sliced artichokes, probably had something to do with the amount of butter. Actually, that's not a good thing at all, more a disappointment.

Also disappointing was the zucchini, onions and tomatoes in a tomato sauce. Tomato oil sauce would have been more appropriate.

There were other dishes, nothing memorable enough to save Esperpento from two star territory.

Know if you go as a group you are in the side room away from the buzz and liveliness of the main seating area. That might have helped.

Or just take your group to Ibiza. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jason B.

description:
Me likey.  It's tough to find a good tapas place where they dont gouge you on prices.  I'd say every dish that we've gotten here was great, from vege options (like the grilled beans and potatoes), to the seafood.  The paella was really good too...I hate when a paella just sucks bad (like the paella place in Beldin Place in the city), but this one had me scraping the plate clean.  note: the paella here is hit or miss, lately mainly misses...i can't tell if its better on non busy nights.   The sangria is also one of the best I've had hands down.  The guy that works the front door is a nutjob and funny, and the staff is super nice and friendly.  

This place is a madhouse, I don't think there is an organizational chart for the tables, its loud as hell, and it feels like I'm in some alley in Spain...super crowded on weekends so be prepared to wait.  The only downside is the occasional street performer coming in...I just want to eat and talk to my friends, not have you sing above me and then ask me for money...it's already loud in there, and this leads to a screaming table convo.  But then again it adds to the crazy...hmmm now I don't know what to think.  Anyway, for a fun, cheap, and tasty place that screams SF Mission, this is a staple for our out of town guests.

Edit: I come here a lot, but the quality of the paella has been inconsistent...when it comes out overcooked, colorless, and bland (you can tell simply by looking at paella how it will taste), I get really sad because it's what I look forward to the most here.  4 stars unless the paella gets fixed!
author: A A.

description: I have been to Esperpento at least 20+ times and I always walk out happy. It's a very small, kinda loud at dinner, casual place with great inexpensive tapas.  I have tried many dishes  but I stick to my favs.  Sangria to start, garlic chicken,  prawns,  the must patatas bravas ( they sell the sauce to take home)  garlic mushrooms, and the amazing artichokes, they are slivered, grilled and taste divine!    I park on the convenient  lot  that you  can exit across the street. The entrance is one block down.
author: B C.

description:
4 stars for service, 3 stars for food. Everything that I ordered was warm but not hot as if it was sitting out for a while. The only thing that was hot was the paella which was really good and it was huge! (That's what she said!) 

The plus side is the atmosphere is really cool. Great place for a date especially if you don't want to wait too long like Cha Cha Cha. I still prefer Cha Cha Cha and Picaros over this place.
author: David W.

description:
this place surprised me of how good it was. had a 5:30pm reservations because we had to catch a show. This place was packed already. We had a table for party of 6 upstairs which is more quiet.

everything comes with lemon and it just makes it have that extra yummy taste

Gambas Al Ajillo garlic shrimp-so buttery....yummy


Almejas A La Plancha grilled clams with garlic. "guindilla" parsley and olive oil-just perfect

Calamares Fritos fried calamari-least favorite. not cripsy and so oily. pass on this


Jamon Serrano canapes of spanish cured ham on toasted french bread served with ripe tomatoes and olive oil-to die for. amazing


Patatas Aioli homemade garlic mayonnaise-just potatos with garlic maynnaise over..this one was alright..can skip


Champinones Al Ajillo mushrooms sauteed with garlic-2nd fave dish. best mushrooms ever

Alcachofas a la plancha thin sliced artichokes grilled with garlic & parsley-my fave from here. i can eat plates and plates of it

Ropa Viejo beef, chicken, and chorizo stew-way too oily for me, but if u dip it in bread it's so good

Rabo Toro, Ox-Tail Stew -not bad, but not the best...

the salted fried cod-way too mushy...

Paella De Mariscos Or Seafood with calamari, shrimp, clams and mussels-get it for 2 (even though we had 6 people) it is hugeeeeeeeeeee....the clams were so sandy, and a rice was a lil too brunt for me

Paella "Matanza" Or "De Carnes" chicken, pork ribs, chorizo, morcilla, outifarra-for 2 cuz it's huge and the meat had more flavor then the seafood. 

i would def come back here again and try other things
author: Karen H.

description: Food is ok. It does resemble the Spanish style but it is not quite as good as it is in Spain. Their prices are reasonable and it is still a good option to try something different. They need to improve their customer service, though. On a separate note I have to say that I didn't like the singers who were there Saturday night singing something wasn't Spanish music at all.
author: Nando G.

description:
I will start off by saying that this one star review was based on the service, not the food. the food may have merited a three star review if it weren't for the horrific service.

the food was descent, nothing to write home about but satisfying. the sangria was good, although when my friend ordered another they didn't bring it, so she order one again 10 minutes later, & they brought her another. however, we were charged for the sangria that came. when we mentioned the mistake, they fixed it no problem....

HERE WAS THE PROBLEM:

my friend and i decided to have them split bill down the middle between our cards. five minutes later the waiter returned with bill, holding up my card saying "this is broken". and there is was...my month-old new atm card broken in half. i asked what happened & he said "don't know...it's broken" (note: english was not his first language) to make myself clear i said "when i gave this to the girl who took the cards it was not broken, not even slightly." she just looked at me blankly, shrugged, and then again repeated "i don't know". while at this point i should have asked to speak to a manager, i was just too shocked, confused, and flustered to think straight. on top of all of this they automatically charged the entire bill on my friend's card without her consent. luckily she's a nice person (& i had cash) so she wasn't bothered by this. personally, i found it horrifying. 

again, i should have asked to speak to someone instead of just stumbling out of the restaurant bewildered. breaking a card in half is not any easy task & most certainly not something that can be done by mistake without noticing. 

if someone had just acknowledged and apologized for breaking my card i would have been pacified. the idea of spending the whole weekend without money (because i'm one of the few people left in the world without a credit card) would be slightly less irritating. 

i realize this is a very irregular situation and probably doesn't speak much of others experiences here...but the fact that the staff couldn't even apologize for something like that makes me angry. 

needless to say, i will never eat here again.
author: Jana G.

description: Finally a good Spanish tapas spot in SF! The grilled calamari was great and not too oily, the pimientos rojos were a little undercooked but still worth it, the grilled mushrooms had just the right amount of garlic and the albarino was lovely. My one complaint would be about the chicken adobo...does it always have to be with dark meat? C'mon... But all in all, a great place, good prices for what you get and I'll be back soon!
author: Erin W.

description: What a delightful and tasty lunch of such value I kept looking at the check to see if all was included.  Went for the Lunch combinations with my friend and we shared. Started with a delicious soup (that we weren't expecting). Kept trying to figure out the tastes and had to ask-carrot & zucchini with just the right amount of zing.  Delicious.  Chose the garlic chicken & the sautéed calamari with sides of salad, creamed spinach & rice.  Couldn't have been better.  Will go back and go back and go back soon. A great find.
author: Judy B.

description: Decent sauteed calamari tapas and sangre de toro.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I love Spanish tapas! 

Esperpento is the best place for Tapas in the Bay Area!!!

Their Sangrias are sweet and fruit flavorful, really good.
The food is to die for.

The Owner's I believe are from Spain and I think thats why, Esperpento stands out from other places as like Cha Cha Cha....
The atmosphere is colorful and load, which is great and fun.

Its a popular place, so i recommend to make a reservation or go early as 5:30pm or 6pm.

Go try this place.

I recommend Esperpento to you!
author: Anika P.

description: The food is excellent! Very authenticate from what I remember traveling to Spain. The aioli is so yummy and goes great on so many dishes. I never liked Paella until I ate here. Family style dining in a group is best! Order the Tortilla Espanol, Championes, and fried artichokes (to get the aioli!)
author: Nichole S.

description: I like this place...good croquetas, good jamon, good patatas bravas/aioli, good sangria...can be a bit hit or miss sometimes, but more often than not I leave very happy, and the price is reasonable (and I am from Spain, for what it's worth :-) It can get very loud, especially with the musicians - that can be annoying.
author: Ben R.

description:
MMMM! Esperpento has some of the best tapas I've had in the city thus far. AND also, the best sangria! 

Love their Gambas Al Ajillo garlic shrimp, spanish cured ham, Patatas Aioli homemade garlic mayonnaise and their seafood paella. 

Don't get greedy with their bread! Don't want to stuff yourself to the point you can't savor the many delicious tapas they have to offer.
author: Jenny K.

description:
The first time I went, it was a five stars. I went on a Friday for dinner got  great service, and the food was wonderful. Can't go wrong with any of the potato dishes, and the garlic shrimp was perfect. The chocolate mouse was a little grainy, but my dinner mate loved her flan and the sangria was refreshing, but that was the first visit and it all changed the second time.

I went on a Monday for lunch and got the worst waiter! He basically ignored my companion and me during our meal. We never got our water glasses replenished, even though he was guzzling away looking at us. I had to go to the counter to ask for napkins when he disappeared, and our small dirty plates piled up. By the time I got his attention, he still got our order wrong and only served one dessert, instead of the two we ordered. 

That was the service and now let's discuss food. My companion ordered the jumbo shrimp and had to devein them. She looked like she was at crawdad crawl with all the messy peeling and cutting and no napkins to wipe her hands with. They should not have been served like crawdads on the Bayou. I had the patas aioli and it was great, just like last time. The artichokes were tough and my jammio serrano did not come with olives, bread, or tomatoes, but some orange sauce, and their Spanish version of creme brulee was vanilla pudding with a hard burnt top. 

Overall, it's really hit or miss depending on luck.
author: Mark F.

description:
:-)

OMFG.. How could I forget about ESPERPENTO?!

3295 22nd st
San Francisco, CA 94110
(415) 282-8867

Located near the mission is one of THE BEST Tapas and SF Spanish restaurant (in my opinon.) Good food, reasonable prices and ambience (though it can get LOUD).... 

I spent many evenings here where I came to:  

PARTY

KARAMU

FIESTA

FOREVER... 

and yet I must have hit the sangria one too many times...  
WTF? How could I forget? (And this is why I don't drink anymore... 
this and the HÜSSY reputation.)

Hard to tell you all the good food points (there's so many) so you'll just have to GO TO! Seriously, check out Esperpento!

You'll have a deliciously good time.

4 Woofs... I AM DEFINITELY A FAN.
author: JöHnNy A.

description: I came here for the first time this week and I was impressed with the food and prices.  I wasn't sure how I would like it because I am allergic to gluten but they have several items on the menu that are okay for me.  I looked at the plates after dinner and tried to decide which of the 5 items I liked best but it was a toss up, a 5 way toss up.  I am coming back soon and I'm going to try new items to hopefully find more favorites.  "Favorites" by definition should be a small group right?  But I can't decide!  Great place.  Show up early so you don't wait too long for a table.
author: Eileen L.

description:
So the food is GREAT, I've been there for lunch and had their lunch combos (grilled snapper, albondigas, salmon, milanesa, etc) with choice of 2 sides, salad and soup. The sangria is pretty good, too. - not as good as Cha Cha Cha's, in my opinion. The Tapas are always good - the grilled artichoke, asparagus, the quail, the potatoes with garlic aioli - YUM.
BUT the service there is AWFUL!  I mean Really really bad - both when it's empty at lunch and even worse when it's packed at dinner time - if feel like "who do I have to kill to get a basket of bread", or my water, or to finally order my damn food! My friends and I sat there for a good 20 minutes (watching other people order and get their food) before someone even acknowledged that we may need water.
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
*"The Lobster/Seafood Paella "
This is the Dish that caught my eye and for $28 to feed a party of two, i really couldn't say no! Exactly what I expected, Not too much, but not too little on the flavor and Portion. 

*"the Garlic Shrimp"
Were Amazing! the shrimp were tender and plump, not Dry and rubbery. Definiately not too but Garlic, just enough to savour what the dish entailled. 

Overall, my experience was Great! Our waiter was on top of his game and definiately made sure we were informed and satisfied.
author: Brittany B.

description:
Must haves: garlic shrimp and patatas brava! and don't forget to dip the bread in the garlic shrimp oil - so good! And of course, the sangria is delicious. I've never had the paella, but it always looks good when I see it at other tables. 

One of my favorite restaurants in the city, and ranks above Cha Cha Cha in the Haight by far. A place you MUST eat at if you haven't yet.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This restaurant is really cute! I loved the decor, the people, the service, the ambiance.

Highlights of my meal: Sangria! It was delicious, even better than the Sangria I make at home. Tapas... they were all really good. We had various of their tapas and loved each one. 

What I didn't like: The Paella. The rice was a little bit hard and the flavor was just OK.

It's a good place to go for Tapas.
author: Patty G.

description:
I just came back from here not too long ago. Originally, we were going to go to some other place, but I'm glad we came here instead. By the time we arrived the place was packed and there were a few parties ahead of us. We probably had to wait at least 10 minutes, which we didn't mind at all. The manager and waiters were very friendly and our food arrived quickly. 

We ordered a pitcher of Sangria (sweet and refreshing), Grilled Mussels, Grilled Calamari (YUMMM), Grilled Artichokes (a little salty, but I enjoyed it), Potato & Onion Omelette (OMG YUMM), Ox Tail Stew, Grilled Salmon (i could've done without). For dessert we had the Creme Brulee and the Flan. I really enjoyed the creaminess of the flan and the fact that it wasn't overwhelming sweet. The burnt sugar on the creme brulee kind of ruined it for me. The total was around $62 for 3 people, which was okay for the amount of food we ordered.

Something about the guitar players (okay fine, they're musicians) playing music sort of bothered me. Honestly, I only heard half of what they played since the place was loud and  the most half of me conversating and listening to what my friends had to say. It made us feel uncomfortable that they walked around asking for money 'for their music,' which I wasn't even paying attention to at all.

I'm giving it 4 stars, maybe because I'm still a bit buzz after the 4 glasses of Sangria I had, but nonetheless I'm left feeling satisfied after some good eats! I'll definitely come back here and try some other dishes.....or maybe until I find a better tapa place.....*shhhh*
author: Serena W.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The tapas are delicious, the wait staff is jovial, the occasional mariachi bands are entertaining, and the price is right. You can leave the place full and drunk for $30.
author: Karl R.

description:
I guess I really never realized how inexpensive this place was until I went again last night for dinner with Cesar N. 

$56 for 1 bottle of wine, 5 small plates, and flan dessert. 

Amazing. And the food was deelish, as always!
author: Stacy S.

description:
