I see that people don't rate the service high; but this experience should be savored, slow service is not bad service; what's the rush - slow down and relax - it's virtually tropical in the mission...

If service and a more refined ambiance is your thing head over to Andalu...
author: Omer K.

description: Went here the day before Bay to Breakers (yup, bay to broken) and LOVED it. We got seated right outside of the entrance, which is ideal for people-watching and for enjoying the nice weather. The sangria got our weekend started on the best note you could ever want. We somehow ended up drinking 4 pitchers by the end of the night. YESSS! I thought the sangria is to die for... I recommend you try it. We ordered various tapas, of which I really liked the garlic shrimp, chorizo, and the "croquetas de pollo" (chicken croquettes?!). Our main plate was a huge paella with chicken, beef, ham and all sorts of seafood. It was VERY good and fed all seven (yes, siete (7)) of us, which is quite impressive. All in all, a lovely place that I can't wait to visit again when I'm in the Bay Area.
author: Cinthia S.

description:
My friend took me here and I'm glad he did. It's a very happening place and it was packed like a can of sardines and we had to wait 20 minutes, but I didn't mind at all. I ordered something exotic such as oxtails and grilled calamari and we had sangria (that was very tasty). Overall, I'd like to come here again. 

P.S- They have lovely decor. I wish I could take those plates they have on the wall home.
author: Corey C.

description:
I have been here many times and I have yet to review the place; mostly because I've taken a Yelp hiatus...a long one.  

I appreciate their extensive menu and their somewhat integrity in keeping Spanish tapas...well, Spanish.   My favorite dish here is the grilled veggies.  Large portion of nicely seasoned and what seems like a  perfectly grilled medley of healthiness.  A must to balance out other not so healthy options, such as the rabbit (tricked my bf into thinking it's chicken), fried potatoes/calamari, manchego cheese, etc.  Their paella was tasty too.  Is the place awesome? No.  But it's a great lunch and/or dinner spot to satisfy any Spanish tapas cravings.  Service is spotty for sure (sometimes attentive, other times not very attentive).
author: Adrian N.

description:
Maybe we should have gone here to get our tapas fix, post vacation, amid back-at-home malaise.

Delicious, and served by a straight-up Spanish/Madrid native. She pronounced it "San Fran-this-co" and everything. She also said (granted she works at this place and might be a bit biased) this was the best resto for Spanish tapas in town. Having tried a number of them, I might have to agree with her.

Tapas tends to roll a little overdone hereabouts. Ramblas doesn't exactly. Alegrias doesn't. Esperpento definitely does not, and the food is quite a bit better than all of those spots.

Albondigas (yes!), patatas bravas (yeah, baby), gambas al ajillo (butta, baby) and roasted green peppers (pimientos al padron) with a carafe of sangria fit the bill for a casual evening out. And at $50 total (tip included), it's also a hell of a steal for quality goods.

Repeat visits, for sure!
author: Tara R.

description:
Mixed review. I hope the next time I come back here I can raise the star rating, because this time the service more than failed to impress me. 

Sangria? Really fucking good.....I mean, screw Cha Cha Cha and their rendition, oh my God, can I have more until I am falling down drunk, good. This worked in their favor a bit, because had me and the lovely Kate K not had sangria to take the edge off we might have lunged at the servers for being so inattentive. 

I mean, nearly 20 minutes for someone to acknowledge us once we were pointed to a table from afar? This was only after my partner in crime GOT UP OUT OF HER SEAT and asked them to at least bring us some water. It never improved. Aside from being given our order, which they got wrong, we never saw them again until we stacked our own dishes to resemble something like the leaning tower of Pisa and asked for the bill when they came to save their stoneware from certain damage.

Anyhow, very good tapas and, as stated above, fantastic sangria. If only the service was as good.
author: Drue C.

description: We just came back from this restaurant and we are not very impressed. The food was good, but the service was awful. Not one of the servers had a smile on their face - they just looked annoyed. We had a complaint about their mussel appetizer (we complained in a nice way) and the manager was sent over. All she said was "this is how we've sold the mussels for the past 8 years," and then she just walked away. We will not go back.
author: Tanja Y.

description:
Totally awesome! Maybe the best tapas in San Francisco. We went with a really large group, so we got to taste so many dishes. It was Saturday night and it was crowded. Sangria was very good. I remember trying these dishes, but I'm sure there were more. All dishes were well prepared and good size portions. We've been coming here for many years and the food is always consistently good. Reservations are recommended. 

Gambas Al Ajillo garlic shrimp
Calamares Fritos fried calamari
Grilled of Strips Salmon served with romesco and aioli
Patatas Aioli homemade garlic mayonnaise
Champinones Al Ajillo mushrooms sauteed with garlic
Alcachofas a la plancha thin sliced artichokes grilled with garlic & parsley
Croquetas De Pollo chicken croquettes
Rabo Toro, Ox-Tail Stew 
Tortilla De Patata potato and onion omelet
Mariscada seafood platter
author: John M.

description:
Esperpento on a hot day is total chaos!  We got there right before it got crowded and they brought more tables onto the "patio"*.  Which means, we had an attentive waiter for the first 5 minutes, and then we had a ghost man who brought our food and took our plates (and not with any frequency - just  ninjalike stealthiness) but didn't stop long enough for us to make any necessary requests (ie the bill).  Usually, restaurants are pretty good about remembering the check.  It behoves them and all.

The food and sangria was good.  I put it in the ranks with Cha Cha Cha** for price range, flowing booze, service, noise level, and food character.  However, I found the food here to be just a little better without being more expensive.  And here, they have a trubador who bears striking resemblance to Little Richard with a spanish accent, in a metallic purple shirt, strumming and yelling incoherently a slightly familiar-sounding song.  We totally tipped him.  He was awesome.

Tortilla de papas - a must-order
manchego - pretty good (hard to f^ck up)
artichokes - best plate by far
white bean salad - so so
sangria - another must-order

*read: just the sidewalk.  Like literally right up against cars trying to park.
**Full disclosure: I  hate Cha Cha Cha
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Patatas Bravada: Bellisimo
Garlic Shrimp: Delish
Grilled Artichokes: MMM.
Tortilla: Exdcellent

I really love this place. Delicious food, friendly service, and a great deal. Muahhhh
author: Sabina And Pete V.

description:
The amount of food for the price is fabulous! This is your $5-$6 tapas place, meat/seafood dishes are more of course. Lots of veggie choices. Sangria pitcher is $16.50 and a glass is $4. We've come here with small groups and larger ones. We've come on busy nights and slow nights. The service is usually prompt (it was prompt last night when we arrived at 530pm). And the food has been consistent.

Here's what we ordered last night: 

2 sides of rice
garlic chicken
potatoes with aoli sauce
mushrooms
potato omelet
pitcher of sangria

The food was good, garlicky and filling! The sangria was pretty strong. But for two people, this was too much food. Our eyes were bigger than our stomaches when we ordered! I think next time, when it's just the two of us we'll order: 3 tapas, one order of rice and 2 glasses of sangria. That should do us. 

Total: $54 (includs tax and tip)
We'll always be back!
author: Caroline C.

description: Esperpento has served as the backdrop location to many important moments of my life so far. And oftentimes the soundtrack has been a live rendition of El Rey, compliments of the Musicos that wander in from the street.   Spicy potatoes and chicken croquettes are amazing. The paella and sangria makes me want to do the sultry mambo.
author: Jane K.

description:
Espana in San Francisco, that is what this place is.
I love it, I love it, I love it.  
After a superb vacation to Spain, my tastebuds have been forever spoiled to only the best of tapas, and thus far, nothing has come close.  My first visit to Esperpento, only having tried two dishes, I still had hope as I called to ask if they could seat my large party here on a Sunday evening.

On my last visit here, it was with a party of 21 people, and we had the entire second floor to ourselves.  For being able to accomodate all of us  -  A+.  For it being upstairs - - well, let's just say "heat rises" - and with all the patrons down below, cooking down below, it was like trying to eat in an oven at 230 degrees, but we managed.

Again, the patatas bravas was fabulous.  We also ordered fried artichokes, a couple of shrimp dishes, sauteed asparagus, bone marrow dish, rabbit, oxtail, calamari, and a few others.  Everything was excellent - -  except the rabbit.  I didn't like that one, it was dry.

Finally, I had the chance to try paella here, which I always intended to come back and try.  We ordered two varieties - - the all-meat, and the all-seafood - - both for 6 people each, and  then ordered a combination for 4 people to feed our large party.  It was so good that even though most of us were stuffed from the tapas, we still chowed on it.  
But we had SO much leftover that several boxes were provided for some of us to take it home.  Fresh meat, seafood - - the paella was tasty.  It didn't compare to the amazing paella I had in Bilbao, Spain - - but nothing ever will, I am resigned to that fact.  It was close enough, though - and I don't need an airline ticket to order it.

All in all - I love this place... and will continue to eat here.  The sangria is not quite as good as that of Cha Cha Cha or Fresca, but everything else is just as good or better.  

Atmosphere is much nicer at Fresca - Fillmore, so for dates and such, that is perhaps a classier option, but for a casual dinner with friends, it'd be hard to beat Esperpento.

Furthermore - - the price was incredible.
Of the 21 people, only 19 people were paying, and it broke down to a mere $41 per person, including 18% gratuity.  If all 21 were paying, it was going to be only $38 - - and that was after ordering perhaps one paella for six too many - -  so that breaks down to one of the best deals to be had for good food in San Francisco.

Tapas, to me, is not a true 5-star type of restaurant.  For the food - 4 stars, but I throw in the extra star simply because this place is in its own league when it comes to tapas in SF.  If it stands out, then it's worthy of making my list of 5 star establishments!
author: Grace K.

description:
Por favor, no me burla del español.

Pasaba un semestre del universidad en Barcelona cuando tenía vientiuno años y comía muchísimas tapas.  Comiendo en Esperpento me recordó de la cocina española que ahora me echo de menos.

La sangría era excelente.  Mi pareja y yo nos acordamos de que la alcochofa con ajo y limón era buenísima también.  Pero me molestaba que los calamares no eran muy buenos.  Creo que sea importantísimo de tener mariscos sabrosos en un restorante de tapas españoles.

El atomsfero era bien, nos sentabamos afuera y nos disfrutaban la cita.  Nada era terrible; comería aquí otra vez, pero no me impresionó demasiado.
author: Mari C.

description: I came here on Saturday to celebrate a friend's birthday and it was my first time there! I thought the food was amazing! I loved the tapas--artichokes, mushrooms, octopus, and the potatoes with aioli! OMG, the potatoes are to die for! If you don't mind the garlic breath you'll gain from the meal--then dig in!!! The seafood paella wasn't my favorite but it was good. The staff were friendly and always making sure we were good with water and bread. Minus one star for being a small space but it was still fun and lively! Would definitely come back for the artichokes and potatoes! Mmmm...yum.
author: Mel P.

description:
Been here twice and had a good experience both times.

The first time - Tuesday evening - pretty good, although our server was not very attentive or aware of us.  Eventually someone else started taking care of us and things got much better.  We had a carafe of sangria and five tapas - the highlights being the snapper and patatas bravas.

2nd time - a Saturday night, around 1030.  This place was pretty packed then, but I think it's because it's one of the few places still open.  Food was super quick that time around - patatas bravas were still delicious, and the creamed spinach was really tasty too.  The calamari was fine, nothing special, but the grilled artichokes had too much garlic for me to enjoy.  This time our server was right on top of things however.

One of these days I might try their paella dishes since I have a good vibe here.  Really, I think this place is a little more like 3.5, but their menu is appropriately priced and the sangria is really good (and totally worth getting a carafe), so I'm okay with rounding up this time.
author: Tmon B.

description: I went here with several friends the other night and we ordered a lot off the menu thinking it would be tiny portions like most tapas places. Not so, the plates were a good size for sharing. I got to sample a lot of things and everything was delicious but especially the scallops and the grilled artichoke. I will definitely be coming back here next time I am in town
author: Kerri S.

description: Delicious! Lots of tasty tapas and entrees, grilled trout being my favorite. Their house sauce is incredible, I wanted to dip all my food in it.  Great atmosphere, friendly and attentive staff and very reasonably prices. Definitely going to make this place a regular for all my tapa cravings.
author: katrina w.

description:
A very unpleasant dining experience.

Came in on a weekend day around 4:30 for a light meal.  There were only 3 other parties in the restaurant.  The menu said that weekend lunch prices are from 11am-5pm.  I asked the waitress if I can still order the lunch special, just to make sure, even though I've got a half hour window.  She says yes.   Decided to go for the lunch special, which included a free cup of soup of the day, plus two choices of sides, and french bread (?) with every order.  Seemed like a good deal.  Ordered garlic chicken from a smiling waitress, who never came by again - until I went to get her.  Three times.

My drink arrives, but no bread.  Then my meal arrives.  

"Where's the soup?"  I asked the waiter who brought the food.  He looks at me funny.  "Soup," I repeat.  "  It comes with the lunch special."

"It's dinnertime," he said.  

"No, it's 4:45 and your menu says weekend lunch is through 5 pm."

"I'll check," he says, and wanders off.  So I start in on my meal.  THe garlic chicken tastes awful - covered in garlic in a sauce that looks like it has MSG in it - shiny but not tasty.  Just leg meat, on the bones, all dark meat.  Potatoes are OK so I eat those.  THe side salad was just a few pieces of lettuce, one slice of tomato and a piece of red onion.  No dressing.

Waiter comes back with the soup.   But no bread.  I have to track down my waitress and ask for bread (she was sitting at a table in the back of the restaurant with her back to the room chatting with someone).  And then after a few minutes, I have to ask for bread again.  Now there is only one other party in the restaurant, who has just sat down. The waiter comes out with bread... walks past me ... delivers it to a couple who has just sat down.  HELLO!!!  Have to go ask AGAIN for bread.  My soup is now cold, and so is the rest of the meal.   No offer to reheat my entree while I'm eating the soup.  I ask for a refill on my drink and the waiter seems confused by this as well.

And then I wait.  And wait.  I'm done and I want to go but no bill.  Table full of dirty plates.  I have to get up and tell the waitress I would like my check...Of course, I'm wondering if they are going to try to charge me the dinner price for the plate...  And sure enough, when  the bill finally comes it's 2 dollars more than the "lunch special."  I have to go walk over to the waitress again and explain it to her.  She walks away and confers with the male waiter - for like five minutes.THe male waiter comes over (is he the manager?)  And says, "Oh, well when we printed the check, I thought we were at dinner hour, I'm sorry."  

"I think we had this discussion earlier, about the soup, and the lunch special."

"Uh. Yes."  

"Well, I am just going by what is printed on YOUR menu."

"Uh," he says.  He walks away.

I was sorry to have spent my money here when there are so many other tasty places to eat in the Mission.
author: Rose Q.

description: The food is pretty good but WATCH OUT never pay with your credit card, because they always ding you a couple dollars more whenever you use your credit card to pay for the bill (i.e. bumping up the tips without your consent whatsoever). I've got cheated a couple times and i'm finally fed up so i have to leave this 1-star review to warn future diners.
author: Aaron K.

description:
In short: awesome, authentic, Spanish cuisine, at extremely reasonable prices. 

I grew up in the Iberian Peninsula, and Barcelona is my favorite city in the world -- in great part because of the food -- so we had been looking for a place were could find authentic Iberian food. 

I'm happy to announce this is it! 

Everything we tried was perfect -- from the perfect sangria to the awesome croquettes, this is what superb Spanish food tastes like! Since I can't just hop on the next flight to Barcelona, when it comes to food this is the next best thing... 

Cool detail: they get their seafood from the nearby Sun Fat, which, as anyone who knows Sun Fat can attest to, is in itself a great harbinger for the deliciousness of all their seafood choices... 

Even the location is awesome -- close to BART *and* if you absolutely must drive, across the street from the New Mission Bartlett Garage (the only decent parking garage in the Mission).
author: Afonso I.

description:
amazing tapas! their tortilla and patatas were my favorite. the salsa brava on the patatas was delicous..flavorful. my mouth waters just thinking of it. the jamon was also very soft and yummy.

the sangria is good, not enough fruit if you ask me, but it does its job. i think i was feeling pretty nice after my third glass.

will definitely return!!!
author: Susana M.

description: I visited this place for the first time on a Monday and went again with a group of friends on a Saturday. This place is great for groups because you can select many different tapas which is all too easy to do given the size of the menu! The sangria is also great- a pitcher or three, depending on the size of your group and/or your thirst, is absolutely necessary. My favorite tapa is the sauteed calamari, I wasn't too fond of the mussels; they were small and not that flavorful. I'd love to go back and try the seafood paella!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Where else can 10 women (bachelorette party, even) try like 8 delicious dishes and have about a bottle of sangria apiece for like $30/each?! 

We had very attentive service and the dishes came out at a good pace, which has not always been my experience at tapas/small plates restaurants. Sangria to me is just overly sweet wine, but everyone else loved it and I manged to choke back a dozen glasses. 

The food itself, and we tried everything from the meatballs to the paella to the asparagus to the mushrooms, was awesome. And the veggie dishes were not prepared as an afterthought--they were my favorite. I'm adding Esperpento to my list of places to remember to patron more often!
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Ok.
I just returned from a one month trip of Europe and  I spent 8 days in Barcelon~Catalunya Spain, so you'd think that I'd had my fill of Spanish tapas.
Hell no. You see, the thing is that I wasn't at all that impressed with the tapas in Spain. Maybe, it was the establishments that we went to, but I thought that couldn't have been it, because every tapas restaurant that we ate at, was super crowded  and at one place we had to wait about 30-45 minutes for a table. I couldn't figure it out.
Why was the tapas in Spain just ok?
Now, I'm here in the Bay Area for a few days of recovery and decompression from a 24hrs + transition from France via London.
And, my friends wanted to hang out and have dinner before I head down to SoCal and get back to reality.
JC gave us 3 places to chose from where she's eaten before and it was in the area where she lives.
Pretty convenient. Cool.
Esperento was one of them.
Funny thing though, we actually decided on Thai food.
We get to Osha and there are about 20 empty seats and about 2 tables of 4 tops paying their bills, and the hostess/waitress says that their booked for reservations. And there was only 3 of us. What-ever!
So we decide Indian. Dosa. Line out the door. Oh man.
Next!
Esperpento it is.
Cool.
We get there and there are only about 4 parties ( about a dozen or so peoples). I usually consider and empty restaurant  on a busy avenue a bad thing. But at this point I didn't care. I was hungry.
We walk in and we're promptly and politely greeted by a gorgeous Latina, and we're sat at a perfect size table, right by the window.
Nice. Thanks you.
The menus is quite extensive and worn out. (good sign)
Oh man. Paella extravaganza and SO many variable of tapas to pick and chose and combine to create a feast of your fancy.
Very very nice.
Not too many beers to chose from. Sad. They were out of Negro Modelo (one of the 3 beers they had to chose from) so i settled for and Anchor Steam. Mm. Great.
After about 15 minutes and extensive item suggestions between ourselves, we finally have some idea on what we want.
Actually we didn't, but I thought we did.
So, on the fly this is what we got:

Tortilla De Patata - potato and onion omelet (basic tortilla Espagnol),
the potatoes were nice and soft and the eggs were velvety,moist and soft. And what ever that creme fraiche like sauce was? It made the dish even more delicious.
Champinon Al Ajillo - mushrooms saluteed with garlic. One of my favorite types of food in the world is mushrooms (any kind, really) but it's gotta be sauteed. Mm. It's pretty basic and simple. These were very good. The mushroom were fairly large and very plump.
Gambas Al Ajillo- garlic shrimp. Lots of garlic and delicious. Although I felt that the shrimp was a bit on the small size. Hah! 
Pollo Adobo - spicy exotic chicken. Huh? They serve Filipino food? Nah, this was cooked a lot differently. There was a lot of garlic in this dish as well and I think it was sauteed in red wine and maybe a little sherry. Of course there was some other spices in it. It was really good, but not what I was expecting. Hm?
We got a side of rice that was probably cooked with some kind of stock (chicken?) and there were some vegetables, herbs and spices. Again, simple and delicious.
And for the piece de la resistance(insert trumpets here), we ordered the:
Parrillada De Carne - a montain o' grilled meats!  Chorizo, morcilla (blood sausage. hell yeah!), and some other sausage(which tasted like my most favorite of meats: spam!), grilled chicken, pork kebabs and carne asada (skirt steak?) on a bed of what might have either grilled or baked potatoes, topped with grilled red and green onions. 
Fellow carnivores. This is your dish. Oh yeah! It's on.

Needless to say. Once again we ordered more food than was possible to consume. But dammit. We gave it our best shot.

Ok. So here's what I figured out.
One. Garlic and salt. That is what was laking in the foods in Barcelona. Not that it didn't have any, but that it didn't have enough. Or what I would have preferred.
Two. Esperpento rocks.
Now two things I didn't like about Esperpento.
One. Minuscule beer list. Aw. Hey Esperpento folks. Beer is good. Lot's of beer to chose  from is better.
Two. Frozen steak. Yuck. Please don't freeze meat for too long.
It fucks up the color, taste and texture. 2-3 days at most. Or, get higher quality beef. You can up the price on the menu if you have to.
I feel people won't mind paying a little extra if the quality is well worth it.

The atmosphere is warm, relaxed, comfortable and still a bit lively.
The service is great. Our server was attentive, but not intrusive.
And the over all quality of the food is pretty freakin' good.
The bill was the most impressive part. About 20$ a person w/ tip.
Very nice.
author: Kione E.

description: 4 stars for the patatas bravas. 1 star for noise level. The acoustics of the restaurant is not very good, making it less romantic for a dinner date.
author: Waves G.

description:
If you're with a big group of friends, hit Picaro because it's louder and brighter. If you're on a date, I say go for Esperpento, and here's why.

They don't give you that garlic dipping sauce that keeps your breath unfresh for days on end. It's quieter and more dimly lit. The sangria is better. Best I've ever had in fact. Also they have some different veggie tapas, my favorite of which are the roasted artichokes.
author: Sharon T.

description: I am usually not one to give reviews nor really bad ones for that matter. But the service was really bad and the food was mediocre. When I arrived, my bf was parking the car and decided to get a reservation so we could get seats faster. The man who usually is the host (Latin man with the comb over) said that it would be about 15 minutes. When he finally had a table for me he asked if I could give it away to a couple that just arrived and that there would be another table available for me soon. I said that was totally fine. Then as time went by another table was available and he gave that one away too. Then I was pissed because my bf was close by and he still insisted my table be taken from me. Such a rude host!!
author: Nicki W.

description:
Went here for a girls night out to start the night. Def. recommend making an rsvp. Even though we had an rsvp, we still had to wait a few minutes for a table to open up. 
Once our table was ready, we immediately ordered a carafe of the Sangria, it was very tasty! YUM!
Beware of where you sit because if you are one of the unlucky ones to sit on the outer part of the table where everyone walks by, I guarantee you that your chair will get kicked at least once throughout the night.
We ordered a few tapas that we could all share. One was the jumbo grilled with garlic, delish!!! Only thing was that they are slippery little suckers and one went flying down to the floor....oops! :)
Dont remember what else we ordered but I do remember that everything was tasty. No complaints on the food. The service was good too.
They even called a cab for us.
All in all a very cozy spot for a quick tasty bite and glass of sangria.
author: Carmen C.

description:
esperento tapas restaurant...wide variety of appetizers...spanish entire cuisine...combinations of small plates....enjoying full meal...small cramp rustic, but cozy dining....puzzling tables and seating around, and lifting over patron heads....trying best to accommodate waiting customers by door...waiting only few tick-tocks....seated with water pitcher, cups, and tossing of cold breads and butter basket....slightly hectic ordering...busy crowds and servers running and carrying....menu finally given at end....and ordering to beginning...followed my plates out in following order....

sangria jar (red wine and fruit cocktail)...finding disappointment being extra small carafe for $seventeen...feeling robbery...

boquerones fritos (battered 'n' deep fried anchovies)...five small pinkie sizing...fishy crispy treat at $five...

albondigas (five sauced small meatballs)....total $five.fifty..averaging $one.ten each for fine ground dense meatballs....resulting in rubbery texture...tasting magnificent...but, for self wanting "chunky" meaty course ground texture better...

croquetas de pollo (thick chicken and  mashed potato, croquettes, pancakes)...small palm-sized round....wedges cut with creamy topping...finding mildly seasoned...and well....chicken and potato...decent $five snack....

almejas a la marinera (clams in tomato soup-like beans and mild seasonings)....tasting slightly mild, bland, to tastes...starchy of plenty of beans floating....open clams to spooning liquids...pairing with clam and soup slurp...for $six.seventy-five...not as enjoyable...unless liking bean flavoring starchy tomato "bisque"  type bowl of clams....

*vega (spanish red wine)...bottling at $twenty-two for average red wine...tasting acceptable...better deal to $seventeen small carafe sangria....no?...yes?....for lush looking for best alcohol by volume per $dinero....

*gambas al ajillo (garlic shrimp in oil)...highlight of tapas...flavorful and robust....such a tiny treat and oil saucing best for bread dipping...highly recommended at $seven for handful of peeled shrimps...tail on....

jamon serrano (dry-cured spanish ham)...paper thin slicing...ham being pig...over toasty sliced baguette...two-bite sizing...fine and standard as self made snacking...$six for five pieces....esperpento liking five of all?....

*paella for four (baked in pan with chicken, pork, calamari, clam, mussel, shrimp and broth seasoned saffron and olive oiled rice)...being best part of dish...for self paella all that self needed for meal...pricing reasonable at $forty-six....being $eleven.fifty per person portioning...

total meal for six equaling $one-hundred-thirty.forty-seven....automatic adding of eighteen% gratuity and bump of total pricing to $one-hundred-fifty-three.ninety-five.....portioning out to $twenty-five.sixty-six per person dining each with small glass of sangria....and one glass of red wine dining.....filling meal satisfactory....

*highly recommended
author: Hen A.

description: Really good tapas! Specially chorizo, patatas bravas and croquetas de pollo
author: Cristina F.

description:
Went for tapas with a group of friends, and it was great!
Some of my favorites include the patatas bravas and garlic shrimp.
author: Desiree L.

description: This place is incredible. I work down the street from this place. I always bring lunch to work. I despise eating nastiness for lunch. There aren't too many healthy options around me, aside from La Taza on 21st but this particular day I was not in the mood for that. I pulled up their menu online and decided to have the sauteed calamari. You get an option of two different sides. I opted in for the rice (delish) and creamed spinach type of deal. Except it was not all thick and gross like cream spinach, it was really good. The whole plate was amazing. The Calamari was sauteed with what tasted like garlic, olive oil, herbs, etc. It tasted incredible. The freshness of the seafood also impressed me. I am planning a date night here with my girlfriends.And also with my boyfriend .Any excuse or chance to eat here will be gladly taken by me. *drools
author: Mariangeles C.

description:
I pass by this spot all the time, and I've been curious to try it and checked out the reviews on Yelp first before I decided to see for myself.

Came here on a nice, warm evening and had the pleasure of dining outside in the street--perfect for people watching, especially those drinking at the bar across the street (just be aware of the panhandlers asking for change). The service was friendly and the food was delicious! We had the fried calamari and garlic shrimp tapas, but with the small portions, they were gone in a jiffy, while we waited for the paella de mariscos (menu says, give at least 30 minutes)---the best restaurant food I've had in the Mission in a while. A carafe of sangria completed (and complemented) our meal. 

It's a good place for a casual date or a meal with a couple friends--simple, nothing fancy. I would definitely come back and try out what other tapas they have to offer. I knew there was something similar but far better than ChaChaCha's (a couple blocks down) and I think I found it!
author: Zell C.

description:
This my hang out with the girls. My friend brought me here once and I cant seem to turn away! The sangria is soooo delicious- we always grab a pitcher and finish it :)
other dishes I love are:
spicy potatoes
garlic shrimp
asparagus with parm
pork kebabs
and seafood paella is also great

the only thing i dont like is the band, they come and play the guitar right in your ear and its really hard to have a conversation
author: Jynni T.

description:
This is my favorite paella place! Ever since I came here 4 years and forgot the name and exact location, I've been trying to figure out where I had such great paella. Thanks to yelpers and the pictures people uploaded, I was able to confirm THIS IS IT. 

In the last four years, I've settled for other paella spots like Cafe de La Paz in Berkeley or another place on Belden place in SF and they never did the trick. 

Last night, a group of 7 came to Espepento and the food was great. It was a comfortable setting and the service was friendly. Our waitress gave us good recommendations - artichoke, asparagus and spicy potato. And of course, we had the paella for 6 that included mussels, clams, shrimp, and chicken. We generally do not like tapas places because of the small portions, but here we had left overs!

There was even live music! I am so glad I have "re-discovered" this place.
author: Mary R.

description: Awesome! The best Spanish food I have ever had! It's a very warm and cozy place with fun people. There is a whole load of options for vegetarians. Their Sangria was amazing! I will go there again and again.
author: P A.

description:
Esperpento is horrible. I found glass in my food the last time I was there, and when I brought it to the attention of the waitress, she proceeded to raise her voice at me and accuse me are trying to start problems. All I wanted was a new dish... I asked for the check (which we paid in full, no tip) and we all left, we didn't finish any of the food or ask for any of it to be boxed.

Absolute worst experience I have ever had.

If I could give negative numeros... I would.
author: danny e.

description:
Talk about bang for your buck. I'm putting this on my list of places that I can get drunk and full for under $20... that is really saying something.

I am not normally one for small plates but make the exception here as the plates are generous and the prices are VERY reasonable.  I have only been here twice and only paid once however I don't remember either bill being large.

What is big here is the flavor. Each dish is both bold and distinct from the other dishes.  Many times I think that cheap tapas places just have one 'seasoning blend' that gets put on everything on the menu be it chicken, beef, seafood etc...

I would say that the standouts for me are the sauteed chorizo as well as the spicy potatoes.  The only disappointment of the 7 or so dishes that we had were the abondegas, the meatballs didn't have enough flavor for me and the 'soup' was WAY to thick. All of this with some really tasty sangria and my dinner crew was set to get back to drinking.

If you are in this hood (my hood) and are low on cash but want something that isn't a burrito... come to Esperpento.
author: Thadd L.

description: A new favorite for me. Loved the grilled artichokes and the jamon Iberica. Delicious. Almost wanted to come back for dinner after lunch. Sangria was also good.
author: Kelin B.

description:
This place is good for sharing some small dishes and a pitcher of Sangria. The plates aren't huge, so you may have to order more than you think!

With that said, sometimes the service you get at a place makes it all the better. I overlooked the fact that I didn't love, love, love the food because our waitress was so helpful and really sweet. She made suggestions when we told her it was our first time at Esperpento and helped us pick some popular dishes. 

My favorite dish that we ordered was the patata and egg, which came with a garlic and butter sauce. Talk about fatty, but oh so good! The Sangria was refreshing, but the fruit wasn't edible at the end because the rinds were still on. Interesting...

Being adventurous, we also tried the olives stuffed with anchovies. Umn..... not my favorite. The meatball stew was just so-so as well.
author: Natalie N.

description: I was pretty hungry by the time I sat down to eat here so part of me was just happy to be fed.. My friends and I had called a few places around the Mission and every other place seemed to have an hour wait, so we were really happy when we were quickly seated.  They had a good number of vegetarian options which was actually super nice.  A lot of the tapas were actually okay, not entirely amazing (a mushroom one sticks out as being good, but not great).  The patatas bravas (namely the sauce) and the sangria were really good though.  Additionally, there was a zucchini dish that was really tasty!  I'd probably go back!
author: Rachana S.

description:
"Esperpento, especializing in tapas and Spanich food"

The typos on the menu are endearing, the staff kind and attentive, and the food delicious.  

I love the location and the decor, but more importantly, I LOVE the Sangria.
author: Christine M.

description:
2.5 stars.

I really like the ambiance, the decor and also the Gypsy/Spanish singer-guitarist with a great voice.  

The tapas, on the other hand, were alright.  I thought the Spicy Potatoes were too salty.  The Garlic Cabbage were quite tasteless and cold.  The Green Beans could be cooked more.  The Potato Omelet wasn't too bad but really doesn't match up with the other tapas joints I have been in SF.  My friends seem to like the chicken croquettes.

I think we also got Sauteed Spinach and some shrimp dish.  The bill came to a total of $54 for 4 of us  Very affordable but I really didn't like the food.  I must say though we had the nicest waitress even though they were super busy.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I couldn't shovel these tapas into my mouth fast enough. We got the chorizo (not to miss), patatas bravas (spicy!), grilled shrimp (very flavorful), green beans, and the spanish pancake (a dense potato treat!).

Hopefully we'll the get the paella next time. My daintily framed boyfriend (he wrote the review below this one) tends to eat about 30 to 40% less than me at all times, so I'll probably be able to pack most of it in anyway.

Sorry- TMI. The SANGRIA is so citrusy-sweet and unique--in a great way. A tiny bit fizzy and very (trust me) "effective" if you're looking to get buzzed. It caught up to me and I could barely walk down the stairs from the mezzanine level.

Minus one star for it being so frackin' loud you have to shout to have a conversation.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I only have three things to say about Esperpento:

Chorizo, Hongos, and Sangria.   All of which I luuuv with 75% of my heart!  (The other 25% STILL belongs to Jeff at Barracuda in NY, even now, a year later.)

Most waitstaff are charming, foxy, and authentic Spaniards, lispy Spanish & all.

Oh yeah, and go early---like before five o'clock, unless you like noisiness and crowdiness.
author: Randy F.

description: Went on Friday night. Noisy, crowded, tables jam packed together. Guess some might call it "cozy". If you are a big person or have a disability just be aware that this place is not going to get high rankings in the ADA compliance category. I did NOT find the food delicious enough to make up for how noisy and annoying the place was. I never want to go back, you hipsters can have it.
author: Sydney A.

description:
Introduction, your poor service:

I would have given it 5 stars if it wasn't for:

1) Long, long, long wait.
2) Terrible host, lack of professionalism - unfriendly, was not helpful at doing his job, he told us 15 minutes - which turned to over an hour!!!
3) Cockroach creeping around next to our table (we were seated on the far outside of the restaurant)
4) Had to wait even more time (15 minutes) just to get an acknowledgment from our waitress. Yes, we were seated almost to the next restaurant, but we waited over an hour!!!

So the service was crap, but the food made up for it. Otherwise, this place would have been a 1.

The food:

We had the combination paella with seafood, chicken, and ribs (it's standard but we had to wait 40 minutes for it to cook). Paella is known for their specialty, so I'd recommend trying if you go. Their spicy potatoes was better than Cha Cha Chas and we had sangria to top it off. 

Every dish was delicious, the only complaint was the shrimp in the paella was not as fresh as I'd like it to be.

Conclusion:

We arrived at around 8:30 and left the restaurant almost 3 hours later at 11:30. Esperpento, we understand you are busy, and we do understand we have to wait like everyone else. But where is your general courtesy for good customer service? I am not hard to please and I was disappointed. Minus 2 stars for your poor hospitality.
author: Enji L.

description:
Warm and inviting little Spanish tapas restaurant with live music.  We went to celebrate a friends birthday and they were able to accommodate 22 of us upstairs.  Service was quick and friendly.  The delicious Spanish food kept coming so expect to eat.  Sangria was good and my favorite dishes were the paella de carnes, garlic shrimp, sauteed mushrooms, and the combination meat platter consisting of pollo al ajillo-garlic chicken, pinchos morunos - pork skewers and montaditos de lomo - pork loin canapes.

The bill came to under $40 a person, definitely affordable for a tapas spot with alcohol and lots of leftovers.
author: Diana L.

description:
This place is great!!  I studied abroad in Spain and never had delicious food like this!!  The seafood paella is to die for.  I ate so much of it!  Then we also had tortilla patatas which were so yummy.  And patatas aioli too.  

The sangria is wonderful.  We drank lots of it.  We were there with a Spaniard who ordered the Creme Catalan for dessert.  She explained that creme brulee is French, and the French are shit.  So it's Creme Catalan for her!

It was pretty loud and noisy in there, but very festive.  We had a large party and they were very accommodating.

I'd definitely go back to this place again.  Parking can be a little bit of a problem, but there is a nearby garage.
author: Lily H.

description: This place is not bad and I like the environment, but the dishes are not that interesting given the long line. Good, but I expected more.
author: Ana W.

description: yummy tapas,... I love the calamari, patatas bravas, shrimp in garlic, garlic mushrooms and a glass of sangria is good too! The paella is good and its a great place to have a party, the upstairs loft accommodates about 25 (or more) people, and the service is good!
author: Valerie A.

description:
The only damper on my Friday evening was the fact that my friends were 1 hour late for dinner.

Everything else was awesome.  The host was just fantastic and had a table ready for us when they finally did arrive.  We were seated immediately and brought sangria.  YUM. 

Then we dined on patatas bravas, grilled shrimp, garlic chicken, zucchini, tortilla, grilled artichokes...and more sangria.

My very favorite was the grilled artichoes...i couldn't stop eating them!  Also I loved the mariachi tunes while we dined - brought me back to mexico.

Great place for a group -and did I forget to mention that we each only payed $25?
author: Lauren V.

description:
We managed to grab a table early on a Friday night, which was a blessing, because there was a constant crowd waiting on the sidewalk outside.

The patatas bravas were absolutely amazing, and our party of 5 enjoyed  somewhat randomly selected plates, standouts included chicken croquettes, oxtail soup, seared vegetables, and saffron scallops over rice.  The sangria was generously portioned and tasty, and I was pleasantly surprised that our table of 5 was stuffed to the gills (and with 2 carafes of sangria) for just $100.

My only complaint was that the servers obviously wanted to turn our table (understandable, given the crowd outside waiting to be seated) and kept finding additional items to clear from our table while we were finishing our drinks.  By the time we were ready to go, they had cleared the tables down to the bare surfaces (including water glasses).  However, given the waiting crowd, I think our wanting to linger was understandably inconvenient.

The decor was enjoyable, the service was friendly (and quick - a second serving of patatas bravas arrived within minutes of our request), and the price was right for an evening of fun with friends.
author: Laura M.

description:
This is one of the better tapas restaurants in the city.  I've eaten at Picaro, Charanga, and Ramblas all of which have better ambiance and posher surroundings but flavors not quite as down home and just plain tasty as Esperpento's.  

The fried and grilled calamari are to die for and so were the deep fried anchovies.  Pretty much anything in their fish and shellfish menu you can't go wrong.  Also their blood sausage and ewe's milk cheese were bold in flavor and delicious.

One star deducted because the place is very very cramped with tiny tables with barely any leg room and adjacent tables within an elbow's reach.  Also the decibels were pretty high in here.  You have to shout to have a conversation.

On a side note, the three times I've been here, our table was either mistakenly given away or we had to wait a very long time despite our entire party arriving on time for our reservation.  However, the totally cool host brought us a pitcher of their yummy sangria on the house for our troubles.  And who doesn't like slurping down free fruity chilled wine outside on a nice night in the mission?
author: P.J. D.

description: we had a great time at Esperpento today. the food and drinks were very good  and some fantastic, we were waited on well. everyone in the place seemed happy enough for a sunday afternoon and the wait staff did their job. for the quality and the quantity the price was excellent. my sister and I went with our mom for her birthday and we had tapas and sangria and were very happy with our excursion and will go back. especially after reading all these bad reviews i am for sure going to go back and support Esperpento. sheesh. you know, if there is a dish you don't quite like but everything else is great why don't you go back and ask them to cook it the way you like it next time? that's how you get what you want and make your local restaurant better.
author: Malaga S.

description:
The time: 8ish on Saturday (8.2.08)

The wait: not bad, about 15 mins.

The host: nice and attentive, got us seated fairly quickly

The fare: 
~ Alcachofas (Artichokes)... tasty but hard to eat... it seems the hard parts of the leaves were still left on? Questionable. 
~ Patatas bravas (spicy potatoes)... DELICIOUS
~ Tortilla patatas (omelette)... very good
~ house salad (with butter lettuce)... GROSS ... i will explain in a second

The waitress:
Terrible

The problem:
I was mopping up my salad with the yummy butterleaf lettuce and close to finishing when a little surprise came crawling from underneath one of the last pieces of lettuce. I watched in disgust as it circumnavigated my plate, probably wondering the same thing I was: what the hell was it doing on my plate?!

When we finally got our inattentive and elusive waitress to our table, I said, "There's a bug in my salad."

With a deadpan expression (it could have been her drawn on eyebrows, I don't know) and lack of concern in her voice, she said, "Oh." And took my salad and disappeared. 

When she came back, she put another salad in front of me and I said, "I don't want another salad-" and was cut off by her saying, "You don't? Okay," to which she picked up the salad and walked away. I didn't see her again until it was time for the check, which took longer to get than our meal. 

She said, with a little bit of attitude in her voice, "The salad's not on the bill."

Really? Thank you for saving me a couple bucks; that'll come in handy when I'm paying the co-pay for a doctor's visit if I get any sort of sick from this. Sidenote: this happened right after my friend at the table said she got a parasite for eating a salad with a dead bug in it. But my salad had a live one, so I'm sure I'm fine...

I don't expect a waitress or waiter to kiss my butt when I'm at their restaurant. I like the basics: efficiency, attentiveness (as in filling the beverages and making sure the food is okay), and politeness. Can't say the service here resembled anything like this. Okay, she might have been tired and had an off-day. It's not her fault someone put the salad in a bowl with a bug in it or didn't wash the lettuce. But she is responsible for offering an apology and trying to make sure the customer wants to come back. A free salad to make up for a dirty dish does not cut it. 

If the potatoes weren't so good, I'd give this 1-2 stars.
author: Jolene T.

description: Ever notice how sangria seems to make everything taste better?  The tapas here though hold their own, and at $3-7 a plate you can't go wrong.  The fried snapper, stewed oxtails, chicken croquettes and clams are good starters and prepare your palate well for the  must-have seafood paella.  The service was dismissive; we asked to see the desert menu, or rather the part of the menu that mentioned the 4 deserts available, the waitress grudgingly recited them as if she were reading off the stops on the New Jersey Transit  line.
author: Joc V.

description:
Pro's:
1. Food - Authentic and it's deeelicious! Fav's - lobster paiea
2. Sangria - one of the best that I've ever had 
3. Live Band
4. Inexpensive

Cons:
1. Service
2. Parking
author: Jaylyn S.

description:
We have been eating here for over 10 years.  After our honeymoon in Spain, we sought out spanish food here in San Francisco.  

After discovering Esperpento we ate there once monthly on the day of our wedding for the entire first year.  

We have *GREAT* memories of sangria, patatas bravas and aloili and camarnes aloli.  Every experience has been great.
author: Tracie P.

description:
Esperpento gets a solid four stars for my review. 

Reasons for the one star deduction:
The service and the seafood paella were both lacking, especially the paella. The rest of the meal was great, though. The service wasn't bad just a little off- we had to ask for water twice before we got it. Otherwise, the meal went smoothly and was delicious.

I'm glad I returned to Esperpento, as I had not been in over a year. I really should make this place one of my regular haunts.

Here's a list of memorable dishes I've had in the past and what I had last night:
1) Paella de Mariscos Or Seafood with calamari, shrimp, clams, and mussels. ($18.00 for 2) Just OK, not the best I've had by far - much better at B44 in SF or Bolo in NYC.

2) Morcilla sauteed spanish blood sausage. ($5.00) Very good, but I miss the blood sausages with romescu sauce from Timo's, which is gone now (location where Range is now on Valencia).

3) Alcachofas a La Plancha thinly sliced artichokes grilled with garlic and parsley. ($5.50) Excellent.

4) Albondigas meatball stew with saffron. ($5.50) Very good.

5) Parrillada De Carne griddled meats, chorizo, morcilla, chicken pork kebabs, carne asada. ($20.00) Very good and tons of food, heaven for meat lovers. 

6) Asparagus A La Plancha. ($5.25) Very good.

7) Sangria. (Price ?) Very good.

Last night we had Paella, 3 tapas, and 2 glasses of Sangria. The total price with the tip was just under $40.00. 

If you like tapas, go to Esperpento and enjoy.
author: Yvette K.

description: Delicioso!!  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF.  Delicious Food and great prices.  Where else can you get a lobster tail with 2 side dishes for $12.50?!?!  You know it's a great restaurant when you get there at 9:30 at night and there is a 30-45 minute wait!!
author: Rose Z.

description: I have eaten here several times and I've always loved the food, but the little mouse running around the dining room while we were eating ruined it for sure. I worked in a restaurant myself for years, so I completely understand that it happens from time to time. I also understand there are solutions to this problem that are pretty easy in the restaurant industry. Come on if you work there you must see it or hear it somewhere in your environment. That should be addressed before serving people food.
author: laura m.

description:
My favorite restaurant!!

Although the wait is always long ( even if you made reservation), the sangria and the food are totally worth the wait!!!! While u wait for a table, just ask for a pitcher of sangria!!! At the end of the day, you wont be disappointed!!

Favorite dishes:
All the potato dishes
Sauté mushrooms
Salmon
Clams
Grilled asparagus
author: Jessica L.

description:
Patatas bravas (spicy potatoes)
Plato de Calabacin (zucchini & onions in tomato sauce)
Asparagus a La Plancha (asparagus with lots of garlic)
side of rice (side of rice :)
Sangria

Delicious! Also pretty affordable -in the teens per person for two people. If you do not get most of these dishes when you go, you at least have to get the potatoes. Service was also nice and professional, since I only noticed the waiter when he was bringing our food and getting orders and such, so he wasn't obtrusive at all. Like me, they cooked the asparagus with a healthy share of garlic lumped in, mmm. We were the first ones seated in the restaurant for the dinner crowd, but by the time we left the place was pretty full and bustling. Writing about it makes me want to go back there right now for those potatoes..

P.S. for the germiphobes: the bathroom's also pretty clean as restaurant ones go.
author: Yiling W.

description:
I think tapas is overrated really.  For what you're paying for, I think you should get much more.

I ordered one tapas and it was a spicy sausage you can get for half the price (minimum) in any other Mexican restaurant close-by.  I mean, almost $70 for two people?  For that price, I expect MUCH more of the following:

* Customer service.  Only at the end of our meal did someone come by to refill our water.  I also thought there was too much attitude in the service...
* Greater quantity.  For that kind of money, I would leave 'stuffed'.  Not even close.
* More 'experience'.  If not more quantity food, than I expect much more of an experience than what I got.  I expect pampering darn it!

It's a nice date place, but there are a dozen other place close-by I would choose over this...  I'd go again if someone insisted on tapas..  And they paid.
author: R G.

description:
Judging them based on their Tapas, not their Paellas, which I should probably should try if I ever go back, but I had Anthony's cookies and Bi-Rite ice cream just before.

Based on the Tapas alone, it was all a little tasteless.

Sangria was ok.

Not a bad place to eat, but you don't have to go out of your way to eat here.
author: Frederick C.

description:
My first memory of this restaurant was when I was a little buger and ordered the chorizo tapa.  Not knowing that this was a tapa at all, I was imagining a full meal plate.  By the time everyone's orders were coming, I was thinking, yes..foood, I was so hungry.  When my order comes, I get a small plate with three little chorizos. I felt like crying...three chorizos! Feeling humiliated and watching my brother laugh- zoom in on his teeth. 

Lately, I've been ordering the combo dish, I usually have the salmon or fried calamari, with potatoes and spinach..mmm so good.  The paella is good too, and of course sangria is a must.  Is it just me or do you feel like you're being skimped on the Manchego cheese? Well it is a tapa.  The shrimp appetizers were ok, not too good or not too bad.  The flan is one of my favortites and so is creme brulee, although once the creme was cold..eww.  There's nice art on the walls, Picasso, and Pedro Almodovar and colorful intricately embroidered mantillas, yeah I've got it visually memorized.  One of the ladies working there looks like Angelica Huston. It is a strange coincidence that both Esperpento and Picaro have look-a-likes working there ..hmm.  Good place to eat with friends and family or on a date.  I always wondered what was upstairs though.
author: Glu C.

description:
There isn't much else I can say that hasn't already been said, you SF yelpers really know how to, umm yelp.

But anyways, all our small plates were delicious. Their sangria had a totally different kick than any other I've had--almost a slight bit of fizzyness. Utterly amazing.

On a weekend night there can definitely be a wait to get in.

I dropped them one star due to that the service was a bit inattentive. But they did make up for that with a free dish which was something of a spanish pancake, also quite T.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Loved the tapas here! During our visit to San Fran, our friends who are locals made dinner reservations for us here. There were 8 of us and it wasn't until we showed up that I realized how small this place was. Anyway, we only waited outside for about 5 minutes as our table was cleared off and cleaned. 

While it was a bit tight around the table, there was a lot going on around us which made our dinner very interesting (in a good way). We ordered a bunch of plates randomly off the menu, which was great because everyone got to try almost everything. We passed the plates around and had plenty of pitchers of sangria. 

I can't remember the exact amount, but I'm pretty sure we all only paid $20 each for dinner and drinks. The food was just superb!
author: Cathy S.

description:
It's a good place for tapas and just sharing food with 3 or more of your friends. It's fun that way. Paella for 2 plus 3 sides would be enough for a group of 4 people plus a pitcher of their good sweet Sangria (don't expect to get faded). 

- Chorizo, patatas bravas, paella with seafood and beef, garlic shrimp are pretty good. 
- You can do without the Adobo Pollo. 
- Rabit stew is definitely very tasty!  

Don't expect awesome food but considering the nice atmosphere, it's definiltey worth checking it out.
author: Hebert J.

description: House wine is 4.50, steal for a SF restaurant.  The food was yummy, good selection of Spanish tapas.  Had to wait 30 mins even though we made a reservation.  Place was packed.
author: Tashie P.

description:
They have this private room a couple doors down that looks like it can seat 10-12 people.  We sat at the single table outside that room on the sidewalk.  

Our server was really nice Paola was her name?  Really nice and friendly  personality, and made some recommendations that turned out great.  HUGE number of selections on the menu.  Maybe the restaurant needed more workers, because it was hard to find her sometimes.  

They also have this room upstairs that looks like it can fit a part of 26 or so.The inside of the restaurant looks really busy and was pretty noisy.  

The sangria was kinda meh, but I don't know what legit sangria should taste like anyway.
author: Dong T.

description: Paella (seafood or lobster). Order it and you'll be a happy person.
author: Ryan S.

description: Very disappointing...saw this place featured on Check please  Bay Area,since they gave a good review I was excited to try it .I ordered paella mix seafood n meat it was bad the muscles were dry ,the rice was hard it  was cookged like a fried rice and dry . It was for 2 ppl order . What a waste of money!!!! The plan was too small for the price. The  potato pancake was salty. I will never recommend it !Check please  Bay Area should never show this episode again .DIssapointing n waste of money!!!!
author: Evelyn T.

description:
Want a great tapas bargain? Ding! Ding! Ding!

Get this: a carafe of sangria, patatas, garlic mushrooms, blood sausage, calamari, ox tail, more potatoes, rice, and another plate of unidentified deep fried stuff:  Less than 15 a person.  Ridiculous!  Other places around the corner that taste half this good want that per plate.  Forget em!  Comparatively, Esperento is a freakin' gold mine.

To top it off, the service was lighting fast, the ambiance is cozy, and they even had live music serenade us for dinner.  Lucky for me it is far enough to where the pedestrian commute lets me break even on the caloric intake.

Though there was no signature taste to the meal, everything was tasty and well proportioned.  If I find an Esperento-only menu item to rave about I'll change my mind, but otherwise a solid 4-star choice for tapas, hands down.
author: niero g.

description:
Thanks Esperpento!! 

I had one of my birthday dinners here with a group of 20-25 folks. We had to wait a bit outside even though we made reservations already for 8pm (it was a Saturday night) I thought we'd get the whole 2nd level for us, but no..there were some random little dates sharing the same floor. Boy did I feel bad for them cause we were super loud. Blame the SANGRIAS. Those sangrias....looks and tastes so fruity but it'll hit ya good ;)  Food was awesome! Patatas bravas with their special sauce was my favorite tapa. Also the Torta de Patatas was yum. Calamari was good too. Queso Manchego was alright. Then came the 3 types of paellas: seafood, chorizo and the combo. I LOVED them all. My favorite was the combo paella. I used the big serving spoon as my utensil..yes, it was that delicioso. 

The environment is fun and eclectic. I felt like I was in Spain again. I'd definitely go back.
author: Alexa M.

description: A friend recommended this place so we went with a group of 14 people.  Service was very fast.  The place was a little small.  Food was just OK, nothing really stood out.  I'm glad I tried it but probably won't be back.
author: ryder w.

description:
I am saving myself forevermore from having to eat at Andalu's.  The prices are so much better, but more important, the food is so much more delicious here.

For the first time I understood why cooks rave about artichokes...grilled artichokes are amazing.  Their scallops were fat and chubby, their oxtail just dripping in a rich stew, and their potatos buttery and crisp (sort of like a Potato Anna).  There was so much more...it was a large group.  We were each hogging one particular dish, trying to grab that last extra piece before someone else saw that there was still some left.  It's the kind of food that has you humming while eating.

My friend did remark that the paella was unremarkable.  However, I see no reason to ever order the paella given the variety of their other dishes.

Thus far, the only time I have truly felt full eating tapas.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Okay, betches, I was in Madrid on Monday. So I kinda know what I'm talking about here.

Esperpento is amazing. It's the closest taste to what I ate over there that I have found in the city so far. Don't start: No, I haven't been to all the Spanish restaurants. But my taste-bud memory is strong, so back off.

Other "tapas" places here are good. But they don't taste like Spain.

We got a pitcher of Sangria that, if you can avoid excessive amounts of fruit, tastes like what we had there. Not too fruity. More like wine spiked with a hint of fruit.

For tapas, we had gambas al ajillo (garlic shrimp), which slid right out of the shell and tasted so, so good. Patatas bravas was HEAVENLY (pardon my all-caps). Albondigas, while probably the most lackluster of our meal, didn't disappoint. Perfectly seasoned, if a little dull. Topped of with pimientos al padron, those DELICIOUS roasted green peppers we got just about everywhere we went in Madrid.

Seriously, the only thing missing at Esperpento is a tostas menu (our waitress agreed).

So, if you like flavorful, exciting small-plate food, go here. Not terribly exciting ambiance, but never dull either. A pleasant wait staff rounds out an awesome dining experience.
author: Jeff H.

description: I thought it was OK, but not great.  The waitress was pleasant.  The wine by the glass, decent.  I had the ropa vieja and it was tough and not the delicious dish I am accustomed to...  The chicken croquettes were better, but not stellar.  I wanted to love this place...
author: Cara R.

description:
The tapas and the sangria are very good here... even better than Cha-Cha-Cha (though with less of the hip atmo if that's what you're looking for).  

I'm a little bummed by all the negative reviews regarding the service... but I guess just avoid friday or saturday nights as it gets a bit crowded and the place is probably understaffed for busy nights.

And if you are in the area during the day, this place is also a great lunch spot.  You can skip the tapas experience and just get a nice grilled fish with salad, rice, bread all for less than $10.  Ah, to be unemployed in the Mission again... those were some of the best lunches I ever had.
author: Neej M.

description:
Esperpento is usually packed and can be hard to get a table, but if you are a late night diner - 830pm or later - you won't have trouble, especially on a week night.  

It's great for a "neither of us know where to go or what we want and now we've spent 2 hours talking about it and we're only growing hungrier and more irritated" kind of night and before you know it you're out the door and down the street staring into this unassuming little tapas place and..... 

.... voila!!  As soon as the sangria hits your lips you won't remember those 2 irritating hours and will be so happy that the service is responsive and helpful.  On your first time dining, don't be shy, ask you server what's good!  It can be the difference between a mediocre meal with plates no ones every ordered and the grand slam you really want... some of my favorites include - 

Calamares Fritos - standard.  Not too greasy or under/over cooked.  I was pleased.  

Patatas Bravas - spicy potatoes.  I could have eaten this whole dish to myself mmmmmmmmm good.  Not too spicy but very flavorful.  

Grilled Artichoke - (I forget the Spanish name) - it sounds a little unusual, which it is, but I enjoyed it.

Judias Verdes Rehogadas - Green beans with garlic. LOTS of garlic, just how I like it!  

I'd love to try the paella next time, when I'm not gnawing at my own arm in hunger - it takes 30 minutes to make ... fyi!

We walked out of there after having 2 drinks, 5 tapas and tip for $46, not bad at all!! Most of the tapas are $5-ish range.  

I can't wait to come back!
author: Alice H.

description:
The first time I ate here was pre-Yelp days and I remember it being very authentic. Last night, the BF and I were craving tapas, so I suggested Esperpento. This place was packed on a Saturday night, but we scored an awesome table right when we walked in. 

We had the chicken and vegetable paella for 2, the grilled artichokes and the mushroom and garlic tapas. The paella reminded me of the paella I had in Barcelona. The rice had a nice bite to it and the chicken and mixed seafood were flavorful and tasty. I loved the grilled artichoke hearts. They were marinated in olive oil and grilled to a crisp. The mushrooms were ok. With a pitcher of sangria, I was very happy!
author: Denise L.

description:
I really liked the Sangria.  It had just the right amount of fruit floating around in it!  

The food was really good too.  I liked all of the interesting items on the walls.  I sat facing this really interesting poster of some crazy haired moustached mariachi looking guy.  Who is that guy?
author: Jenn O.

description:
Esperento receives 3.5 stars.  Sangria was good, though I've had better in the city.  The food came out relatively quickly and almost all at the same time, which is a plus.  The spicy potatoes were tasty, albeit a little on the greasy side.  The sauteed mushrooms were only okay, too garlicky and not many other dynamic flavors.  The same could be said about the artichoke hearts....bland and chard with not much flavor going on.  The salmon also was too garlicky, and was accompanied by a mound of garlic on the plate.  The only two dishes I have little to no complaints about were the adobo chicken and the quail.  The adobo chicken was only a tad spicy, but he sauce was super flavorful and doubled as a great dipping sauce for the free bread.  The quail was well prepared, greasy and a lot of bones, but that's to be expected.

Our server was energetic and was fairly attentive in the beginning of our meal.  It was later hard to track her down to ask for our bill and later to retrieve it to process our payment.  

Overall, the restaurant was your typical mission tapas joint.  Not the cleanest, but it's decorated well considering.  Great that they have a few tables outside, especially since it was a nice, warm evening.  Prices were reasonable as our tab for six plates and two carafes of sangria was just under $100.
author: Marie B.

description:
We began with Oxtail stew and anchovy-stuffed olives, not to mention a flask of sangria, which was even better than Cha Cha Cha's sangria. As delicious as the tapas were, I waited and waited for a reason to give this restaurant four stars, and as I saw the paella making its way to our table, I though that would win my heart. 

At that same moment, a waiter wearing a dirty white t-shirt zipped by, leaving a trail of bad smoker's breath behind him. That was just disgusting, though I shoved that image away to make room for the paella that came to our table. It was quite delicious, that ambrosia of black mussels, calamari, and clams. 

But I couldn't quite help comparing the taste of this seafood and rice to the more tamed and refined seafood dishes down the street at Luna Park. To be fair, we'll try Esperpento again, hoping for a four-star experience next time. After all, I have been known to plot an extra star to my reviews now and then. 

By the way, Esperpento translated means "absurdity." Perhaps they were referring to the goofy hermano playing the guitar, bellowing lyrics that just made people grimace in agony.
author: Daniel C.

description:
We came for lunch and had the following:
Gambas a la plancha-tasteless
Calamares a la plancha-lacked flavor
Almejas a la plancha-tasty
Queso Manchego-good
Chorizo salteado-ok
Patatas Aioli-good

We also had a bottle of the red sangria and it was so-so... we've definitely had better.   I've enjoyed tapas in Europe and throughout the US and thought this place was lacking in flavor.
The service was good and I was vassilating between 2.5.-3 stars so I decided on the latter.
author: Lizete S.

description:
So my parents and I found this place while walking around Noe Valley at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon, and it turned out to be pretty good for a first time tapas experience. We started out with the jamon (forget the rest of the name, but it had thin strips of ham, sweet onion and roasted red tomatoes over French bread) and the quail over rosemary potatoes; the jamon was very refreshing with the combination of the ham and sweet onion, and the quail was tasty along with the excellent potatoes (albeit a bit salty).  

We then had the paella with calamari, shrimp, mussels, pork and chicken. Read the fine print on the menu, it does take 30 minutes, although it felt like less time elapsed than that. The paella definitely wasn't bad, the chicken and pork were fairly tender; there maybe could have been a little more flavor from the shrimps and such, but having the variety of shrimp, etc. was a nice touch. You can order the paella for 2 ($26) for three people and be more than fine, because the pan it comes in is fairly large. I finished my portion of the meal off with a cafe con leche.

It was somewhat noisy inside though, largely due to music that was just a tad loud and also because of some large groups that were in there at the same time.
author: Justin L.

description:
I took a friend here for his birthday. i was able to make reservations for eight 3 or 4 hours ahead of time (for some reason someone said you couldn't make reservations...but I guess I proved them wrong). 

They kept the sangria coming (and we drank -alot- of sangria) and our food came out pretty quickly.

Some of the nights favorites were the green beans, spicy potatoes and that potato omlet. The Paella is good (though I've only had the vegetable one) and people said that the sardines were great as well. 

I've been here on a weeknight and there was no wait at all. Guess it just depends on when you stop by.

Good place, the service can be a little strange.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Really liked the food and the atmosphere (though it was very loud). We tried pretty much everything on the menu and everything was very enjoyable.

I recommend the blood sausage (I don't eat bloody things usually but it was good, especially with the patatas bravas combination), the grilled shrimp, chicken, and meatballs. The calamari was quite bad actually but it was probably just my taste.

The place itself is nice, small, and cozy. The bathroom has 1 toilet and 3 chairs facing it directly which I found quite hilarious.

Overall, very good experience, similar to Tapas Ramblas, except I felt like the food at Ramblas was better.

Oh yeah, and the prices were extremely good. 6 people full to the brim with sangrias (which were excellent btw) - $140 including tax and tip. That's about $24 a person - not bad at all!
author: Artem R.

description:
So I don't give 5 stars in one day...the service was okay..the food was so good. I didn't know I was going to like this palce...

Gazpacho soup
Olives....I mean come on. Just Go...it's cheap also.
author: Pink G.

description:
**** Dateline, June 27th ****
Dave turns 28, and goes Tapas!

The scene is Esperpento, right before the evening dining rush... we've been waiting for a table for four for a few minutes (they wouldn't allow a reservation), and everything is moving well. The dining room itself seems close to full, but not too busy, most people seem to be at the tail ends of their meals. Time goes by and we're motioned to our table for 4, so far things are going great for my birthday dinner... if only they stayed that way...

We sit and begin to talk amongst ourselves, all the while people are being seated, and business moves as usual. After about 20 minutes I begin noticing something... people that were seated after us are getting drinks, they've ordered, and in one particular case, one table had already started getting food. We haven't even gotten our WATER yet, let alone had a chance to order. So, doing what any normal person would do, I flagged down one of the staff and asked if we could order. He smiled, nodded, and disappeared.

*Time goes by.*

10 minutes later I have to ask again to order, the server I asked did his best to get away, but he knew he couldn't just walk off after smiling and saying yes. So, we ordered, finally. (For those counting, we've been sitting for at least 30 minutes.) We got some great tapas dishes, and a paella de carne. We also ordered a carafe of some of the best sangria I've had in my life.

Most of the tapas and the sangria came fast... however, we never were offered water refills, or even asked if we wanted more sangria. *WE DID*

We ordered some great tasty mushrooms, masterfully crafted clams, truly flavorful and spicy patatas bravas, and a fairly well done pinchos morunos (pork kebab.), however we also ordered the morcilla sausages... after we had finished all this, we waited about 10 minutes and flagged down our server to find out where the missing morcilla sausages were... "Oh yes, sorry." and then he disappears. To his credit, they came out 5 minutes later, and they are by far my favorite thing on the menu.

Now during this time, we have empty drinks, empty bread, and a slew of empty plates in front of us. The plates were eventually removed, but no one came by to offer more bread, water, or sangria. On the bright side, they did take a birthday dessert to another table... (... that table got great service, all 4 of them. :) Grrr. Drinks, bread, and birthday wishes.)

When the paella de carne came, I didn't care about them anymore, I saw this beautifully luscious rice creation in front of me, and my world went all paella crazy. The flavor was amazing, it included pork ribs, ham, sausages, morcilla sausage, pork kebab.... amazing. However, it was also the greasiest thing I've eaten in months. I missed out on a great night of drinking because it destroyed my stomach. It tasted good though.

So, at this point, we had a great tasting but mediocre meal. The tapas were great, the service was atrocious, and the paella would have been perfect, had it not made me sick.

I don't know, I've loved Esperpento, but it might be a hard sell for me to go back, unless I know they've fixed these issues.
author: Dave M.

description:
I made reservations at Esperpento for Saturday night, party of 9 for my birthday.  We got there and saw that it was this cute little place and VERY busy, thank goodness I had made reservations! It was so great, because since we were a large party (we ended up with 11!) they put us in our own private room!
We started with a couple of pitchers of sangria, then had to decide what to order, there were so many choices.  We finally decided that each couple would order 2-3 items and share.  I ordered the calamaria, tortillas de patatas, and an artichoke dish.  We were disappointed to find out that they were out of the ropa vieja because I really wanted to try that, but I liked the food we got.  One of my friends got the carne paella which was VERY good, I could have eaten a lot more of that but didn't want to overstuff myself! The quail was also good, but watch out for those tiny bones, wasn't really impressed with the green peppers, nothing exciting there.
Overall, it was a great dinner and when we were leaving the hostess even came outside (we were waiting for a few people) and asked us  how everything was and what we ate.
author: Monica P.

description:
Ramblas is waaaaay better. But it is cheaper here, and for the price, it's ok. But I wouldn't recommend the paella- it was really nothing special and kind of just tasted like Rice-A-Roni. Come on, now. The sangria was decent- but nothing special either. 

I did like the veggie platter- some really good cabbage (I know, cabbage sounds really boring, but it was in a good sauce). 

Overall, it's decent enough- I would have given 2.5 stars after the disappointing paella, but maybe their meaty ones are better, who knows. My vote is there are plenty of other much better places to eat in the Mission; nothing really special about this one.
author: Kristen L.

description: Paellas, sausages, potatoes tappas to share among 3. It was delightful environment and you can really feel the Spanish flavors and culture at this place.
author: Oanh N.

description: the restaurant was full, which convinced us to go inside. It was my first visit. I don't know, if they had a bad day or if they just can't cook. I did not like it at all. the food was fat, soaked with some weird smelling sauce. Won't go there again.
author: Daib S.

description:
Went here on a Saturday and it was crowded....i think the
