samgria was watered down cause we had a couple carafes and we were still sober.....The Potato fritters were salty as hell, and the shrimp in garlic sauce looked like it was heated in the microwave. The paella literally had 2 pieces of a whole chicken wing and and 3 pieces of pork butt cubes that were tuff as nails.  

The space was very cramped and the "outdoor seating" is basically some tables set out on the sidewalk without being roped off from passers by.  I swear people were literally eating right up on the window of a parked car.   
Parking sucks on a Saturday night.

Wouldn't recommend coming here...
author: Charles M.

description: This place has pretty excellent tapas. Their patatas bravas are as good as I've had in Spain. Their jamon serrano is extremely quality as well as their sausage with white beans dish. Their grilled gamabs are extremely flavorful as well, although be warned, they come with their heads eyes and feet still attached .. so if that grosses you out I don't recommend them. Wine is tasty, their house is from Spain- and for a 4.50 glass, I must say it is super delicioso. The staff is friendly quick and not pretentious. You never have to wait  long to get a table, but a reservation does help. No one in my opinion beats their authentic spanish pork tapas. yummy salty goodness. good prices too!
author: Sarah J.

description: We had dinner here with our beloved crew of 2 other couples and had a fun time.  The restaurant isn't too big but it was cozy and boy was it crowded.  There were a couple of tables behind us celebrating a birthday and we got to join in on the "Happy Birthday" song and toast.  We really enjoyed the paella and the sangria.  Overall, its a fun little place to have yummy tapas in the Mission,
author: Michelle D.

description: I don't know how this place gets 3.5 stars. The food and service was great. I recommend the grilled artichoke, anchovies in olive oil, yellow rice and spicy potato. We will be back again!
author: Jeff A.

description:
Walking into this place on a busy Saturday night was like walking into someone's living room where there is WAY too much furniture and bad lighting.  So very crowded.  

We had reservations and were seated in the loft area which was so HOT!  I mean HOT like boiling lava HOT not like boys with foreign accents kind of HOT. I had to strip down to my tank top which I haven't done since I've been in the bay area all week.  

The artichokes were thin and tasty, calamari were nice and big and sangria was definitely on the sweeter side.  The paella was great to share and I thought was alriite.   It was intimate and cozy, but they need to put a few more fans in the loft or open up a window! Jesus, let there be air.  I was on the verge of nose bleed and dehydration.
author: Christina C.

description:
I went there with a group of 20+ people. 

Sangria - very refreshing, not too sweet.
Paella - the meat one was very salty, the seafood one wasn't bad
Tapas - nice variety, but nothing really stand out. Maybe the mushrooms
Prices - very reasonable 
Services - not super attentive, but not bad either
Ambiance - very crowded, people bumping into your chairs all the time. 

Overall - 3 stars. Don't mind going back, but wouldn't go out of my way to dine there.
author: C L.

description:
The food here is great. I actually first came here with some vegetarian friends and was surprised to see so many vegetarian options. In fact, I came here once with some people, ordered the vegetarian paella for my brother, and it was so huge that 3 people ate it and there was still enough for us to each have leftovers for the next day.
For the non-vegetarian, the meatballs are excellent as are the shrimp and anything meat with garlic.
I am also partial to the green beans, white asparagus and the potatoes. Oh, the tortilla espanola is great, too.
The wait is never that long (20 minutes, tops, on a busy night, as far as my experience goes) and the Sangria is worth ordering.
If you want a cheaper drink before or after, The Latin is right across the street!
author: Rachel M.

description:
Sangria - very good. Food - excellent. Always easy to get a table. Open for lunch - perfect!!!!!!

Everyone should try the grilled squid!
author: duane a.

description:
Came here for my birthday with a group of about 12ish.  It started off great because the table I reserved was immediately ready for us when we arrived.  Throughout the dinner we ordered a couple of pitchers of sangria, a bunch of tapas to share and a veggie paella and a meat and seafood paella. Here is the breakdown of my impression of the dishes:
Tortilla de patata - meh. Typical spanish omelet. I always thought these would be so much better if it with some type of sauce
Patats bravas - really good. 
Champinones Al Ajilio (mushrooms) - the best option! very flavorful
Asparagus ala plancha - good flavor. Tangy flavor
Alcachofas  a la plancha (grilled artichokes) - ugh. Not my favorite. Then again i was never a fan of artichokes. Everyone elses impression was mixed. they either hated it or loved it. 
Grilled quail - didn't eat it but heard it was good. really small though. But i guess that's a quail for you.
Garlic shrimp - didn't eat it but one of the highlights for the meat eaters. They asked for more bread just to finish the sauce off. 
Veggie Paella - I thought it was alright. Not disappointed at all, tho. It depended on what mixture of veggies ended up in my mouth.  I did not care for whatever bean was in there (i think a lima) and that tended to throw off the flavor of everything else. 
Meat and Seafood Paella - I thought this was weird - the meat eaters HATED this but they LOVED the veggie paella. Go figure. 

The environment was lively.  Good mixture of characters.  It wasn't too loud that I couldn't hear people. 

The wait staff was attentive. The only issue was that they came out with the mushrooms after most of the other items were finished.  With large parties I am forgiving on things like that.  

All in all, I really enjoyed this place.   Would definitely come back for a group event or with just a couple of friend.
author: Richard C.

description:
I've eaten here a few times and have always come away completely satisfied. I recommend seafood paella, potato omelett, chicken adobo, chorizo (always salty salty so beware), sliced artichockes swimming in butter and garlic), and ox tail (slightly greasy, but that's how i like it). Maybe not all at once, but yum yum try as much as you can. Cheap (for tapas) and the sangria is delicious.
Mariachi, casual attitude, and decent service.....one of my favs I suggest you try it!
author: Rachel R.

description:
I absolutely love tapas, and wish there were more places in the area for it. Esperpento's tapas are hearty and tasty. I'm a sucker for the basics: tortilla espanola, patatas bravas, mushrooms sauteed in garlic, mussels. They also have some interesting vegetarian dishes like awesome thinly sliced, fried artichokes. Paella is decent, although not the best I've had. Their sangria is pretty good, and they have a decent Spanish wine selection.  I agree service can sometimes be a bit slow.

All the dishes are pretty big, for tapas. This is a good place to bring a group to chow down on tapas and drink pitchers of sangria. I personally find the periodic mariachi band visit, an occupational hazard at any restaurant in that area, to be a little irritating, but it's interesting the first time.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

their pollo adobo is sooooooooooooooooo good!!! as well as the garlic shrimp and the PAELLA!!!!!!!!!!!!

mmmmmmmmmmm......

i live in the east bay and wouldn't mind driving to sf just to eat at this place!!! i've been here 5 times already.. and the food and service are pretty consistent!!

you should go try it!!!!!!
author: miss ruby ..

description:
I can't stand this place.  I've been here twice and the food is great, the prices are great, but the SERVICE IS HORRIBLE.  I'm always left waiting forever for water and bread, and we never know if they've taken our order or not because they come back a million times.  They get some things right, and some things wrong, its just so frustrating because the potential is there.

try the potatoes.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
This place is definitely overrated for its tapas.

Don't get me wrong, the food is OK, especially when you are in a big group where the atmosphere tends to fit better. But there are indeed other better tapas places for the same price range.

If you are planning for a dinner date for two over the weekend, forget about it. The music is loud. And if you are lucky, you might find a mariachis singing next to you above the already loud music, and then later soliciting you at the table! And because no one can hear each other, one has to yell. At this point, it is not a restaurant experience anymore, but more of a bazaar.

Plus on our visit, the establishment overcharged us!

2 stars rating based on:
2.5 stars for the food
1.5 stars for the ambiance
2.0 stars for the service
author: alberto c.

description:
Great calamari! awesome chicken crokettes and Amazing Spicy Sauce!!!
pretty good price too.....
author: J Angel G.

description: I really like this place awesome Spanish food. I love their sangria and I go back every time Iam in town.
author: Rosa V.

description:
Great food, great sangrias and not expensive.  I love this place!!!!


*******second review*******
My do I love this place.  A group of us went recently....we ate a lot, drank their perfect sangrias.....total bill per person with a nice tip,  25 smackers.  A great bargain!!!!  The service was also very good....quick and friendly.
author: Christina C.

description: We had Tapas, Patatas are great! Pork kebab is delicious ! Chicken is amazing. We had Calamari as well was not outstanding. And the Ham on bread thing is not a good choice. Good for a date, a bit loud dinner time, but I would go there again.
author: Shadi K.

description:
I've traveled and lived in Spain-and yes, I'm trying to be pretentious- and I likee. I tell you why I likee: It reminded me of Spanish food, and the prices did too. Reality Check:  Potatoes, rice, eggs don't cost a whole lot, and this locale is humble so the prices shouldn't be high.  Sangria is lame. Try the rose wine by marques and caseres (sp?). 

I had Gambas a la plancha Prawns grilled in garlic sauce (not like asian). and it was quite good. I also ordered the patatas brava which has some great hot sauce (once again not what you would think if you are used to mexican or asian food). 



Service was fine and good. I don't need sunshine blown up my arse- just civil, basic,  service. Hey, like in Spain, France....anywhere but here. I'm excited about going back  to try more with friends, family,  or on my own even.
author: Kenneth K.

description: The food was delicious. I went with 3 people and we got a good sampling- grilled calamari- delicious, shrimp, grilled asparagus, sangria... we loved it all. I don't like packed busy restaurants on a weekend, so I probably won't go at 9pm on a Friday again, but will definitely keep coming back for more!
author: Alisha A.

description:
I liked Esperpento a lot more before I actually went to Spain and had real tapas. I've now been to Spain about 10 times and had tapas in Asturias, Barcelona, Madrid, Granada, and Cordoba. Esperpento does have good sangria and it does sort of help the "I'm dying to go to Spain but I don't have money for airfare" pangs, but it just really isn't quite the same. 

Esperpento uses WAY too much garlic. They use garlic in practically everything. Garlic aioli on top of the tortilla espanola?  I know tortilla espanola is bland, but it is supposed to be! Because of Esperpento, when I finally got to Spain the first time, I expected everything to be full of garlic, but you know, the Spaniards use very little of it in most things.  And I was grateful for that, especially considering that I was single the first time I went to Spain and well, who knows who I might have met? 

Esperpento is a good place for large groups though, which is normally how I end up there, at a birthday party or whatever.
author: Syd W.

description:
since my friends picked this restaurant I didn't know what to expect except that it was going to be good.  those friends of mine are real foodies so I knew I was in for a good meal.

we had a big party, 10, so they gave us the VIP room where it was private and separate from the other patrons.  not that I'm saying the other customers were creepy or anything.  it's nice to have your own private banquet style room so you can enjoy the food and the company without having to listen to other customers.  the main dining room is pretty loud though.

we started with a few appetizers like the chorizo, garlic shrimp, grilled artichokes, spicy potatoes and fried calamari.  for our entrees we ordered the vegetarian paella, seafood paella, steamed mussels, clams and finally the meat platter (beef, chicken, pork, sausages, on top of potatoes). I find it interesting that they had to spears of asparagus on the huge meat platter.  is that their way of having you eat some vegetables along with the mounds of meat?  also, this meat platter is literally your "meats and potatoes" dish.

so after listing all the items we ordered I want to thank my friends for ordering and showing up so that I can order more and sample the many different menu offerings.  it's always good to have more people.  I'm definitely going to come back here and eat more.
author: Samson M.

description: I went here for a drunken late night tapas experience and it delivered. They were generous with the bread. We ordered lots - from mussels, to a tortilla, to braised chicken, to croquetas. Most things were very tasty and affordable. The only issue was that most items were over-salted. The sangria was quite tasty. This place is much cuter than its cousin, and they had a great guitarist who performed karma chameleon among other songs. Muy cool.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great sangria, tapas.  Got to try the tortilla de pata!  The ambience is very authentic and quant.
author: Andrew T.

description:
This place defines the word amazing!!!!!!!!!!
If you go say hi to Oscar he will most likely be your totally cool host for the evening you would think it is his place as His attention to customers is unparalleled. In the middle of our meal our fist time in I dropped my napkin on the floor about 30 seconds went by maybe and as my girlfriend and I were talking he comes walking up with a new napkin takes the one that dropped he just happened to have caught this while attending to the crowd inside as well as those outside waiting!!!
Oh and if your really lucky you can have Marjorie as your waitress Can you say spectacular!!! She was absolutely great the first time in, patiently giving us suggestions on which Tapas to order all her suggestions were great but even better we showed up 3 weeks later this place is constantly full. We walk up Oscar recognizes us immediately welcomes us like old friends and take our name the wait was 30 minutes we come back 25 minutes later and he has the same table as the our last time waiting for us and Marjorie shows up as our waitress again!!!
Marjorie of course not only remembers us but everything we ordered she was again spectacular and the food again was The Bomb!!!!!!!!
Here is what we found delicious Pollo adobo the tortilla dish on the cover of the menu (cant remember the name) the artichoke, shrimp and Garlic, lobster and padrone pepper Tapas were absolutely delicious!!!
with 30 years of restaurant and hotel service background I would feel comfortable sending anyone here. 
Oh yeah and the prices are totally resonable!

I give them 6 out of 5 stars!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: David A.

description:
I have failed to write about this gem!   I would say we are frequent patrons at this place.   Thank You YELP!

Everything seems to be a  Must Have on the MENU, but not to be missed are:
Paella  4 Stars
Patata Bravas  4 Stars
Sangria 4 Star
Garlic Shrimp 4 Stars
Albondigas 4 Stars
Grilled Asparagus 4 Stars
Beef & Chorizo Stew 4 Stars

Friendly service, great value, awesome food!
author: Mia N.

description:
Thank goodness the sangria was numbing and I was in the company of my hot date.

Mind you, perhaps my flu-like symptoms, meds and alcohol made it all just a swirl of noise...but this is most def a rookie / low key tapas joint. The Tuesday evening neighborhood haunt. Share their platters instead and accent with tapas if extra hungry.

Not that the food is bad, but I'd rather spend a bit more somewhere else where the food is kick*ss and the service is at least efficient. Great gazpacho. Reliable tortilla. Cream of spinach was weak. The sangria, the locals and my hot date who used to hang out there in his early days made it worthwhile.
author: Tanya P.

description: Our favorite Spanish tapas restaurant hands down. We like to get there when they open at 5 before the noise level goes through the roof. The turista paella is very good. And there sangria is very delicious.
author: Juan C.

description:
The service was non-existent.  I know, likely they were busy with the other two tables that had guests at them, but the five or six staff members artfully avoided us & our empty drink glasses.  

Portions were small and the presentation sad.  Four pieces of cheese with two canned olives drizzled with cheap olive oil for $7?  

The food was greasy and oily.  The sauces all split before our eyes.  I don't think the food is cooked fresh.  Microwaved, maybe.  But chicken should not be ready to serve thirty seconds after ordering.  

And the pitcher of sangria that we ordered was served in a carafe.  Carafe = not a pitcher!  

Our group left hungry, disappointed, and with mild indigestion from the greasy grease of this place.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
I'm always cautious about tapas places because they're either not that good or they're super pretentious and usually is a fusion-based cuisine (i.e. Cascale in Mountain View).  But Esperpento is THE best!  It's authentic, tasty, good serving sizes, crowded, lively, and has sidewalk seating.  It also reminds me of my favorite tapas restaurant in London called El Molino.  The two places have almost the same exact patatas bravas and garlic shrimp recipes, which happen to be my two most favorite dishes (and the basis for this review).  The prices are pretty reasonable (between 3 people, $65 including a beer and glass of sangria).   I also appreciate how they offer a side plate of rice.  That's very convenient especially if you don't want to order paella.  

It is hard to get the waiter's attention at first, and if you come at a busy time, just expect to wait around for a while.  I won't comment on parking since it's Mission/Valencia and people who frequent the area should know what's up.  (Should also mention that there is a parking garage across the street, but not sure if it's public.)
author: Em C.

description: As my friend would say, "Holy Toledo!"  Man this place makes me like salt, even though its not that great for ya, but with a fusion of paprika and fresh garlic.  Oh my gosh, I was in heaven.   Who knew that those three ingredients would kick ass so much.  So my girl introduced me to this spot last night.  We ordered a pitcher of sangria, which was not bad at all.  We then we ordered cabbage, artichoke and mushroom tapas with the SPG.  Wow, it made me love veggies even more.  Cabbage was saturated in it, but still fresh and crispy.  It almost looked like kimchi too.  Mushrooms were assorted types and sizes, which was cool, and the artichoke.  They slice the whole dang thing thinly and grilled it.  I never had it that way.  It tasted amazing.  We also order the stew, which was blah, but the fried snapper was great.  The dipping sauce was yogurt base, but wasn't over powering, so you could still enjoy the taste of the fish.  Oh, I'm so going back.  I need to, this place was awesome.  Not too crowded, service was alright, decors every where, and had a great time.  I can still taste garlic in my breath, but its because I ate the left overs in the car ride over to work.  Mmm, wonder who wants to talk to me this morning.  Haha!
author: Janice F.

description:
My coworkers and I had lunch here and had a good time. The Sangria was tasty. Kind of a fruit punch with a bite at the end. The tapas we had were excellent. I'd recommend the anchovies and the artichokes. The paella was also good. A lot of variety of meats and seafood, combined with good flavor. We only wished the it would have been cooked a little longer to give the top that browned texture. 

Street parking was pretty easy at lunch, although I know this place gets packed at dinner time. The service was good and the store was clean. No complaints.

I wouldn't say it's the best Spanish resturant I've ever been to, but it's very good.
author: Andrew M.

description:
First of all, it's not Ramblas, so it should get a start just for that. But let's move on.

Started with a pitcher of sangria, which was pretty good. I've had a lot of shitty sangria in SF, but I was able to drink more than 1 glass of this one. My only complaint is that the fruit was diced instead of sliced, so it all landed in 1 person's glass.

I forgot. We didn't start with sangria, we started with Tuff Guy. Our waiter could not be bothered to say 2 words to us. It was hard enough to get his attention to order anything. Lucky for him, Esperpento suspects they offer bad service, so they automatically add 15% to your check, regardless of party size. YES! This is not cool. 

Tuff Guy finally swung back around to our table after I almost through my neck out trying to get his attention. At that point, we ordered:

- tortilla - excellent and so light!
- asparagus - they don't know to trim off the ends? or do they think we're impressed with extra long asparagus that hasn't been trimmed?
- potatoes aioli - very good
- veg paella - excellent and the 1st time I had seen a veg paella
- artichokes - yummy!
- manchego cheese - hard to mess up cheese
- mushrooms - pretty good, but it's my gold standard tapas dish and I've had better

I had a good time when i went here, but my review seems to be a little harsh. I guess it was the company...
author: Shal J.

description:
Went here for a birthday celebration, and had a pretty delightful experience. 

They were welcoming and graciously accommodated our party of 18 or so -- albeit I think we went on a weeknight, and they thankfully weren't that busy. It was loud in there, surely our fault *oops*, but it's not a "romantic" dinner kinda place anyway. Unless you enjoy yelling at your date? Then hey, do your thing.

The sangria is pretty killer: not too sweet, and wonderfully strong. Order the garlic alioli potatoes!! Seriously. 

The portions really are huge here, so if you're ordering an entree I suggest sharing (or gain brownie points with your roommates and bring them leftovers).

I look forward to going back again :)
author: Megan B.

description:
Was a little worried going in due to the couple of negative reviews, but ended up planning a small birthday get-together here anyway b/c of relative ease in obtaining a reservation and a combination of price/ambiance/word of mouth. And it worked out just fine. The wait staff was nice, though a little clueless. The space is small, and it gets noisy. But the sangria and the food were rather good - paella of course, but also the spinach, artichokes, chorizo, quail, patatas bravas and patatas aioli, mmm...I'd come back.

3.5 stars
author: Liz L.

description: Bomb ass Spanish food and sangria. Plus live music! What more u want? Highly recommend the garlic shrimp and patas bravas. Idk why these other reviewers hating, especially about the burnt paella, if it was a big deal then tell them. Not their fault u didnt. So stfu.
author: Andrei K.

description:
I totally love this place. Good food, even better sangria's in the middle of the city far from tourist and overly trendy people. This is a wonderful place to hang out with friends or to take my daughter out to dinner. 

The servers are friendly and helpful; even with me speaking terrible Spanglish. From time to time there's an wandering band that comes in and plays for tips which adds to the enjoyable ambiance.
author: Victoria D.

description:
After hearing so many good things about this place, namely how good their sangria was, I finally made it there last night. All the rave reviews of the sangria are dead on. It was divine. The tapas were slightly superior in taste and lower in price than most others I've tried.  An appealing combination. 

The place is really cute in a tacky sort of way. At least, I found it charming. It was a beautiful night and they had the large doors open and I felt like I was finally enjoying one of our rare warm city nights. 

Marachi singers come in and play at your tables which was unique, but I'm not sure if it was in a good way. They are so loud and then come around waving a bag asking for money. Luckily, the songs were short so it wasn't too obtrusive and it, admittedly, added to it's charm. 

It was a Monday night and the place was full at 9 o'clock, so I can only imagine what it's like on a Friday. Go early in the week if you can. You'll have a more relaxed and intimate dinning experience.
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Geez. Esperpento. You could be so much better.

I wish you would hire waitstaff that had a clue. That would help. I don't really like being seated and then waiting 20 minutes to get even a glass of water on the table. 

Your dishes: too much grease and salt. I mean, they are cute and all, and some are tastier than others, but... there's room for improvement. Like, a lot of room.

The atmosphere is festive  - I like that.  But it also just seems pretty chaotic, and my clothes reek when I leave.

I would go here again if you would wise up, but I think too many people who don't know the neighborhood are taken in by your curb appeal, and you don't get the encouragement you need to get your act together. A shame.
author: Dusty R.

description:
Hells yes! 

Tapas rock my world. I went here on a date and the Sangria made the experience sexy-sexy. Stop now. Go there. Get the Calamari. Tasty shit. The restaurant is a tad cramped, but having been to Spain, I must say they did a good job at keeping up the authenticity. The staff is incredibly nice, and very helpful. 

So why the hell did I give this neat-o place four stars instead of five? It's so loud. Almost like being in a bar- which is sad, because I wanted to murmur saucy things to my date- but instead had to scream them- which kinda ruins the mood, you know? The Garlic Chicken is kinda bland- but only in comparison the the deeelish mushrooms and Calamari. 

YUM.
author: Nnekay F.

description:
Best place for tapas.  Haven't ordered a dish i didn't like or
wouldn't recommend.
author: M E.

description:
This place has a great selection for vegetarians which is unusual for a tapas place. The food is good. 
The service is good even though its a little slow. thats why it gets a 4 star.
author: Rahul P.

description: I LOVE tapas. The sangria here is one of the best I've had...I would come back just for that alone. Ordered a bunch of tapas dishes per the server's recommendations, along with the seafood paella. As a warning, it's HUGE. Left with major food coma and a slight sangria buzz = happy me. The establishment is a bit small and parking is a pain in the butt, so definitely come early to grab seats and snag a parking spot.
author: Vivian D.

description: Great vibe here at this tapas restaurant, very busy, lively... and good service.   The tapas were delish... i take a star off because I didnt care for the Paella... It was bland and didnt crisp up at the bottom but more mushy.  I would definitely come back to try the other tapas.  Good place for groups for sure.
author: Tonya S.

description:
I was really disappointed by the food at Esperpento. My partner and I got 

the Sangria (very good...not too sweet! But not enough fruit...ONLY apples and oranges? Really?) 

grilled artichokes, which I had never tasted like this before. They were good, but a bit too...crunchy. It seemed like they needed to have started with better, fresher artichokes to do this dish well. 

calamari a la plancha, which was edible for sure but nothing i'd write home about. a little flavorless. thank goodness the calamari was not chewy. grilled veggies that came with it were boring. 

rabbit & mushroom paella - so heavy i thought my stomach would drop out. it is the next morning and I still can't eat anything, and I only ate about 1/4-1/3 of a Paella for two. Since when did Paella totally swim in oil? It's supposed to carry flavor without the grease. 

Also...please, owners of the restaurant: Put a buffer on your ceiling! Some sort of canopy, balloon ceiling panels, or just stretched fabric on frames installed on you ceilings would make it so the sound would not echo so much. The place was so loud that I had to shout to have a conversation with my partner. Really un-desirable.
author: M A.

description:
Best Spanish food in San Francisco!

I was hesitant to write a review because with a limited amount of tables, I'd hate to spread the word and make a small local restaurant more crowded than it already is, but the food is too good not to talk about.

I originally came here looking for Paella, but the tapas along with the other dishes simply blew me away.

I'm not a huge fan of eating olives as is but the "Aceitunas Rellenas De Anchoa" olives stuffed with anchovies (imported from spain) has gotten me addicted, especially if you eat it with the patatas aioli.

My father was raised on eating spanish food daily, but since he migrated to the USA in the '70s, he has never enjoyed a spanish restaurant as much as Esperpento.  

Dinner gets crowded and it's rare to not have to wait for a table, but Lunch is usually quick.
author: Paul C.

description:
My aunt was visiting us from out of town, and she and my mother love a place that serves good tapas. We were not disappointed. The sangria was tasty, not too sweet or tart. 
My aunt and I loved the Iberico ham as well as the gazpacho. My aunt ordered the lobster tail and grilled mussels which she said were delicious, and my mother had the tortilla de patata and the chicken croquettes, also good. 
I had a bite of the tortilla, and it was great, nice and fluffy and potatoey, the way my great aunt makes hers. I had the ropa vieja, along with the rice and spinach bechamel. The ropa vieja was good, though I am used to it more cuban style. The sides were good, but nothing to rave about. 

We also would up purchasing some paellera pans at a reasonable price, so hopefully I can attempt to make decent paella at home. A nice little gem in the city overall.
author: Sim C.

description:
4 stars, but would like to compare with another Spanish restaurant to be sure of that.
Anyway, we had a reservation for 8pm on Saturday for 2, and didn't really wait for it. Nice little table on the side, even if I would have loved to eat in the little corner under the stairs, or in the mezzanine.

On the food side, the appetizer we got (patatas bravas, queso manchego and calamari fritos) were very good and tasty. Very good olive oil in the queso manchego, Potatoes were well cooked, and the calamari well fried.
Then we had a Paella for two. The quantity is good, as well as the quality. Not dry, which is really important. We had the one with seafood.
On the drink side, we ordered a pitcher of Sangria, which was also well balanced and tasty.

Nice restaurant, nice deco, waiter service OK, and good food.
author: Bruno P.

description:
I love this place!  And I'm just getting started.

I've been lucky enough to travel a little bit, even studied in Madrid for a semester while in college.  So I've developed a unique appreciation for Spanish food, and this cozy spot delivers every time.  At times the service can be a little slow when they're crowded, but the food comes out quickly every time and always smells mouth-watering, while always tasting fresh & delicious. It does get loud the more crowded it becomes, but this place is not built to provide a boring dining experience.  Plenty of other soulless places to go if that's what you're looking for.  The walls are ornately decorated with beautiful objects of Spanish culture, movie & bullfighting posters, etc.  For me, there's a sense of being in another place & time when I go there, which creates an incalculably better experience each time.

The food is outstanding.  Off da hinges.  Whichever superlative you wish to communicate & bestow.  I can't remember how many people I've taken there who ended up loving the place - family, ex-girlfriends, co-workers, friends, etc.  I'm exceptionally partial to las croquetas de pollo, tortilla espanola, gambas al ajillo, and jamon serrano.  Of course I've had the paella on several occasions, and that has never disappointed.  The Sangria is excellent here, I never waste time to order a carafe as soon as I sit down to order.  Sangria, as it should be.

In my humble opinion, most of the other places in the City serving Spanish food and/or tapas are still behind this place, many way behind.  I've pretty much had them all, never went back for seconds to many of those places, and am always happy to go back to Esperpento.  If I could give it more than 5 stars, I would.  Hands down, still my favorite restaurant in SF for more than a decade.  Don't see that changing anytime soon.
author: Rolando P.

description: I haven't Yelped in so long, but this place has made me a believer. Whenever I go to San Francisco, I'm usually with my family and we have a set list of restaurants that we always hit up. So it's rare when we actually try some place new. The server was awesome and walked us through the menu and made some really spot-on recommendations. The tortilla espanola and the white bean salad were especially nice. The patatas bravas were perhaps the best I've ever tasted. I wish I had saved more room for the paella at the end, but that was moist for a change. I've had such subpar experiences with paella, so I found it refreshing to have one that was worth writing home about. Kudos again to our server. A very memorable dining experience.
author: Adrienne M.

description:
As I was eyeballing the food on our table, the only thought going through my head is that if I ate this food, I would get food poisoning. I was right. 

I give it one star for the sangria--not because it is good sangria, but because I think the alcohol and sugar saved me from getting fully sick.
author: Brer R.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I appreciate uberly chic tapas places w/ small plates drizzled in condensed sauce made from the root of an unknown tree bark from the Amazon rainforest. 

But I LUUUUURVE no frills tapa joints w/ a lively loud environment filled w/ happy people who are, in turn, filled with FABULOUS sangria. 

Especially if they serve great food. 

Try the blood sausages and potatoes. 

I promise you... after eating/drinking here... you'll be outside in the middle of the night trying to learn drunk skateboarding with your leftover paella and leather purse. Oh wait. That's me. If you see me, say hi!
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
This is the second time I ever had paella, and the first was absolutely awful. I ordered the meat/seafood paella. I shared it with my boyfriend, the portion looks huge but I could still eat more after we finished it.

We both didn't like the meat in the paella, they were cut really big, and hardly absorbed any flavor at all. The seafood were okay, they didn't taste really fresh and could use a bit more flavor as well. But the rice blew me away! I could eat this rice everyday and I wouldn't get tired of it, it absorbed all the tasty flavors of the seafoods and the spices. Cooked just well for my taste as well.

I would get just the paella with just rice if I could, but since that's not on the menu, I recommend getting the seafood paella, stay away from the meat =p
author: Daisy L.

description:
I love it when you randomly find cool places.  We were walking around the Mission, as my BF had never been before, and decided we were hungry.  After passing several taco shops and not being able to pick one, we came upon this place and chose to go in.  

Cute, fun energetic decor, and nice waitress.  We weren't starving so we had a large Parrillada platter for $20 which was amazing and way too much food! The platter contained chorizo, sausages (2 kinds), steak, grilled chicken, and beef skewers on top a bunch of sliced grilled potatoes and covered with grilled onions, green onions, and asparagus!  Some of it was a little salty for me, but my BF loved it all!  So depends on your taste preference.  

We were so stuffed we couldn't even finish it and had to bring the rest home.  But, mind you we also had Popeye's and Nations for lunch so that may have played a role in that factor.
author: Denise B.

description:
Economical prices... most dishes averaged at $6 to $8
Service was fair.
Poured a little tooo muchhhh sangriaaaa....
Everything we ordered was delicious - their seafood selection was great!
Rabbit was served... I had rabbit for the first time...
Place was packed and loud.  Don't expect to understand what your friends are saying.
Especially when the mariachi band comes in.
Nice, interesting interior.
Thank goodness we had reservations.
Overall, just okay...
author: Jasmine L.

description: Had a nice dinner here with friends. The food was good, it was crowded though. The service was good. Nothing really made it stand out from any other tapas place in the city. There are some better and some for sure that are not nearly as good. Kind of feel wishy washy about my visit here.
author: Jill T.

description:
This place is uninspired.  
Food: I can cook better food than what I ate here, and trust me, that's not saying a whole lot.  I had the veggie paella, i.e. mushy rice and overcooked vegetables.  Unimpressive.
Service: meh. No complaints here.
Ambiance: This place was filled with screaming kids.  I don't hate kids; I simply dislike them.  Especially when I'm eating - they're unsanitary.  To add to the obnoxiousness , a guitar player wandered around the restaurant screaming (singing? Even The Hoff would agree this guy had no talent) "Lady in Red."  
The saving grace? Sangria.
author: Nicole K.

description: This used to be my favorite Spanish restaurant -- I've been here over 25 times. I started going to this restaurant since 1998. The food was wonderful back in the old days and the prices were fairly reasonable. On my recent visits (3 times), I was so disappointed with the quality of the food, the service and the prices have gone up substantially. And the decor is dated; the same since I started coming here. I thought this place was as good as some of the restaurants I dined at in Madrid and Barcelona, Spain. Now, this place is more miss than hit on everything. The paella used to be my favorite. Now, it taste either half-cooked or soupy.
author: Peace L.

description: Bad experience at this place. Food was not ok. My friend ordered salad without onions, but for three times the server kept bringing a salad with onions in it, so my friend cancelled the order. We ordered flan for dessert and it was not good, chewy instead of silky. And the coffee. It is the worst coffee I can remember. All my friends who were there that night agreed on that.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
most of the tapas here were good.  i had some chocolate chicken dish that i was not fond of though.  the staff was super friendly but the service was a bit slow and inconsistent.  they were great when they were there... just they weren't always there.

- tapas bravas was excellent, i understand its tough to go wrong.
- garlic mushrooms pair well with the unlimited bread.  another one of those dishes where i literally clean the plate.
- squid dish was decent, it had a chewy texture as it should and the flavor was not over-powering.
- lobster paella was pretty good though i feel the lobster is consistently over-cooked.  i try to pretend that it is just there to flavor the spanish rice, which makes sense to me since the rest of the dish is so tasty.
- chocolate chicken dish was grainy and had conflicting flavors for me, i just couldn't do it.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Delicious food and great atmosphere.  We came here for a going-away party and it was great. It was my first time to Esperento and I have to say I will for sure come back.

The seafood paella was delicious and very authentic. The sangria was great and the flan was sweet and decadent.

I highly recommend this place for authentic tapas and Spanish food.

If you are coming with a group recommend getting a reservation. We had one and still had to wait a few minutes, which was fine. So do reserve your spot!
author: Daniela K.

description:
3.5 stars
solid, but i actually enjoyed their other place "El Picaro" at 16th and valencia much more. tapas were good, wine was solid...but the other place just has a bit more of that extra touch. Good spanish eats though for great prices, paella looks good but just got tapas, pollo al ajillo wasn't that awesome, but dry but calamari, patatas bravas and the ensalada mixta were all terrific.
author: Ben B.

description:
myself and some friends stopped in here on a lovely sunny saturday afternoon.  we were strolling along valencia, and they had just finished the shop at lucca's for the last bit of the needed ingredients for the dinner party they were hosting for us that evening.  they wanted a light bite to sort us through dinner, and suggested we pop in here for tapas.  

we ordered:
jamon iberico - thinly sliced spanish cured ham
ostras sateadas - sauteed oysters
alcachofas a la plancha - thinly sliced grilled artichokes
&
a bottle of red wine (i forget the name as they selected the bottle)

many people ordered various types of paella, and they all looked delicious.  i look forward to coming back and trying different things on the menu.

the restaurant is adorned with various spanish art; hand painted plates, fans, intricately embroidered beautiful shawls, posters of dali and picasso's work, almodovar's volver cinema poster, and other spanish related decor.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Went to try this on recs from tv show Check Please, uneven and pricey :-/

Best
- blood sausage, wowsa

Yes
- potato gravas, good side
- sangria

Disappointed
- grilled calamari
- seafood paella for two: 1st of all too big (more like for four), then the flavors were a bit lacking (they indulged my request for chorizo but it wasn't very good, too sweet, I like it grilled more)


Bonus: stop by Revolution Cafe when you're done
author: xo x.

description: I went here over the weekend with a few of my friends and it was packed.  When we leave at 9pm, there was still people waiting outside.  The food here is pretty good.  We ordered the Grilled of Strips Salmon, Calamares Fritos, Mejillones A La Plancha, Trucha A La Plancha, Paella De Monte, and the Lobster Paella.  The lobster paella is delicious.  The rice were cruchy and the dish is very flavorful.  I would recommend this place, but make sure to call in for reservation.
author: Calvin T.

description: If you love affordable tapas and a good atmosphere, you should come to Esperpento!
author: Elena D.

description: It's a must to order sangria and spicy fried potatoes. Good food for a good price. The $9 lobster tail was a hit but it's not as big as I've imagine. If you like Chachacha's, this place is better!
author: Charlie R.

description: Went again yesterday and YES the food is still amazing.  This time instead of the ropa vieja We had the CARNE ASADA YUM!!!  The service was kind of blah, especially when there were heardly any tables there.  Oh well, you can't have it all sometimes.
author: melafay c.

description: My husband and I went here today for lunch. It was great. I spent some time in Spain and it totally brought me back. The food was very authentic. I make some mean sangria and no place we ever go ever seems to compare. But, I met my match today. We tried the rabbit soup to be a little daring and it was great too. We will go back for sure. Nice staff, very friendly and comfortable.
author: Rachel P.

description:
Let me start with the negative to get it out of the way----parking SUCKS in the Mission!!  Unless you take advantage of Bart, take a cab, get dropped off, you'll have to deal with circling the block a bunch of times to get parking (the nearby garages were full).  Thankfully with patience, my friend and I got lucky as a car was leaving just a block away.  Okay, now on to the good stuff:
garlic shrimp-GOOD!
patatas bravas AND aioli-GOOD!
artichokes with the aioli sauce-GOOD!
asparagus-GOOD!
ox-tail stew-GOOD!
chicken croquettes-GOOD!
lobster paella-GOOD!
sangria-good, though not extraordinarily good, it still was pretty good and worth getting.  We did go through a few caraffes and some were sweeter than the others.  I will say that it was a big negative that our group of 8 had a reservation, only to have to wait about an hour to get seated.  The host was really apologetic and gave us a couple of complimentary caraffes of sangria for the inconvenience.  That definitely made up for it!  Most places don't do that kind of thing for you.
author: Tess E.

description:
I would really love to be able to review the food here except it just didn't work out that way.

Having walked past a number of times I found myself flying solo since hubby was late at work. Rather than cook I figured I'd try my chances in the Mission.

Esperpento was busy so I wasn't sure if they could seat me. They did have a table for 2 outside and a larger round table inside. The waiter who greeted me thought I was a 2 so I corrected him and said "just me whilst waving 1 finger". He seated me at the larger table and set 4 places.

Another waiter came up and bought 4 menus so I explained it was just me which she said was ok. I asked if she would prefer me to move if they had a smaller table (such as the outdoor one) so they could use the table for 4. She thanked me and said she'd check. She came back and said they had a table upstairs and handed me off to another waiter.

I followed her upstairs only to be met by the original waiter speaking Spanish at her, gesturing at me and stopping us from going on. She then told me there was no table for me. That if I wanted a table I would have to wait 10-15 mins. I pointed out I had a table and offered to move to suit them. Asked if I could have the outdoor table. No go, told it was wait or nothing. So I voted with my feet and left.

I would have had no issue if they'd asked me to wait when I first arrived. I understand a single diner in a busy restaurant is not as profitable. However to seat me and then pull this?

Instead I went up the road to Garcon who were happy to feed me well and take my $.
author: D M.

description: Though we have visited this restaurant many times, we were somewhat disappointed during our last visit. The pollo adobe was not fresh chicken, rather it was frozen, and it was chicken wings instead of being chicken breast. The mole sauce had no flavor other than a particular sweetness, but it lacked spices and a little kick to it. The scallops we ordered were not fully cooked and the rice we ordered had hard pieces of rice, meaning that they scraped the bottom of the pot, therefore the rice was overcooked and not fresh. Our waiter was  quick to rush us to order and did not once come back to check and see if we needed anything. The tortilla de patata  and the patatas bravas were much better than in recent years, so we are happy they changed their recipe for the better. The sangria, the ambiance, and the music is definitely the best part about this restaurant, but sadly not the food.
author: Pame Y Cristi P.

description:
While any night is a good night to be with friends and carry the night away basking in nostalgia over carafes of sangria, it does not dismiss the possibility for mediocrity at an establishment hosting such revelry. Such was the case at Esperpento.
Esperpento, I was bedazzled and taken in by your hearty sangria, but failed to find much fan fare with the various tapas we consumed to lengthen our abilities to process the sangria. The ox tail was nice, fried squid was as expected, and the paella was okay, but nothing jumped out and said, wow, tapas, delish! My food memory is forgetting already... save for the sangria.
I wouldn't mind coming back, but my search continues for a finer tapas experience.
author: Jessica L.

description: Reasonable and lively, for when you don't want fancy schmancy tapas. Good patatas bravas and tortilla espanola.  The ropa vieja does taste like "old clothes" so skip that.  The white beans and sausage also savory good.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Fun little tapas place. We made a reservation for 8PM and it still took about 20 minutes to get seated. The tapas were good particularly the seafood plates (I recommend the Cazuela De Pescado Con Almejas - snapper and clams cooked in spanish sauce). My other favorite was the classic Spanish Tortilla De Patata. I think we ended up ordering 5 or 6 plates for the two of us which was wayyy to much but I was glad we got the try a little of everything. This place is great for groups. The atmosphere was festive but kind of loud. The dinner ended well with a Creme Brulee and a cappuchino.
author: Debbie C.

description: We made reservations yet still experienced a one hour wait outside for dinner. A carafe of sangria for our party did not make enough amends, but we were hungry so waited it out. The food was good - patatas bravas smothered in a creamy-spicy sauce, nice dish of mushrooms, salty-as-hell cabbage tapas, and a pretty good dish of paella that came out of the kitchen way too long after we sat down to eat. We were stuffed by the time the paella came out, and what a big dish of paella it is! Lesson learned.
author: Angie C.

description: The food was absolutely great.  Took me right back to the pintxos and tapas of Spain.
author: olivia f.

description:
I don't understand all the negative comments about this place-I've been here three times and every time it was the same- damn good.

Tapas in Spain is cheap and fun.  In the South it's free, in the North, it's a mere pittance.  In Barcelona there are places that count by toothpicks on your plate or if you're bar hopping in the middle of the day in Madrid, the bartenders give you a free plate of salty tapas to go with your pint. You stay fed, inebriated and happy.

Tapas in Bay Area is generally expensive and tries a little too hard to be cool-come on now, tapas is just bar food, something to go with your beer, what's with the snobby front? I'm talking to you Cesar.

Esperpento has lower prices than most of what I've seen in San Francisco/Oakland, but most importantly has that vibe that I want in a tapas place.  It's loud, it's crowded, the sangria's good, the Estrella Gallicia (totally missed out on this while in Spain) is great, and street musicians come in and play-it's a good time.  

Service has always been good to me, I think I've waited an average of 7-10 minutes on weekend nights for a table, food comes out quickly, and I love how some dishes take longer than others, so it's like a tapas parade: grubbin' out on the patatas bravas, pollo adobo and some eggplant, then the oxtail stew and tortilla comes out, followed by the mussels...mmm mmm good.  They keep the bread basket refilled so I can soak up the stew and sauces and the portions of the tapas are generous so I always leave full.

It's not exactly what tapas in Spain is like (I didn't see any sardines soaking in garlic olive oil), but it's close.
author: Mike U.

description:
And I ventured out again to "the mish" to find some food with my friend Nat. I say this place is an average Tapa's restaurant (Tapas from Spain to be exact!). 

The food was not bad! I loved the potatas (a potato/egg pancake), which causes you to have lovely garlic breath in the end = very much worth it! My other order consisted of Meat balls in Safron, salad, calamari, & to be daring olives with anchovies (which surprisingly wasn't too fishy!).  The sangria wasn't bad, and was a good drink to accompany the meal...just watch out for those orange rinds, the small bite size pieces of fruit tend to camouflage into the wine color. 

Best part: The overall dining experience. A cute little restaurant that is actually 2 stories...it's not a huge place, but average size, the tables were a tad bit on the squishy side. Oh even better, when you get seated in the "cave." A very intimate little table tucked away in the corner (trust me you'll enjoy it!).  The waitress was very helpful in recommending certain dishes to our likings, and how much to order. 

Overall the place is pretty clean, and enjoyable. Get there early because it starts getting crowded on weekend nights.
author: Catherine O.

description:
I love love love Esperpento!  Always a great place to go when I'm seeking  something sure to be good and don't want to venture off and try something that might disappoint me.

I've tried many of the tapas choices, and none have disappointed me thus far.  My favorite entree to order is the seafood paella.  Yum.  I just salivated thinking about it.  It takes a while to cook, so I suggest ordering it as soon as you get seated or call it in.

I also love the environment--upbeat and festive--not pretentious and frou frou like many Spanish tapas joints in town.  Eating Spanish tapas should feel like a party inside and outside your mouth!
author: Trix L.

description:
Our party ordered our own separate tapas plus a meat paella platter and a fish paella platter and sangria.  When the tapas arrived, two orders were missing, so we had to wait for them. 

I ordered the pork kabobs.  Kabobs I have eaten in other restaurants always contained meat, vegetables, and maybe pineapple.  These kabobs were two skewers, each with nothing but 3 pieces of the toughest, most tasteless meat I have ever eaten.  

At least 3/4 of the paella was made up of large tasteless globs of overcooked rice, with tasteless shrimp and some kind of black(!) mystery meat.  

The sangria was very alcoholic, but with almost no fruit flavor.  

With 3 mariachi(?) guys jammed into this small restaurant, begging for tips, and playing extremely loudly, conversation was almost impossible.

In a city that is known for its great restaurants, I can't imagine what keeps this place in business.
author: Eddie W.

description: I had a great time dining at Esperpento.  It's a lively little restaurant  with live Mariachi music and good food.  The parking garage across the street was a added bonus.  I'm glad Daniel L & Maybelline C.  suggested this place as I'm very happy that there is a decent Tapas restaurant so close to home.  We ordered the Patatas Brava (Spicy Potatoes), Fried Calamari, Oxtail Stew and Paella Turista which has clams, mussels, squid, chicken, pork ribs and shrimp.  We also had Sangrias with our tapas.  I typically find them too sweet, but the Sangrias was very nice here.  The highlight of the evening was definitely the Potatoes.  The garlicky, slightly spicy sauce was addicting.  I would go back just for these potatoes!  3.5 stars round up to 4 for the good service and lively atmosphere.
author: Paul K.

description:
This is one of those restaurants that I wish I went to more but for whatever reason(s) just don't make it out to that much.

Finally did tonight and remembered why it's soo good.

First of all, I think the decor is really cool.  Spanish pride is very apparent and the paintings of Dali, Picasso and Volver are a few wall hangings that stand out.  The golden yellow color scheme and wooden tables and chairs give the place a very down to earth feel and makes you incredibly comfortable.

The food really is the shining star though.  The patata bravas are probably the best in the city.  The sauce is unbelievably good.  The manchego cheese is a great starter, love the little dash of cilantro they add to it.  Also had the zucchini stew w/onions and found it equally fulfilling.  The sangria is perfect on a warm day.

Esperento does not seem to get as crowded as some of the other tapas places in the Mission, and why I don't know (personally thinks it's better), so if you go, you probably won't have to wait for a table (score!).
author: Swetha G.

description:
In the Mission. Tapas. Can you go wrong? The food at this place was great. Flavors were definitely more on the Spanish side (yes!) versus the range of Caribbean tapas joints all over the City. It's a tiny spot though and ridiculously loud. Fun for groups but doesn't necessarily have the space to accommodate them. Bring earplugs and forget about having any table conversations. 

As for food, I was feeling the torilla de patatas, the gambas al ajillo, the garlic chicken and the paella turista. Skip out on the garlic mushrooms and the fried fish tapa... essentially just fish sticks. The paella was good although could have stayed in the oven a little longer to get a crisper bottom. Sangria was dope too. 

Parking garage is literally across the street so makes it easy on those with cars... unless you're up to spend $20 on a cab ride from areas like NB (which is what happened to me... *doh*!)
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Been wanting to eat there for sometime since I saw it featured on CHECK PLEASE BAY AREA.  Plus, I am a big fan of tapas.

We went there for my birthday.  Our plan was to nibble a little tapa and get some dinner later that night.  It was just me and my husband.

Was surprised to get street parking on Valencia.  Arrived at past 2 pm for late lunch and was completely blown away by the charming decor.  When we sat in there restaurant was empty except for about 4 tables.  I like the down home charm and ambiance of the place.  

Now for the food.  We didn't get any paella because well, we weren't feeling it that day.  Instead we ordered some tapas:

Gambas ala plancha - grilled jumbo shrimps - well not quite jumbo but they were yummy.

Cazuela de pescado con almejas - snapper and clams cooked in spanish sauce/tomato sauce - very tasty as well and the goes well with the free bread they give you.

Jamon Serrano canape - lovely as well, but I suppose it's my least fave of the things we ordered.  

Patatas Bravas - one cannot go to a tapa place without checking out the patatas bravas right?  I like the aioli, although I'd prefer the potatoes to be cute a little larger.  This one's yummy.

Escalivada - roasted eggplant , peppers and onion - really good.  A new one for me. Never seen it in other tapas place before.

Estofado de Conejo - stewed rabbit - boy it does taste like chicken, truly I tell you.  I really enjoyed this dish.

With a bottle of Barcelona beer and a glass of sangria our bill came to about $50 dollars.  We left the restaurant with to-go boxes,t hat's how full we were.

Would go back there in a heartbeat.
author: Maria R.

description: My cousin booked a reservation here to celebrate my Mom's birthday. We ordered a bunch of small plates x2 to feed 9 people. Some of my favorites include the potatoes with the aioli, the asparagus, and the garlic shrimp. We also ordered the seafood and meat paella, which was very tasty. But by the time we finished the small plates, we were way too full to eat most of the paella. I'm not the biggest fan of rice dishes, so I'd probably come back here for the tapas. They have a great sangria as well.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Great food, I agree with some the food intends to get a little on the salty side but you must choose wisely!

My regular night out in dinner here is:
-Pitcher of Sangria (Totally taste like juice)

-Chicken Croquette (I totally can't get enough of these, sometime they are out of it)

-Garlic Chicken (very tasteful it has some sort to tomato paste and broiled chicken)

-Calamari (YUM! who would like it the dip is pretty good too)

-Spicy Potatoes (Baked just right! the sauce intends to get a little spicy if you are not a spicy eater)

-Paella (2 people is good enough for 4 people, they serve a very large portion for this, This is the real Paella, some people think that it's really stick rice like the Filipino dish, totally not. Traditional Spanish Paella is not sticky rice don't get it twisted.)

-Grilled Artichokes (Very different they use the same sauce as the Calamari dip, its a little heavy on the stomach just because they use a lot of oil to grill it) 

Great place and vibe, there always someone coming in to show their talents, independent  local musicians preform in the restaurant to make tips, optional if you want to donate something.
author: Conchita B.

description: Great tapas, good prices, staff a little confused but OK.  Went with wife and two friends.  Had about 12 plates total bill with tax and tip $50.00.  Good deal.  Must try the blood sausage when you go trust me its great.
author: David B.

description:
A little on the shabby side. The location is a little on the crappy side. Parking, thank God, there's a garage across the street so that the dog I left in the car doesn't get harassed by bums. But who cares about all this really. The reason I went here is for the food!


 My friend even got a nasty ticket from a motorcycle cop since he was talking on the phone. Like the minute he picked up the phone coz it rang, the blue lights came on. Thanks a lot! Add another $200 to our dinner price tag, thank you very much!


 Buy hey, we are here last night, 3 people. We totally pigged-out and ordered Almejas A La Marinera (clams in spanish " marinara " sauce, with sauteed onions, garlic, parsley and white wine), Calamares Fritos (fried calamari), Brocheta De Vieiras (scallops brochette), Boquerones Fritos (deep fried anchovies), Expensive Jamon ($11, but oh so heavenly), Tortilla De Patata (potato and onion omelet, one of the most popular spanish tapas), Pisto De Calabacin (stew of zucchini, onions and tomatoes with tomato sauce), Ensalada Mixta (butter lettuce, tomatoes, onions, cucumbers, olives, tuna and hard-boiled egg in a salad dressed with vinaigrette), Albondigas (meat-balls stew with saffron), Rabo Toro (Ox-Tail Stew, hands down the very best item in the restaurant), Gazpacho (cold vegetable soup), 1 Flan, 1 Chocolate Mousse, 1 "Arroz Con Leche", and 3 sangrias.


 Needless to say, we were very happy campers. It was a little slow getting menus, but the glorious food excused any problems whatsoever.


 I still have the stew in my fridge, oooh!
author: nicgadei

description: This is a friendly, cozy little restaurant with tasty tapas.  I really like the pisto (zucchini) and spinach with Bechamel sauce.  They have a good selection of veggie tapas and have started serving their version of a mojito, which --while it tastes like there's 7-Up in it-- is quite refreshing.
author: Andi T.

description:
Very cool atmosphere...pretty small restaurant, but really crowded and busy, which isn't surprising because the food was awesome! Never had Spanish food before and I love it now! 

Pluses: 
Attentive waiter, seated a group of 11, tapas came quickly, good sangria,  lots to choose from the menu.  If you order the pallea, be ready to wait awhile for it...but it's SOOO worth it! The order for two seems like it can feed 5 especially after sampling the tapas, and it was very hearty....lots of meat, sausage, and spices!

I highly recommend this place if you want some real Spanish food!
After you're done with dinner, and want to stay in the Mission, go to Medjool for some dancing!...on Mission, between 21st and 22nd
author: Lisa C.

description:
Great service, good energy (if you like it loud and upbeat), great wine selections for cheap ($22/bottle) and the food was very tasty.

Granted, I'm not a huge tapas person - even after having lived in Espana for some months. Most of it is just too salty or oily for me but I can definitely appreciate authenticity, which this place is nothing short of.

We had the blood sausage appt., roasted eggplant, and seafood paella.  having had homemade paella from my host mom, nothing can compare but this paella comes closest ! Great flavors, seafood was fresh and plentiful. Expect a wait though, so don't come starved.  I couldn't do five stars because some of it was just a bit too oily but that's just a personal thang.
author: Kristine T.

description:
I've been here several times with girlfriends with whom I lived in Spain, and this place is great. Oily like everyone says, yes, but that's how Spanish food is. 

 I feel this place is plenty similar to the Tapas bars in Barcelona, where I lived for a few years. The setting is cozy and it has been crowded every time, always on week nights.  The servers are Spanish--they are efficient and polite. Everything I've had has been tasty--the calamari, the croquetes, the garlic shrimp....it's all oily goodness.

The Sangria, not overly sweet like most, is the best I've had in the States since I've been back.

The biggest difference between this place and the Tapas bars in Spain is the abundance of free bread. This is a good thing, as you can soak up all that extra good oil. Yum. Not to pricey either. 

I've left pleasantly tipsy and full (not wasted and stuffed) every time, with some extra cash in my wallet. Ole!
author: Acacia Q.

description:
i only go here for the sangria, paella, clams and estofado de conejo...

don't go on a weekend though.. not unless you dont mind waiting....

the sangria is fruitty and sweet....

the paella is GREAT!

the clams oh my....

and the rabbit stew.... these are the few things that i love on this place....
author: chris b.

description:
I took my dad there for Father's day. A good choice.

For my 2-year-old, I took the spinach bechamel, but he didn't really like it (he ate a whole bunch of bread from the bread basket though)

I had the spicy chicken. The sauce was excellent, but the pieces of chicken weren't premium (lots of bones). The sangria is ok.

We all had an ok meal, paid an ok price, drank some ok drinks... The stakes could be a little higher there!
author: xavier v.

description:
Had a very nice dinner here last night.  Even better than our last visit. 
For $47, we had 5 tapas and a pitcher of very tasty sangria. Walked in just before 7pm on a Saturday night, got a table right away and by the time we got our food, the place was packed.  

Food came quickly too. Love the fried anchovies w/ slices of red onions.  It's the one thing I always order here. It was excellent!  Other faves are the spicy patatas bravas, insalada mixta w tuna, tortilla de patata  w/ garlic aioli and chorizo sausages. We always like to mix it up and try something different w/ each visit.  This time we tried the manchego cheese and fried calamari. Both were delicious! 

There were lots of big parties around us and noticed that they either ordered the paella or grilled seafood platter. We've had both before and not only are they yummy, but the portions are generous. 

I'm glad that both the service and food improved with this visit. This is one of those casual, fun place with a European feel. Great place for two or a large group.  Definitely returning for more.
author: Jane F.

description:
I'm on a 3 1/2 star kick, so why stop...

I like this place.  Being that I have never traveled to Spain, I cannot really say that if it is authentic or not.  But my tastebuds like it.  The fried artichokes are delicious.  I also like the potato dish with the eggs.  The name escapes me at the moment.  It tends to be crowded on weekend nights, so don't be offended if you have to wait.  The sangria is drinkable and the fruit gives you a nice little kick start on the buzz action.  It's cute, though it tends to get a little loud.  But all and all, a nice little mission tapas joint.  Yeah, I called it a joint.
author: jen n.

description:
Came here the other night for a coworker's birthday.  Since we arrived just a little after 6 on a Thursday, we found parking about a 1/2 block away and the place was close to empty, so no problem getting a table.  A pitcher of water (and glasses) and bread were quickly placed in front of us, which was wonderful b/c we were thirsty and starving.  A pitcher of Sangria gave the three of us about 1.5 glasses a piece.  I prefer sangia with more fruit in it, but the wine itself tasted very good.

We decided to get three of the tapas and the "Turista (mixed) Paella" and everything was delicious.  Just a warning: the paellas take FOREVER to come out to your table, so definitely order some tapas or you'll get very upset wondering what's taking so long.  To me, it just makes the paella seem even more authentic since they cook it for hours in Spain, but I know it annoys some people.

Anyway, for our tapas we had the Tortilla de Patata, which was surprised me at being served warm, but had a great egg-y flavor and was quite a large portion.  We also had the Grilled Artichoke, which was sliced super thin.  Pieces were a bit tough, but it did have a great flavor, especially when you squeezed the lemon over it.  Also good were the Garlic Mushrooms, which needed a little salt but were very good as well.  Don't forget to mop up the garlic/oil with your bread before they take the plate away!

Our paella finally came out, we ordered the "for 2" size for three people and had about half of it leftover.  The Turista paella had meats and seafood, which to me is the best way to order.  They also had a veggie one if you don't eat meat or seafood.

The place was packed by the time we left, and a guitar player came in and played a couple songs, wandering around table to table.  The place gets VERY loud when it's crowded, so expect to yell to be heard across the table.

Delicous meal, I can't wait to get back here!
author: Lindsay B.

description: Delicious paella, only complaint was that the lobster was too rubbery.  I loved how the rice formed a nice crunchy slightly burnt texture, which is just how paella should be made.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I really liked this place! The food was yummy. Me and a gf got the patatas bravas, grilled veggie salad, snapper, and the chicken croquettes. Everything was very tasty! I'd probably pass on the chicken croquettes next time though. The service was great; we ordered our food and it came out super fast, like within 10 minutes! The sangria is very sweet and we were a little tipsy from one pitcher. I would definitely recommend this place for a date or just a bite to eat; the ambiance was very inviting and warm. I will be back to this place soon.
P.S. All that food for around $50.
author: Natalie H.

description:
Hadn't been here in years so when my vegetarian ex-boyfriend (he was a meat eater and I die-hard Denny's fanatic when we went out) asked where we could go for dinner that we would both enjoy, Esperpento came up.

Sometimes, I'm not looking for something fancy or special. I just want a really good meal with a nice atmosphere. And that's just what we got. We ordered all veg. tapas: two potatoes, a white bean salad, some manchego and this divine grilled artichoke. No complaints and our server was a dear.

Fortunately, we left just as the mariachi band was getting warmed up. It had started to drown out the conversation. But the bill came to $28 for two of us so we were happy as clams.
author: Maya S.

description:
Food is really good but service can be a true hit-or-miss.  If you like tapas and sangria, this is the place.  If you want paella, I would suggest their sister restaurant Picaro.  I don't know why, but one place does really good tapas and the other does really good paella.  

Top choices there: 1) Patatas Bravas, 2) Spinach Bechamel, 3) Garlic Mushrooms; 4) Fried Artichokes; 5) Garlic Prawns; 6) Salmon or Snapper with aioli; 7) Sangria

You WILL leave the place smelling of garlic and food, so, don't wear your favorite cashmere sweater there unless you are ready to have it aired out and dry cleaned soon thereafter.
author: H. Q.

description:
of us stumbled into this place at 10pm expecting them to say that they didn't have any room for us and try another restaurant.  Surprisingly, they said that they could work it out, and the manager went back to talk to the staff.  He came up front, and spoke to two men already sitting at a 4-seater table, and they got up with their drinks and quietly walked to take a different seat in the rear of the restaurant.

We sat down, and immediately ordered some Sangria.  It was fairly tasty, but came out warm.  We just ordered some ice so that we could cool it down.  We ordered gambas al ajillo, croquetas de pollo, champinones al ajillo, calamares fritos, jamon, queso manchego, aceitunas, and patatas bravas.  It was all very tasty, and the waitress gave us some aceitunas and queso on the house.

We had a great time here, and would definitley go back. :-)
author: Michelle K.

description:
I ended up at this resturant as I crashed someones birthday party ~smile. Anyway this is a  great restaurant which supposedly has been in the area for about 10 years. Their food was excellent. 

The waitress was fantastic, very patient and very helpful. Also the staff had a lot of patience even though they were packed.

I would recommend to check out this place. Just call ahead for reservations.
author: Amlan S.

description:
Not really impressed. My menu still had bits of food or whatever on it from a previous customer, and the food was just ok. True, I scarfed down the potatoes aioli (because, well, yum), but the bread didn't seem super fresh, I wished the garlic chicken didn't have skin and the rabbit stew was very tough. I gave up eating it after a couple small bites. 

Service wise, our waitress was nice but brought our first three dishes and seemed to initially forget about the other two. I figured she was just spacing them out, but ten minutes or so after bring the first round she came back to check if we were still waiting on anything; we reminded her of the potatoes and the stew. So the potatoes came out right away but the stew didn't make its way out to our table until every other plate was finished.

But hey, it wasn't a total loss. The sangria was great!
author: Tara B.

description:
I lurve this place. Lurve. Like Celine Dion does, when she sings, "The power of lurrrrve!" Delicious! I love the potato tapas dish and the mushroom tapas dish. One star off for slow and somewhat non-attentive service. 

But the food and wine are great! I especially like when you've had quite a bit of sangria, and the random performers come in and sing in Spanish while playing the guitar.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Okay, definitely not in the right state of mind to write a comprehensible review but the place is worth it to try. Oh those sangrias. God bless them.

So the beginning was a bit of a wait even though my friend made her reservations at 8. However, we were seated a little later at a long table in the top room. I could just see those other guests' eyes as they saw a huge group of young adults walking in. Yeah, sorry for the interruption! 

Took awhile for the waiter and waittress to take our order but hey, when the waiter offered sangrias, how could we refuse? Ordered 4 pitchers right on the spot and little did the waiter know that we would be asking for about twice as much as the night went on. Kept us loving life. 

Ordered calamari and the patatas bravas as appetizers. Delicious. Calamari was crispy & the sauce was creamy. The patatas bravas were perfect. I have no complaints. Then came the paella. Oh my goodness those paellas. You have to, have to order those when you go to this place. They're huge, delicious & amazingly satisfying. The one I ate the most of was the seafood one but I also tried the meat one as well. My friend and I couldn't help ourselves; we finished up those paellas with the huge serving spoons. Sorry!

Left the place buzzy and satisfied. Cannot wait to go here again and eat even more paellas. Come here with a big group or a few other people; either way, you'll be completely happy.
author: Steph W.

description: I just got back from a week in Barcelona, and I'm here to tell you that this place has tapas every bit as good as what you can get in Catalunya.  Despite an exhaustive search for the best tapas in the world, I never found anything that could match Esperpento's patatas bravas.  And I'd put their alcachofas up against anything I found abroad.  They don't have the variety of tapas that you can find in Spain, but the quality is excellent.  Viva Esperpento!
author: Adam G.

description:
Went here for the first time for my friends b-day, and it was a great location for our last minute b-day dinner plans. There were about 14 of us, and considering our last minute planning, they were pretty accommodating. 

You really can't beat the price. We ordered 5 large carafes of Sangria, and  bunch of plates, and including tip, ended up only paying $22 each! I thought the food was quite good considering how cheap it was, and they have a ton of selections. We had several vegetarians in the crowd, and all the veggies dished we got were quite tasty (especially the patatas bravas). However, they were out of the spicy meatballs, which made me sad. The waiter was not particularly friendly, but did his job well enough, and put up with our noise and chaotic ordering process.

 I will definitely come here again.
author: Kelly L.

description:
A quick trip to Spain, for under $25 per person. 

The spicy potatoes are a must. I haven't even tried the paella yet, its supposed to be really good.
author: Miki N.

description: Simply spectacular. Phenomenal menu, great prices, great service. Best artichoke dish I've ever had. Fantastic shrimp, deserts, calamari, rabbit. It's worth the wait. Great place.
author: Z P.

description:
Esperpento, 

  How do I count the ways, the times, the many many times, that I've visited you and sometimes I love you, sometimes I hate you, right now I'm still in love with you..

  I went here for the cheap tapas, pretty good Sangrias, and noisy get together with chick girl friends that give meaning to life in the city.  

  I really like the clams in marina sauce, very buttery and savory.. and just great for dipping. There's not too much clams to be eaten in that one.. The fried squid is just alright, potatoes bravas gets another nod for that orangey mayo sauce they give you. The chicken and sausage skew is good too! Okay, so there's just a bunch of little tapas you should try there, so go if you're in the Mission and feel like walking down to 22nd and Valencia. 

 I really like this place because it's good and cheap, but bringing a date here can be a total crapper because it's so loud and dark at times. I've been with four or five different dates, I really don't know how that's possible... considering that I always want to try a new place.  I keep coming back and then complaining afterwards. I know I've got issues.. 

But bring your friends and just eat everything they've got since you won't break your wallet.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description: The only reason I would not give this fabulous restaurant 5 stars is the noise. It is so loud and crowded in this place. But the food is absolutely fantastic and worth it every time we go! Get the paella!
author: Bridget M.

description: Came here for a birthday party and man was i surprised. The owners were supper nice and friendly. They seated us right away and offered us drink and food promptly.
