description: Best Spanish tapas in the city, but you probably know this by now.  We found this great place while wondering around in the Mission and were quite pleased with our luck.  Patatas bravas, croquetas de pollo, gamabas ajillo and the sangria were all awesome.  Simply the best tapas I have had since out last trip to Spain.
author: Carlton N.

description: The sangria is definitely a must! We had 2 pitchers it was so good! We went on a night that was pretty busy and surprisingly enough we didn't have to wait that long (15-20 minutes) but it was packed. The paella was ok and I really loved the potato omelet dish (forgot the name) but I wanted to eat the whole thing by myself and not share it. I think we ended up ordering a 2nd serving ;-). It has a fun vibe so I recommend going with a small group of friends so you can chill and drink sangria.
author: Adriana G.

description: I asked a couple of people for their advice on a good tapas place and the majority came up with Esperpento. Why they suggested this place? I'm not quite sure.  I was sadly disappointed by the almost practically vegetarian blood sausages.  A bland but overpowering spiceyful dish, if that makes any sense at all.  The combo paella for two was definitely enough for a family of five or so and this too was bland!  I had to add salt and pepper to the paella to make it somewhat edible.  The friend I went with asked me if I wanted to take home the leftovers, my answer 'No. Um, I won't end up eating it and the food will go to waste and stuff. You should take it home' Truth of the matter is, we were both sadly full from an unimaginative meal.
author: Aim E.

description: Same owner, menu and food as neighboring Picaro.  The prices are indeed very reasonable, the food is quite decent, and the decor cute and spicy, but I do have a few complaints.  First, I was glad when the in-house mariachi band was done playing for the evening, as they made an already boisterously loud place even more earsplitting.  Second, the server was a bit inattentive, neglecting to come back to check in on us throughout our meal to the point where I had to get up and retrieve the bill after we had been finished for quite some time.  The dishes themselves were fair; patatas with a spicy aioli, sauteed garlic mushrooms and a tomato-based beef, sausage and chicken stew were savory and tasty, but the jumbo garlic prawns were a bit flavorless and difficult to eat.  There are certainly other exciting new tapas joints I will try before returning here.
author: Rick H.

description:
Gotta try the patatas bravas...they're incredible! Also love the grilled artichoke, fried calamari, mushrooms, and salmon. The food is a little bit on the greasy side, but that's what makes it so flavorful. Great atmosphere, love the mariachi guys coming in and serenading each table. It's great for all-sized groups because they have small, romantic tables for two, or bigger round tables for 4-6. 
I would definitely recommend calling ahead to make a reservation though because without one, wait time can be over 45 minutes. The wait staff is good, can take a little long sometimes but for the most part they are on point.
Last but not least....THE SANGRIA!!!!! This is one of the best sangria I've tasted EVER.  Very fruity and strong, so one pitcher for 4 people can go a long way....like it did for my 22nd birthday (I need not go into more detail). Suffice it to say that this place has a lot of variety and great drinks.
author: Alyssa G.

description: After reading the reviews on Yelp, I decided to go to Esperpento for tapas. The servers were really nice and attended to us well. The highlight of our meal was the Asparagus. The Sangria was also very good too. As for the patatas bravas - it was like they were drowned in sauce and you forget where did the potatoes go? Also the calamari was overcooked and tasted like I was trying to chew a tire! Even the mussels were overcooked and the sauce it came in tasted like they took italian dressing and poured it over the mussels and called it a sauce. I'm not sure if I will be coming back here
author: Vanessa C.

description: Esperpento has roaches! I have been to Esperpento many times. I live close by. Many of my friends have eaten there, too. I was just eating there. I ordered the jam on serrano on bread with tomatoes, which we love, and seafood tapas. It was good. We like the food. We decided to order the chocolate mousse. As we were having the dessert, a roach crawled up the wall and circled near my wife. We informed the waitress, who let us know she was blind, or had bad eye sight. She saw it and said que asco. It crawled to the floor and then came back. We informed another waitress, who was taking my signed bill. She looked at the roach. She lowered her eyeglasses, raised them, then lowered them again. I know what a roach is. It was plain as day against the creme colored walls. No apology. No sorry about how nasty it was to eat in that environment. I don't want to think that maybe if I was a member of the dominant culture, there may have been more concern. At least, make me feel like my business, which you have had for years, is important. I am not mad at the waitresses; they are not the owners. But don't pretend or doubt that a roach is walking circles on the wall. This is on the owners.
author: Norman Z.

description: With the various spanish tapas places around some might wonder why go here? It's cheap for one, no long lines or 30 minute waits, and the food is pretty good. I would say this has the feel of a casual neighborhood restaurant, not the kind of place I would go out of my way to try. But since I live nearby I've been here more times than I can remember. The sangria is a must for any tapas place and esperpento's sangria is good not the best I've had but good nonetheless. As for the tapas my favorites include the calamari (deep fried), spinach and bechamel, patatas bravas, mussels a la plancha, and the  clams w/garlic and parsley. If you're in the mood for something more substantial you can order plates w/one side and either salad or potatoes.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
The patatas bravas, the sangria, the gambas, Albondigas, oh, it's all wonderful. Service is pretty good, really, running a hectic and loud place with reasonable efficiency.

This would be 5* but for the fact that it is very very loud. And then the mariachi bands come in on Friday and Saturday and they piss me off. 'Here! Have an indigestibly saccharine and innaccurate caricature of an alien and exotic culture! Feel good about appropriating it! Because you're intellectually lazy, and aesthetically bankrupt to boot!' No thanks.
author: Alex W.

description: After contemplating about going here or Garcon next door, I'm glad we ended up here at Esperpento.  They have a pretty lively atmosphere with a large variety of tapas.  I like ordering up and I almost had a headache from choosing.  Our dinner was about 8 different tapas and everything was good except for the over cooked  prawns.  I really enjoyed the ox tail and the grilled artichokes.  The sangria is slightly better than average and you can't  beat the trio of Mexicanos that play their hearts out. (have your dollar bill ready when they come by your table)  It is very loud here and can be difficult to carry on a conversation.  Excellent place for larger parties for food and to get plastered on sangria.
author: Jason A.

description: Any place that has a Pedro Almadovar movie poster hanging on the walls and mariachi band playing has got to be awesome. The staff was on it. They were very attentive and friendly. But damn don't try to take the clam sauce away from a hungry girl. Every single dish was delicious and took a lot of restraint to not lick the bowls. Only complaint , too much food and not enough room in my stomach
author: Sophia C.

description:
Wifey's Review:

Should be no stars, I know, I know. Just read the following and you will understand...

Upon seeing Esperpento featured on Check Please Bay Area with Leslie Sbrocco, my husband and I decided to give it a try.  We went on a Tuesday night and it was pretty packed but we were seated right away.  The menu was easy to read.  We ordered five tapas plates and were excited to try something new.  Little did we know it would be an unpleasant experience.  The waitress gave us some bread and it was stale!  My poor husband (who loves bread!) had to chuck it on the ground in hopes of getting a new basket of fresh bread.  It did not happen.  The second basket that finally came (I had to get up to ask the waitress) was a step up.  Anyway, the food came out rather quickly but we never saw our waitress again.  I wanted more hot water for my tea and it took several failed attempts to get the teapot filled.  No one checked up on us.  It was horrible service!  Whenever I asked the  waiter for something, he gave only a passive aggressive response.  He  nodded but never did anything about my request.  The waiter did this twice.  We had never had such an awful dining experience.  After we gave each other the 'we are never coming back here' look, we politely asked for our check.  Since it was only about 7ish, we figured by the time the check finally did arrive we could get home in time to watch "Dancing with the Stars".  We waited and waited and no one came to give us our bill.  I had to get up again to hunt down any employee and ask for the bill.  When the bill finally did arrive, my husband did not give them a tip.  In fact, he wrote a big fat goose egg with a line across it on the section for tip.  We thought the food was mediocre at best and service was atrocious.  Who has to get up several times for a server in a sit down restaurant?  If anything, they should be giving me a tip for all the running around I had to do.  Anyway, so we left on our merry way all the while complaining about the deplorable service.  It gets even better....two days later as my husband was looking at his statement online he sees that Esperpento so graciously charged us a tip we NEVER authorized!  A 15% tip which they did not deserve since they did not do anything that would constitute to any tip let alone a 15% tip.  What audacity and brazen entitlement!  We could not believe that they would do something like that.  We had no choice but stop by to talk to the owner and even called Mr. Muela so we can rectify the matter.  They always say he is not here and there is no manager. How convenient.  This is outright stealing and forgery.  So the saga continues.  The owner is suppose to call us back but I have a feeling that the tip money is as gone as our future patronage.  We will keep you posted on our struggle to get back our rightful money....keep up the good fight...don't give undeserving cretins tips they have not earned!
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
authentic spanish tapas done the right way. i've got a posse of spaniards who agree and frequent often for a taste of their childhoods. 
the paella is spot on, and the sangria potent. chill atmosphere in a great location.
if great tapas is what you want, esperpento will no doubt keep you coming back for more.
author: Olivia R.

description: One of the most overrated restaurants in San Francisco. I came here when I was very poor and had received some extra money through shady means so I wanted to get rid of it as soon as possible. I decided to do so here. I was so thrilled to buy a meal that wasn't a 4.00 veggie burrito from El Farolito. After eating it, I have never felt so robbed in my entire life. Everything was oversalted and the sangria was forgettable. It is truly a shame that they have such a great space because their food is awful. The beginning of my anti-tapas regime, for sure.
author: Maria D.

description:
so. being that i live a block away, i'm a bit nervous about writing a dissatisfied review, but oh well, i'm dissatisfied. hadn't tried the place before, and when we found out that the restaurant we wanted to eat at had a private party and wouldn't be able to seat us for two hours, we decided to call esperpento. 

us: "hi, can we make a reservation for 6?"
them: "what time?"
us: hmm... it's 8:40... long shot, but "do you have space at 9?"
them: "sure, no problem, see you then."
us: "rock!!!"

head over at 9. we're told it'll be 10 minutes, but that's cool, cuz some of our group hasn't gotten there yet anyway. 20 minutes pass... guy comes back out tells us 10-15 minutes. our party's all there now. 15 minutes pass... he comes back out and tells us 10-15 minutes. do we want sangria in the meantime? get sangria, drink, 15 minutes pass and he comes back and tells us another 15 minutes. we finish sangria, send one of us to get bacardi limon. he comes back to tell us another 10-15 minutes. tells us the sangria will be on the house. asks if we want another sangria, we say yes, and one of our people points out that the second one should be on the house too. guy agrees, and they do get points for that. we, ummm, spike our sangria. highly recommend that, and it probably helped this not be the most aggravating thing ever. FINALLY he comes back, tells us we can come in.

we get seated, have to ask for bread 3 times before it's brought to us, order some food to hold us over, food comes, realize some of us are missing forks. 

us: "can we get some forks?" 
them: "okay... we'll see if we can get some from the dishwasher."
ummm okay...was that really necessary to tell me? so weird.

food was okay but definitely not as exciting as other tapas i've had. mushrooms are boring, might as well make them at home. i liked the grilled artichoke dish, we all enjoyed the seafood paella, people were unimpressed by the calimari, and the sangria was great (especially with the extra kick).  we clearly had a lot to drink, so we did enjoy ourselves, but the whole set-up just seemed unnecessary; i mean, they could've said "no, we won't be able to seat you for an hour" when we called. right? right. sooooo weird.
author: lauren a.

description: Still love to eat here. Had the white bean salad (delish!), shrimp with garlic, potato omelet, chicken croquette (blah), and calamari (lighly crispy). It was packed on a Sunday night, and the service was a bit slow, but attentive and friendly. Surprisingly, not too expensive either.
author: David G.

description:
At this place I have experienced:

-average food, not particularly well prepared.

-xenophobic service bordering on refusal. telling us a particularly nice table was "reserved" (?) and then watching it sit empty the whole night...watching other people get served who arrived after us while waiting over half an hour for our first course...no water or bread for us, plenty for everyone else.

-extreme rudeness - male server attempting multiple times to touch my companion. male staff making click-click sounds and whistling (yes, whistling!) at my companion as she attempted to walk to the bathroom. un-freakin-believable!

-awful atmosphere. 

never again.
author: Currently A.

description: I was surprised at how inexpensive it was for a group of us to eat here. We had quite a few small plates and it came to about $25 per person. The spicy potatoes and the mushrooms are super delicious. The seafood was also delicious. The rabbit stew is pretty dry so you might want to skip that dish. I will go back but for now I think three stars probably best describes what I tried on my first visit. Next time I will order some pork dishes, because I have a feeling that's the way to go.
author: J F.

description: Lots of food and oh so yummy!  The food came out fast and the service was really good.  It was super garlicky too.
author: Ashkan J.

description: Thumbs up on this noisy MIssion tapas bar! I'm not saying it's got amazing food or super swell service, but trust the reason why it'd be packed on a Tuesday night: They have a respectable variety and everything they bring you is solid. Just be prepared to not be able to hold any conversations while you're in there. And beware the too sugary sangra, even if it is tasty...
author: Josephine J.

description: Well Tapas doesn't always have to be expensive!  We were pleasantly surprised by the price.  A group of 10 girls and nobody broke the bank!    On top of that the Sangria was super yummy!  The reason I couldn't give 4 stars was the loud guitarist!  What did you say . . .
author: Marcia S.

description:
First off, I always get decent service here, and if there's a mix-up they comp me BUT maybe that's because I'm Brown (and so is most of the staff).  My first experience in '97 was the jam.  Maybe, cuz dotcom frenzy was in its ascendency, it's the painkillers talking, but People, I've been to Spain and this is pretty authentic.  This is not to say it's excellent cuisine-- this is not Zarzuela or Bocadillos or Bar Cerveceria!  This is olive oil and garlic laden (don't come if you no like), cheap Spanish (&Filipino) beer, yummy, homey Spanish food.  This is not microgreens or organic poultry or artisinal anything so get over yourself. (I recommend Bar Cesar in Berkeley for that genre of tapas.)
Tonight's meal:
- Pollo Adobo (not my father's, but he's Illocano); chix was slightly arid, but the sauce is tasty-- not too spicy
- Gambas Ajillo (not Mexican though the chef probably is); the shrimp are too small to carry off the strong flavor of this dish, but they've made the right choice with peeling the body and leaving the tail on--  
- Patatas Bravas (not as good as ChaChaCha); they're not crispy enough.  I suspect in 1997 they were being deep friend and now they resemble Squat and Gobble homefries, but this is a standby tapa to help counteract the grease of...
- Chorizo (weird little sausages); I like Mexican Chorizo and this amazing Chorizo Bilbao sold at Bi-Rite and Lucca, but I don't know what the hell this is.  It tastes like chorizo though, and part of the appeal is the little sausages-- it's like that feeling you get when you see a dachsund. (I want to eat it?!)
- Tonight's best for last...
-CALAMARI A LA PLANCHA:  OK, do not confuse this with Calamari Fritti, I repeat, no talking about Calamari Fritti.  I had the Calamari Fritti once, and I was embarassed for the chef.  Can you do more than dredge sub-par calamari in flour and panfry (I'm not 100% sure this was the method but it sure tasted like it)??  But CALAMARI A LA PLANCHA-- this is a totally different story-- like carmelization, juicy tomato bits studded with crispy garlic- another bread dipping frenzy.

More dubious items:  anything with tuna (atun); grilled artichokes, bechamel with anything, albondigas missing something... Oh, yeah, prices have gone up, too about $1-2 since 2003.  Euro style service.

It's still one of few places to get authentic tapas in the Mish (until Hirogoyen busts out his Basque-shit in my 'hood!).
author: E L.

description:
WHAT!? No one's reviewed this place?? 

My parents told  me they saw this place on KQED and took me here which is kind of weird because I didn't think my parents could know more about the city than me, but boy am I glad they did.

I never understood why people said Cha Cha Cha's is overated until I came here. 

Here's the breakdown:

* Sangria: Definately beat Cha Cha Cha's! It's cheaper, sweeter (a plus for people with sweetoothitis like me), and they give you more! We got a pitcher which is more than 4 glasses for about $10. I was surprised that my super Korean super conservative super Christian parents let me have a glass. Sucked I couldn't let myself get a buzz going because I had to pretend I don't drink hahaha. It was funny seeing my mom gettin her Asian glow on though.

*Food: We got their sauteed mushrooms, spicy potatoes, spicy chicken, clams, a seafood dish that starts with a "Mar" (I forgot what it was called), and flan. All of it was very fresh but I didn't like the sauce that was on the potatoes, it was less creamy and thick than the one they have for the potatoes at Cha's (which i LOVE) and I think the potatoes could have been crispier but it was still good. The seafood dish was awesome. It had generous portions of fish, calamari, giant shrimp, shellfish, rice, peas, carrots, tomatoes, the whole shabang! It cost $24 but I definately reccomend it! The spicy Chicken was so tender, juicey, and hot, but definately not spicy which is fine with me. The flan was OK, I liked it better at Cha's b/c Cha's flan is more creamy and pudding like, and theirs was more jello like. It was all really great though because the tapas are 5-8 bucks and the portions are generous.

*Service: Their food came out fast but it might have been because we came pretty early (around 5pm on a Saturday) and right after we came the place got packed and had a line out the door. The waiters were kind enough to help my parents figure out which dish they saw on TV. I really don't like waiters that are too attentive (fill your glass after every sip, ask you how your meals going amidst a convo, basically you can feel their eyes on you every minute while your trying to enjoy your meal) but their service was perfect. 

* The place: Nothing fancy. Not really coordinated. Our table wasn't level which really bugs me but owell. Their bathroom wasn't Bloomingdales but owell. The parking was a BITCH but owell.

*Cute waiter: Resembled Olivier Martinez. I was mentally kicking myself in the head because I was there with my parents. Even my mom said he was cute. In front of my dad.  Had to pretend that I disagree so they don't realize I've gone through puberty already. GAH! GOD HATES ME.

I called all my girlfriends telling them we must go back. For their food, their sangria (I WILL GET DRUNK NEXT TIME), and that waiter. 

TO BE CONTINUED...
author: Lillian P.

description: Sat outside in the evening for tapas, and besides being harrassed by homeless people asking for change, the tapas was pretty good but without any sublety. The garlic was very prominent in everything we ordered, which usually isn't a bad thing but I would have loved to have actually tasted the lobster. The problem with reviewing a tapas place is that there's so much on offer it's hard to judge the entire place based on one visit. I'd try Esperpento a second time. Perhaps inside, where panhandlers can't get to me.
author: Chris F.

description:
We had reservations for a group of 14 ppl, and they gave us their private room east of the main building.  It was a horrible experience.  Disclaimer, some of the party was late in arriving.

The room wasn't big enough to seat us all, and it took them over 30 minutes to bring an extra table.  So for a half hour, 4-5 people just stood, waiting.  During this, we repeatedly asked to at least get a drink order in, and they couldn't even do that.

Long story short, i had to speak w/ the manger 3 different times to make things happen.  While they did finally start serving us in a somewhat normal manner, the whole experience was just nasty. 

To their credit they did give us 2 free pitchers of sangria, but then they continued to screw up and we had to wait 30 minutes between our 2 orders of paella (which were ordered at the same time).  After 30 minutes, nobody was even hungry anymore (and waiters were nowhere to be seen) so i had to track down the manager, again, and tell him to just forget everything, cut us a check, and let us get out.

I pretty much think this place has no right to do continue doing business.  I will never go here again.  Also, I've had better tapas, the food isn't anything to get excited about.  This was my 2nd time at this establishment and while the first visit had better service, the food both times was simply adequate.
author: John K.

description: This place reminds me of that place in Cordoba, I told my wife; when I got home and looked up "Raba de Toro," I discovered it was a Cordoba specialty. Lunch today: a small bowl of excellent zucchini soup; the oxtail stew; a platter of potatoes ali-oli and spinach in bechamel, all for $8.50. Fine fresh potatoes. We'll be back.
author: Charles S.

description: Really..cognac glass for sangria..spicy chicken can't be more sweeter, where is paella- maybe some other restaurant will serve it..check please..
author: Urvish T.

description:
I don't understand how this place has so many good reviews?! Food was horrible, bland, greasy... will never return.Meat had no flavor.  I pretty much review when something is exceptional or horrible and this WAS HORRIBLE! I looked around for a homeless person to give our leftovers too but couldn't find one so I threw them out- a HUGE BAG of them.

 On a side note had breakfast at TARTINE and it was exceptional!
author: j m.

description: So my bf and I are looking for something to eat for dinner and drove all around the mission area... So we ended up here... the place was good.. really crowded... i swear the place was so small.. in comparison to my apt loft I had before... The food's pretty good... they were quick and... thats all I can say?! Downside is that if you get to the spot a little late you'll have to wait a longggggggggggggggg wait... seriously... luckily for us we got a table right away... and had no wait..
author: Liz L.

description: What more can I say about this place other than that it is absolutely fantastic!!!  Sure, some dishes could've been better, it was quite noisy, and parking in the Mission is ridiculous.  But, the atmosphere, food, and energy in this place was addicting!  I loved the sangria; it was just as delicious as the last good batch I drank about 3 years ago on a farm in the south of France made by an Italian who fled from Sicily to get away from the mafia.  My favorite dishes were the cheese slices and the olives (simple but so delicious), the spicy potato pancake, and the rabbit stew.  Regarding the rabbit stew, I wasn't excited about the rabbit meat, but the sauce it came in was chock full of delicious flavor!  A great spot to take a group of close friends or to get cozy with someone you're crushing on.
author: Trina S.

description:
Before going to Esperpento you really need to prioritize what's important to you and your dining experience.  Particularly during the busy meal periods, you're going to be packed like a sardine into this tiny restaurant.  Also, don't plan on any intimate conversations because you're going to have to raise your voice in order to talk to the person 3 feet away from you.    Also, parking is street only and in the Mission, that can be a problem.

Okay, so if I have so many complaints then why the 4 stars!?!?  IT'S"S THE FOOD!!!  I don't know if this is traditional Spanish Tapas and I really don't care.  I've tried 50 things off of the menu and would order at least 45 of them again.  Known for the Paella (which comes in 5 or so varieties and is excellent) I opt for the Tapas.  Usually 5-7 plates take care of the two of us.  Throw in a few beers or a carafe of Sangria and you have an excellent meal for $40+/-

A few of my favorites are the Aoli Potatoes, Grilled Salmon Strips, Eggplant/onion/bellpepper, potato/onion omelet & Grilled Asparagus.
author: Adam L.

description: I did my research (on Yelp ofcourse!), so I was sufficiently prepared for the inconsistent menu items - patatas bravas good, cured spanish ham on french bread bad, grilled clams in olive oil and garlic VERY good! Clams were simple, yet oh so delish! So good my friend and I asked for two baskets of bread to sop up the oil long after we finished our clams. We sat outside because we didn't want to wait for indoor seating. And again, I was prepared for the homeless people asking for change. That, and the fact that our potatoes came out kinda cold were the only downsides. I recommend a carafe of sangria for two people. You want it to compliment your entire meal. A glass disappears way too quickly. Salud!
author: Nga H.

description: Great food and atmosphere for a resonable price. Plus the Sangria isn't that bad either. :)
author: Cynthia C.

description: This place has awesome sangrias and I mean awesome. I wouldn't recommend going in groups larger than 3 or 4 as seating is difficult also reservations are a good idea. I've only been here once, but I've tried their butter mushrooms, calamari, seafood paella, and clams. Everything was really delicious except for the paella, which was mediocre if not a bit disappointing.  It was essentially tomatoes mixed in with rice and some seafood, nothing special in terms of flavor.
author: Alesia T.

description: Good prices and tasty bits. This is not usually my first choice of eats in the Mission but when the burrito place is jammed, the sushi shop has no room, we can always get a table here. Love the sausage slices on bread with white beans (are those little suckers fried?)...really good. The vegetables options are always done nicely and I doubt you'd find a nice fillet of trout elsewhere in the city for the price. Esperpento is a staple in my regular dining options.
author: Pam D.

description: Love this place... I've been here serveral times and always come out super pleased.  The ambiance is quite lively and its cute how you'll find mariachas coming into the restaurant singing... however, be ware this place gets super crowded so mobility is not so easy.  Sangria is yummy and all the tapa dishes are fantastic.  Paella rocks too... its huge so make sure to go with a large party!
author: Jenn C.

description: Excellent meal and a fun way to eat with a larger group. We ordered a selection of tapas and found each to be well prepared and reasonably priced, considering the portion sizes. Ordered the potato frittata (which in my opinion was the best thing we tried), spicy potatoes, garlic shrimp, garlic chicken, pork skewers, grilled salmon strips, calimari and sauteed string beans. I didn't have any of the meats but the fish was fresh and perfectly cooked - especially the calimari, which often is too rubbery and/or greasy. We also ordered a bottle of house red and a pitcher of sangria, and for all of this we paid less than $100. It was a nice amount of food and a bustling, energetic atmosphere, and I can't wait to go back!
author: Beth T.

description: I would definitely come back here. The setting is really cute and the food was yummy. The waitress was very friendly and helpful in picking out dishes to order. I went with a friend and we got 4 dishes which was plenty!
author: Allisoto P.

description:
My vegetarian friends (do I have any other kind?) had heard some good things about this place, so we checked it out last night. I'm a sucker for Sangria of any variety so they didn't have to twist my arm too badly.  I had an immediate bad impression of the place when I walked in however, three different members of the staff asked us how many were in our party and then looked around, appearing to ignore the table of four in apparent hopes of shoving us somewhere smaller before the fourth person eventually sat us at the empty table everyone else had been avoiding. Also, near the door while we were trying to wait was some guy singing and playing the guitar, who immediately tried to get us to give him money after we sat down. Um, no--it was unpleasant and annoying.

Things got better after the waitress apparently read our minds and returned with a pitcher of sangria that we hadn't even ordered. (Don't things always get better when someone brings you sangria?) The thing about tapas is that you have to share...and I normally don't mind compromise but I'm eating with vegetarians. My mouth waters as I look over the carnivore selections on the menu...grilled salmon, saffron meatball stew, calamari...settled on the grilled salmon which was an excellent choice, but I'm still slightly bitter on missing out on the others. As delicious as they were, sauteed green beans and red peppers belong on the side of a dish, they are not a dish, even a small one. I will not complain about the potatoes or the sauteed mushrooms however, as they were the best things ever. The bread that came with the meal and the flan were totally uninspired, which is unfortunate because I had high hopes for the flan.
author: Christina K.

description: The food still deserves 5 stars.  However, the past three times I came back, the service has been getting less and less attentive and the staff seems so tired and don't even offer a smile.  So I dock one star.
author: Yun W.

description: I don't know if it is just me but aren't beans supposed to be soft?  I ordered one tapas plate while waiting for my friend to get off work on 22nd Street.  I thought a plate of food and sangria sounds great as I didn't want to be at Revolution Cafe or the bar across the street.  So I ordered a glass of Sangria and a sausage plate with bread and white beans.  The white beans were covered with cheese.  It was so disappointing to have beans not cooked all the way with sausage thrown on top of bread. It was a pretty plate presentation though.  The glass of Sangria didn't taste much better than Carlo Rossi either.   Sad on all accounts.
author: Sabrina A.

description: I really, really like the food here!  Yes, waiting can take FOREVER, and I'm not just talking about getting a table, even once you get seated, you're still waiting a good 10-15 minutes for the waitress.  But, you get great authentic tapas at an unbeatable price.  My friend and I got a veggie paella, Spanish Omlette, and a glass of Sangria each, for a total of $40, that includes the tip.  Not bad for someone who's on a financial diet!
author: Jen C.

description: It was suppose to be a 20minute wait but we were seated in 10mins. The food was delicious and the price was decent for the portion. Had the grilled quail, deep fried snapper, clams in marinara soup, and garlic mushrooms. I would recommend all four. Sangria tasted good and strong. Not too sweet and the pitcher only have little bits of fruit and plenty of red wine. =) I like the large selection of tapas and would like to go back and try all the different ones. One down side is it's small so it was really loud in there.
author: Yenly M.

description: It's not a top-shelf tapas dining experience.  But it is a very fun place to go and hang with friends and have decently-priced food.  I have made it a tradition to go there on my birthday, and will continue to do so. :)  It can get a bit loud sometimes, but not overbearingly so... at least not until the mariachis come in. LOL
author: Kevin W.

description:
My GF gets a recommendation from this restaurant and tells me its really good there and I tell her we can try it out.  I must've forgot that it was a Friday and didn't read that it was in the Mission.  But I couldn't back down and just had to brave the parking and crowd that awaited.  Well at least brave the parking part.  We circled the area a couple of times and decided to park on a hill on 20th but figured we could use the exercise on the walk back. 

So we find the restaurant and the host tells us it was going to be a 10-15 minute wait, we weren't surprised because it looked pretty busy in there.  It didn't seem too cold out so we sit at the empty tables outside and in about 5 minutes they call us back in.  Already a plus for them.

They take us upstairs to their little loft area, there was already a table of about 10 people, a couple and an empty table that would fill with about a party of 15.  It was cool that we werent sitting directly next to anybody or have anybody bumping into us.

Our server comes pretty fast (another plus) and she recommends that we should put in the order now if we wanted the paella because it takes about 30min to prepare.  So we look at the menu and ask if we should get the seafood/meat one but says that the flavors get mixed up and recommends either one or the other.  We settle on the seafood and she recommends the garlic shrimp and potatoes.  GF only has water and I try the Sangria.  

The two dishes, shrimp and the potatoes, (I forgot what they were called) came out pretty fast and they were really good, even the sauce was so good that I asked for some bread to soak it all up.  

The Paella came out in about 35min but the shrimp and potatoes kept us busy while waiting.  So they serve the Paella portion for the amount of people eating it, we ordered the 2 person pan but it could've really served 3-4 people.  

After splashing it with lemon and taking the first bite, you can just taste the ocean but not in a bad way, every bite was good and washing it down with the sangria made it better.

They kept the water coming and our sever kept checking on us which was very good for a busy day.  They had these two guys singing with  guitars which was nice.  The overall atmospere was good, it was loud but a good loud and the place was pretty clean.

The only negative was the amount of time to get the check and get everything settled (which wasn't too pricey) but it really didn't detract from the dinner.  We would definitely go back and try the other tapas and the meat Paella.  Pluses for the time to get a table, amount the server came, the food wait , the server being friendly and of course the food.  The only other bad thing (which wasn't their fault) was walking up the hill and being too stuffed to get Mitchell's Ice Cream on the way home.
author: Chris G.

description:
more like 3.5 stars but i round up. 

the food is ok. typical tapas like fried calamari (really meaty pieces), patatas bravas (solid), paella (tasty but not super flavorful), asparagus (simply sauteed), clams (pretty good), chorizo (baby links yum!), artichoke hearts (a little sparse on the size), some really tender chicken dish, some mushroom sautee (despite hating these button mushrooms, i tried it and thought the flavor was quite nice), and much more. we also had 4 pitchers of sangria (very nice and easy to drink, maybe too easy to drink). we shared 4 desserts as well. only one worth mentioning was the chocolate mousse. i'm typically not a mousse fan but i dug into this one. it was creamy rich but not overly sweet. it was also counterbalanced with something just a tinge savory which might explain why it tasted that much better (complement of flavors to enhance each other). 

anyhoo, with 10 people our bill totaled only $21 or $22 each which was amazing given that we were all full and replete. the service was fast and friendly. no complaints. a fun little place, super casual and close proximity to local bars.
author: Cindy W.

description: Esperpento is quite good, though certainly not the best Spanish style tapas I've ever had. The 4 star review is really all about the authentic atmosphere - cozy, cheerful & very quaint setting - and relaible affordable food. The service is  not great though and is always slow, so don't go if you're in a rush - I've been left waiting forever for the check after chasing down the waitress twice to let her know i had to catch a flight. They also tend to make mistakes on the bill, so if this matters to you, check it before you pay.
author: Hazel Grace D.

description: GREAT food!   Fun atmosphere.   Can get a little on the loud side but if that's your thing, you're in the right place!
author: Michael S.

description:
3.5 stars

the tapas here are pretty fantastic. i haven't had anything that wasn't incredibly tasty. that said, the paella is a major fail.  i've had it twice and its extremely bland, with all the seafood components overcooked and flavorless.
author: Allen L.

description: My friends raved about this place, which is a bit surprising since they usually have a good taste in food. The food itself is pretty mediocre, at best. The potatoes bravas where uncooked, not crispy at all, in fact very oily. The sauce was overly vinegary. And unfortunately that was the standout tapas of the meal. But on the plus side the server (forgive I forget her name) was extremely nice and accommodating as was the host who called me when our table was ready which allowed us to jump across the street for a drink. Also the prices were quite reasonable. We were a group of 7 and with a bottle of wines and several beers the total was about $140 including tip. Not bad. I would recommend this as a spot when you aren't too concerned with food but want a little something and a drink. It's hella loud on weekend so avoid if you are looking for that quiet little date spot.
author: Ben H.

description: I love this place probably because it was one of our first dates when the wife and I were courting but regardless it still has yummy food loud mariachi music and reasonable drinks. Loud garlicy and a bit wild but fun place to bring friends to. Now that tapas are trendy this place still reigns supreme.
author: Valerie S.

description: I went here last night, the food was pretty good, I checked it out first on yelp and since it got pretty good reviews so I thought I'd go and try it out for myself. I was not disappointed, the service was good I good suggestions from our waiter. We tried the paella de mariscos which was pretty huge but sooooo yummy and the patatas bravas, which was delicious!!! =P So I definitely recommend this place and hope to stop by again soooN!!
author: shai-lyng C.

description: Good bistro. I had the rabbit stew as well as the shrimp with black rice on two different occasions. The food is nice but the waiter seemed to be lacking knowledge of the various dishes on the menu which didn't make me all that comfortable. He asked my date what she wanted for desert yet never asked me. I interrupted my date and told to him in a non-aggresive yet assertive way that i want something with chocolate and flourless. I specifically stressed no flour. I didn't like the size of the water glasses as well they seemed small and flimsy. I'm used to glassware by pottery barn or waterford. Either way go and check it out but let them know what you want and don't want. :)
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
it's definitely good, but not great that i'd hike to the mission and wait for 40 minutes out in the cold just to be jam packed into a sweltering oven.  

first of all, they have about 20 tables seating 50 squeezed onto the main floor, which is about the size of a shoebox.  so people basically have to climb over tables and other people enjoying their food to get to their table wa~y in the back corner.  if it's cold out, forget about waiting inside where it's warm, as not only is there no room, the wait staff will bump into you and glare at you for being in the way (not that i blame them).  we were a group of 15 there for a friend's bday and we were seated at 3 small tables pushed together.  i was literally sitting on the lap of this girl i had just met.  i'm glad i showered and wore deoderant.

second of all, it's about 8 million degrees in there, especially if you are seated upstairs.  seriously, i have never sweat like that outside of a sauna (and i am not a sweaty person).  maybe it was their devious plan to get us to drink more, because i swear i downed like 20 pitchers of sangria on my own.  if that's the case, well played, esperpento, well played.  again, i'm glad i wore deoderant.  although i found out that although the bottle says it's deoderant AND anti-perisperent, the anti-part apparently doesn't work in heat that's greater than the temperature of hell on a hot day in august.

because they are so packed, we were seated about 30-40 minutes late for our 8pm reservation.  it didn't seem to be the restaurant's fault entirely, as the party before us was lallygagging at the table after they had paid up.  but still, get 'em in, and get 'em out!

the food overall was tasty but super duper garlicky.  seriously, i could've taken down the taliband by just opening my mouth and breathing on them.  and almost everything had garlic on it.  i love my garlic but is it really necessary to use 40 cloves in each dish?  some of the highlights include the calamari, grilled asparagus, mushrooms and artichoke.  we also had the spicy potatoes, croquettes, shrimp, some kind of chicken, some kind of meat, other stuff, and 3 types of paella (veggie, mix and meat).

it was a great time had by all (yay sangria!) but it's definitely a challenge to eat here.
author: Reina M.

description: Good food and a comfortable, unpretentious environment, but not spectacular.  To my palate the paella was a little bland -- could have used some more spice.  I don't know how "authentic" it all is since I've never been to Spain ... but all the dishes I've had there have been tasty -- omelettes, anchovie-stuffed olives, shellfish, rabbit stew...  Good sangria.  All in all I would describe this as more a "comfort food" tapas place than  "gourmet" tapas.
author: David A.

description:
3.3 stars.

Everything was great.  Food, service, music, timing of dishes.   Very pleasant birthday dinner, very tasty sangria.  Our server, a pretty brunette lady was sweet and attentive.  

Highlights:
sangria (luciously intoxicating but could use a little more fruit chunks)
tortilla espanola (perky onions, served at appropriate temp, i.e. steaming hot)
butter lettuce green salad (plain, simple & refreshing)
grilled artichoke (tender but not overcooked)

Lowlights:
paella de mariscos (rice too salty, shrimp tasted fishy, underdone)
desserts (we tried three of four, all underwhelming.  the creme brulee tasted of butane, as if torch held too close to the surface so that gas fumes actually got under the sugar crust)
strange table turning practices

I was all ready to give this place 4 stars.  I see they get some mixed reviews, and I sincerely want to help them be the SF insitution that they should be, having weathered a lot of ups and downs in our economy and all.  This place has been here since as long as I can remember.  And it's a bright and cheery spot on the block, which I enjoy walking by often.  So all arrows point to 4 estrellas.

UNTIL...

at the end of our meal the manager dude came over to turn our table.  He was all "I'm sorry guys..." in that mincing not-very-sorry tone that managerial people like to use.  

Note that we were still picking at our desserts and had just barely paid the bill.  I found this especially bad timing considering that we had ordered the paella, in advance mind you, which took about 45 minutes to arrive, and which I found totally acceptable, time-wise. Everyone knows paella takes longer to prepare.  Is it our fault then that we had a lengthier than usual dinner?  Surely our $everal hundred dollar tab was enough to compensate for us lingering at the table a mite longer...?  I understand that at some point every table must be turned, but he'd already stuck us way up on the 2nd level like refugees, and come on, things could have been handled with a little more finesse.  He knew very well it was my birthday, too, because someone in my party had blurted it out when we first came in.  Didn't matter though.  Manager was clearly on a mission to let us know that this was no Chili's/Cheesecake Factory/Applebee's.  No special leeway for birthday parties, no senor!

I was able to beg another 5 minutes off him, but he kept hovering around... making us all feel really uncomfortable and shit.  Ok, so maybe there was a little bit of a line outside.  But why such a rush?  Lines out front are good for business, they make you look HAWT.  Lines are the must-have accessory for Fall, especially on the Valencia Corridor. 

Anyway, shame on you manager dude.  You know you could never get away with that in Spain.  That's ok though, because I still went out and got a good birthday drunk on nonetheless.
author: Molasses C.

description: I really like a lot of the food here.  The sangria and prices are pretty good.  It can get really crowded, and quite noisy but if you are in the mood to shout over dinner then you should be fine.
author: Katie V.

description: Ummmm, this place is more than "just ok," this place is great. First of all, the service was fantastic. My friends and I wanted to sit outside on one of our exceptionally warm nights here in SF, but there was only a table that was being hounded by bugs. We honestly didn't care, but the staff, and I think the owner, wouldn't have it, so they moved our table away from the neon lights and closer to the street. It really felt like we were having an exclusive VIP dining experience. We ordered two pitchers of their Sangria, which was VERY good and not cheapy tasting. We had mussels, marinated mushrooms, bread bread bread, OMG, I cannot even remember everything we ordered, but I can tell you it was superb and we just had the best time.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Parking is rough, good luck to you my friend if you are driving in for a visit on a Friday or Saturday night.  

The food was okay, we ordered almost one of everything.  Some things I tried was

1) Calamari: Okay, flavorful and wasn't rubbery.  Lots of onions.
2) Fried Calamari: Not bad, the dipping sauce was very plain though
3) Asparagus: Good, but nothing spectacular, a little salty
4) Artichoke: Very good, probably one of my favorite dishes, but some pieces seemed inedible, very tough skin.  Just make the decision to swallow it down or spit it out, don't let it linger in the in between state for too long.
5) Potatoes with red sauce: Good, probably my second favorite thing, although fatty and not exotic it tasted good
6) Potatoes with white sauce:  Was this just sour cream on top?  
7) Whole Prawns with shell: I didn't try this one because I don't like to be bothered with peeling shrimp, call it lazyness, call it clenlyness, no matter I'm not going to bother expending the energy when there are other easily digestible eats nearby
8) Garlic Shrimp with tail: I can deal with these, just bite off to the tail and it isn't too fussy, the sauce was good, but how can you screw up butter and garlic?
9) Clams: Didn't try, not a big clam fan but they looked good as far as clams go
10) Chicken Croquette: These were pretty good, they were what you would expect, deep fried potato filling with chicken inside.

Dessert
1) Chocolate moose: The flavor wasn't consistent, did they forget to stir this thing all the way?  Some bites were sugary sweet others were dark chocolate tart.  
2) Creme Brulee: One of the worst I've had, not sure why this was the case, maybe it was more custard than creme, the consistency wasn't smooth enough for my taste.  I didn't think a restaurant could mess this up until yesterday.
3) Rice Pudding: Really soupy.  Had to dig to the bottom to get to the rice, maybe some like it this way.
4) Flan: Saw it but didn't try, can't comment.  Looked ok if not a bit small.
author: Stephen H.

description: This restaurant is always lively- and the food is very consistent... I've been going here for years, and it's definitely one of those places I wake up craving from time to time...  The Sangria, Patatas Bravas (spicy potatoes) and alcachofas (artichokes) are a few of my favorites... For an incredibly inexpensive and delicious meal, try the paella... I'm personally a fan of the vegetarian one...  It easily can feed two people and the meal will cost around $20 dollars...
author: jackie a.

description:
i live right next to this place and i always wondered why it got packed around dinner time. 
went after work one day and it was sooooo good. 
their patatas bravas are bomb and so are their mini sausages. 
i always order their ensalada mixta.
the seafood paella is HUGE and delicious (the meat one not so much). a 30-min wait tho so you have to be patient. the service could be more attentive too. 
i would go for tapas, not their main courses.
author: Brenda S.

description:
This place is excellent for groups of about 6 people.  We went here last night for my husband's birthday with two other couples.  We decided to order 3 tapas per person and share family style.  The tapas are cheap enough that you can do this and the portions are just about the right size for a group of 6 people to all get a taste of each tapas.  It's also a great way for you to get a taste of a good variety of the tapas.

Our favorite was the ox-tail stew.  It will melt in your mouth like butter!  The morcilla (aka blood sausage...don't get scared away by this) was excellent!  Definitely, we will be back.
author: Patty G.

description: After deciding to on Paella, we searched our neighborhood for a good place and came along Esperpento. The menu is very reasonably priced. We got 2 appetizers, a bottle of sangria and of course a big plate of paella and it all came out to about $55 which is pretty good, the service was good too and the place was packed. The paella however did not blow us away as it was not very savory. We got the mixed plate of meats and seafood and althought the seafood was pretty good, the meats (pork, chicken) left something to be desired, a bit bland and undercooked.
author: Julian M.

description: Food wise, i'd give this place 4 stars.  I've never had a dish here i didnt like.  The seafood paella is my fav.  It does take a while to make though, but it's worth the wait.  However, back to waiting, the service here can be REALLLY slow, as long as the wait for a table.  The would be the only thing that keeps me from going here more often.
author: Kim N.

description: Loved this place. So authentic. Came here with a friend randomly. We had a few different tapas, some chicken and potatoes things and of course the Sangria. Amazing sangria! Then suddenly mariachi appear and start playing. Couldn't have been a more perfect night.
author: Polina S.

description: The tapas came out pretty fast, but the paella took a while and some of the rice was raw.  I wouldn't eat there again.
author: mardou o.

description:
one word: paella

if you love paella, you have to try esperpento...their paella is to die for!  and their sangria is really yummy so thats always a plus+

they have a variety of dishes ranging from ox tail to rabbit, seafood  to veggie dishes.  all in all the tapas i've had, have all been yummy.

the wait can kinda be long, but it is worth it to fill your paella cravings
author: Alice K.

description: These are some good tapas.  I have never been disappointed.  The only thing holding this place back from an extra star is that it is very small and when it gets crowded you need to yell so the person next to you can hear what you are saying.
author: mick H.

description: I think their Sangria is good but that's about it.  I use to love this place but through the years the food seems to get worse.
author: Christine S.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that as a yelp user and member for over a year, I've oft been inspired to write reviews about food due to a phenomenal or regrettable experience. However, I'll be frank and admit that I am a lazy person, and I usually just bitch about a bad restaurant to my friends, while never fully documenting the extent of my displeasure. 

Today is different. 

The horrible service and mediocre food I received at this restaurant compelled me to write this review. I've been to Esperpento before, probably about a year and half ago, and I remembered it to be good (not write-home-able, but good) tapas. However, tonight's experience proved vastly different, and has rendered Esperpento as null in my array of viable restaurant options in the Mission, my 'hood.

My partner and I decided to pop over to Esperpento to get some dinner, after eschewing two other eateries due to their double dolla sign status.  We'd been to Esperpento before, and thought it would be a safe, easy bet. We were wrong.

First off, we were seated within a few minutes, which was great. We sat down and surveyed the menu, figuring out what we wanted. We closed our menus and sat patiently and watched the symphony of bad service, which was to be the story of our evening, play out. 

Just before we were seated and given menus, another couple walked into the restaurant that clearly knew the waitress. Not only did they walk in 10 minutes after us, but they were seated and served FOOD nearly 10 minutes before we were even asked for our drink orders. Oh wait, and actually, we WEREN'T asked for our drink orders. After getting so hungry waiting for 10 minutes to be seated (generally not a big deal), and 15 minutes to be acknowledged by a waiter or offered drinks or bread, I had to physically get up and ask the bus person if we could please have some bread. She offered to take our order and we quickly listed off our tapas choices.  We were brought our wine in a fairly reasonable time (Rioja something or other. It was no better than the 4 buck Bear's Lair Trader Joe's Cab).
Our bread arrived shortly after, and was stale ("authentic Spanish stale bread" my boyfriend, who lived in Barcelona for 2 years, retorted). We nibbled on the stale bread and the dishes that followed, however, the quality was far under par. 

The Jamon Serrano en Pan con Tomate was delicious (it's hard to mess up cured ham). That was were the flavor ended. The eggplant dish was mediocre, the Tortilla de Patatas was bland and flavorless, and as I write this review now, my boyfriend is lying on the couch clutching his stomach from the rancid boccarones (I didn't eat them, but he insisted).  Seriously, he is ill. What's more, we had to rally in order to get ourselves out of the place. Not once, twice, but three times did we verbally discuss a viable dine 'n ditch scenario! After our plates were cleared and we waited the usually 10 minutes, again I had to get up to ask the server for our check!

One pepto bismal tablet for my man and a beer at the phoenix to calm my  nerves, and I'm finally able to express myself about the horrible time we had at esperpento. 

SUMMARY (I know I can blab so here's the meaty bit)...
Great jamon serrano en pan con tomate, but that's where it ends.

Usually, great food can erase the pain that bad service leaves, but not this time. This caliber of bad service incites a special kind of frustration, especially when guests who arrive AFTER you receive service first, and basic attention has to be requested of the wait staff by getting up out of your seat. Additionally, when the food you receive is mediocre at best and incites stomach cramping, it leaves you feeling like you've been taken advantage of. 

I like the idea of Esperpento: Love the ambiance, love the decorations. And I know people have bad days. However, when the waitress who was supposed to be attending our table brought our check, and innocently asked, "How was everything?" I quickly gave her my honest feedback. She was not phased by my complaints of unsatisfactory service and food, and replied, "Oh." 

"Oh" is right.

On second thought, make that a "NOh!"
author: kristi c.

description: I really like this restaurant. I got the grilled tilapia and fried calamari. We got there at 5:00 pm so it didn't get really busy yet.
author: V N.

description: The service here is so horrible that it doesn't even matter what the food tastes like. I'm not sure why, but there's always a wait . .  and they tell us the wait is shorter than it actually is.  So you get stuck waiting because at that point, you'd have to wait anywhere else you went. And if you're wondering about the food, it really isn't good. The last time I went the patatas bravas were sitting in grease and the spinach with cheese dish was congealed. Not very appetizing. There are so many better Spanish tapas places in the city.  Bocadillos is excellent.
author: Jessica R.

description: This is a marvelous restaurant, especially if you're a true " spanish food lover " My favorite dishes include the Seafood paella; a fresh vegetable soup; and a delicious fried calamari. Esperpento features what seems to be an interesting and relatively inexpensive selection of Spanish wines, but both times I've been there, I've opted for the speciality beer. Whether this is authentic tapas I can't say, because I've never been to Spain. But no doubts that every dish I've tasted has been awesome. I had been there in the mid-day, each time between 12-1 on a weekday. By the time I left, the restaurant was a little bit full, but there appeared to be little or no wait. It will be ok If you're alone or a couple; there's no one constantly asking "how everything is?" and there's always promptly right there when you're ready for your next "small plate." The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and the food comes quickly. If you decide to go, I hope your experience will be as satisfying as mine have been.
author: Joy I.

description: Love their grilled artichokes, patatas bravas, and actually pretty much everything I've had there! Extensive menu with all the classics and efficient service. Only negative is getting the itinerant musicians wandering in to play a bit too loudly next to your table. Seriously, I think most people just give them money because they feel embarrassed and want them to move on.
author: Mike B.

description: Love the food, the ambience, and the prices. Extremely well priced wide range of tapas, great tasting paella, and some music too on Fridays. The sangria is sweet and nice, but if you want a drink with more than 3% alcohol, get something else...
author: Raghu N.

description: I don't get it.  Really.  Oh wait.  It's the Mission.  So it's a great greasy place to soak up the alcohol and quell the weed-induced hunger pangs.
author: mcmalaprop ..

description: Great food and service. Not your typical tapas place .... good portions and great flavored food.
author: Ko M.

description: This is one of my favorite tapas spots in the Bay!   The sangria is delicious!  I'm not so much of a paella gal... so I can't say how fabulous (or not) it is... but I can say the small plates are fantastic!  The pollo croquettas, garlic shrimp & spicy potatoes are my fave!  My only gripe with this spot is when you leave you WILL smell like the food for the rest of the evening!  If you don't mind that, this place is totally worth the wait.  (And there is usually a long wait to get a table!)
author: Mijiza M. S.

description:
patatas, paella y pollo..oh my!  i love me some tapas and esperpento never disappoints.  was also part of the seong p. birthday brigade.  while i found the private side room kinda eerie, the good eats and service helped.

my favorite dish by far is the patatas bravas.  ya really can't go wrong with fried potatoes and that insanely tasty garlicky goodness that is the brava sauce.  other notables were the grilled calamari, garlic chicken & of course..paella.

the main dining area can be cramped, but it's festive with plenty of ambience to boot.  i've been a few times over the years and have always found esperpento consistently good.
author: Niki M.

description: I give two gold stars to this place and one to my date that brought me here. The service was excellent and so was the sangria that washed over me in a wave of euphoria. I glanced over my shoulder at a family having a delicious looking paella dish and became instantly convinced that I will return to the restaraunt to order one of my very own. I tasted a variety of tapas dishes such as the spicy potatoes, garlic shrimp and mushrooms, A beef stew dish that overall left a very pleasant feeling of satisfaction in the quality of food served. The ambiance of the spot was touching too...I always love the tapas spot that has multiple portraits of matadors framed and on the walls it always reminds me of Ernest Hemingway's "The Sun Also Rises" which is never a bad thing to think of when you remember how good the food tastes here.
author: Laura G.

description:
This is the first Spanish restaurant I've tried in San Francisco, and I am not impressed.

We got a table right away when we arrived there Saturday around 6.30 pm.  We had the last table, after we were seated the wait started outside.  ;-)  The food was good, nothing spectacular, just good.  We ordered several plates to try as much as possible, and nothing was bad, but nothing stood out.  Except for the sangria, which was very good!  Service was friendly and fast, and the prices are definitely right for the food you get.

Don't go there for a romantic dinner "a deux".  It's way too loud for that.
author: Marijke D.

description:
So you wanna know if you should go here?

Yes, YES! A million times yes!

I went here last week for my birthday, and felt totally blessed things worked out the way they did. Last Saturday I was totally frustrated and still kicking myself in the ass for not planning my dinner more than 4 hours before dinner was scheduled. I called Esperpento earlier to see if they had anything open, to which they replied it would be infinitely impossible to acquiesce my request. Well, they actually said it was "too late for reservations" but I had to throw some big word usage on ya ass! Ya know you need it.

Yet right before leaving for a delectable dining experience at Friday's (yes, I was that desperate), a voice in my head told me to call Esperpento one last time. Don't worry, it wasn't the scurry *kill your Mother* type voice - more like an intuitive, calling from God, conscience type. So I called to see if they had any tables open for a party of ten. The owner's son, who's totally cool, said he would hold the table for us until we got there. He didn't even ask us how long we'd be, he just said he'd hold it. SCORE! About an hour later we all arrived, the table still held for us even though there were others waiting to be seated.

Right away we ordered the seafood paella (takes 30 minutes), sangria, and the fried calamari (the best ever!). Yup, we knew our stuff. Of all the patatas, the patatas bravas were the BEST. The grilled/fried calamari dishes were both perfectly seasoned, the Champinones Al Ajillo were delicious, and the HUGE grilled veggie salad was the perfect way to add more veggies to the two GIGANTIC meat platters  (carnes de pajarillas?). Just like NKOTB, we had all the Right Stuff - Three-Points!

Another SCORE, you ask? Being seated upstairs. This was perfect for us, since there wasn't as much room downstairs for my man to stumble around half-drunk, handing out extra birthday cake to lucky patrons. It felt like I had the best of everything that night - food, companionship, laughter, and love.

The only complaint? I went here two months ago for Valentine's and noticed they jacked all tapas prices up by a dollar/two.

e.g. Patatas bravas/alioli $4.50 then, $5.75 now
       Calamares fritos $6 then, 7.75 now

Still, I would definitely return to Esperpento any time!  If only to hear the owner apologize to my Filipino boyfriend for Spain's colonization of the Philippines one last time.
author: Charrylenne S.

description: Cheap, tasty, filling, garlicky food. Check. Fun ambiance. Check. Cute waiter. Check. $25 bottle of Rioja. Check. Drinks across the street at the Latin America Club afterwords. Check. Mind-numbing hangover this morning. Yup, check.
author: SL N.

description:
honestly, i'll have to go here again to give an accurate review as it's completely left my mind.

i remember the food being good... but apparently not memorable.
author: Friedrich G.

description: Had a great birthday here in Feb. The food was yummy... the place had great ambiance. It's super small inside but they were able to accommodate my party of 8 upstairs. You have to make reservations on the weekend. We had great service and the place was packed. Can't wait to go back.
author: Denise P.

description:
I absolutely love this place! I have loved every dish that we have ordered and being that we always go in a group of at least 4 and order a lot of food, I've tried quite a bit of their dishes. The mariscada, which is a grilled seafood dish, different than paella although that is also good, is excellent as well as the potato appetizer, patatas ali-oli, which has a delicious garlic mayo sauce. The sangria and flan are delicious as well. The service is wonderful! The only thing that I don't like about this place which has nothing to do with the food is that annoying creepy tone deaf guy that goes around the place with his guitar "singing". Seriously, he just doesn't stop and then when he is finally done he goes from table to table staring you down for a tip. If everyone at the table doesn't give him something, he starts giving you dirty looks. How much do you expect people to tip you especially when your performance was unsolicited. They need to get rid of this guy. Minus one star for this creepy guy.

Tip: Try to make reservations or else you will be waiting forever! Also, parking is virtually impossible do be prepared for that.
author: Diane M.

description: Birthday dinner with the ladies! I love this spot for its sheer capacity to always be associated with joy. I can't say i've ever been there and not felt joyful. Sure, waiting for 20 mins after the time of our reservation wasn't exactly delightful, but sit me down with a jug of sangria and any complaint agily melts away... Its fairly rare for a night of debauchery to merge with "healthy eating" but that also happens here-- vegetables with olive oil and garlic abound! (Must have room for another cocktail people!) I didn't love the pollo adobo (a little grisly) hence the 4 stars above but everything else i've had there was downright...RIGHT. Move me to Spain pronto.. livin' on red wine and garlic is the way to go!
author: Rachel S.

description: The food at this tapas place is hit or miss.  I really like the atmosphere though: spanish music, bright colored walls, and flamenco dancers.  The sangria is always tasty, but the last couple of times I came here the food left something to be desired.  It was greasy and too garlicky.  I may come back here to give it one last try-hopefully it won't disappoint!  I give it 3 stars for decor and sangria.
author: anne m.

description: We went back today for some tapas dinner. Forget the paella! When we walked in and sat down, at first, no one noticed us because all the sudden after we came in, the place was very busy. Anyhow, we ordered some tapas- my favorite was the oyster, and ropa vieja- they are soo good!! All I can say is that I was so glad that I went! and at the end, the waiter apologized for somehow "ignoring us". Well accepted!
author: Daisy S.

description:
i went with my mom and wife for my wife's birthday, we ordered the tortilla de patata, the clams with white beans, the oxtail, papas bravas, calamari.

My mom really liked the the tortilla de patata, i calamari was decent everey thing else was ok.
author: James c.

description:
First of all, we went at lunch so we didn't experience any of the service issues other diners did.  Parking was plentiful.

Second, did not make a reservation; no need to at lunch.  Service was attentive.

Now . . . onto the review.  This place is great.  It is like sitting in Seville or Barcelona.  You are transported to a tapas bar in Spain from the moment you walk in.  Brought back a lot of great memories.

The food is genuine and great.  The cabbage with the fish was to die for.  The grilled fish was cooked to perfection.  The tapa dishes (mushrooms, potatoe omelet (to die for), garlic chicken, and chicken croquett) were out of this world.  The only thing I missed (which would have been available in any Spanish tapas bar) is the Iberian ham + cheese dish.  They had both separate but not together.  Prices were reasonable.

Absolutely, positively, the best tapas place I have been at in SF and I have tried many.

¡Buen provecho! ¡Buen apetito! 

¡Salud!
author: Karen B.

description:
Decided to head to this place on Sunday night.  I called at about 6:30 and made reservations for 2 people at 8pm.  Arrived on time, but had to wait a good 20 minutes for a seat.  The host informed us that several tables had paid, but had not left.
The food was very good, and the portions were surprising large considering the low price.  The garlic shrimp and patatas bravas were outstanding, and the Sangria is very fresh.

This is definitely a place I will go back to, again, and again, and again...
author: Rodney S.

description: Very nice tapas, and usually easier to get into than Picaro, though they are owned by the same people.  Frequently eye-wateringly loud on Friday and Saturday nights.
author: Jude F.

description:
i had been to esperpento a few times before and always had good service and really enjoyed the food so i picked it as the location for my birthday dinner.  

i was with a group of 10 and they put us in a one room shack.   there was a big window facing the street that we left open to feel a little less claustrophobic so we received a lot of stares as people walked by.  we also saw a cab hit and run a car as it made a 3 point turn.  unfortunately, no one was able to get its license plate number before it took off.  

since we were there for almost 3 hours, being in the private room worked out well even though it was pretty cramped.  we had the seafood paella, a meat platter, a seafood platter, fried and grilled calamari, potatoes bravas, garlic chicken, ox tail and lots of sangria.  everything was really good.  our waiter was really attentive and the food came out in a timely manner even though we were in that separate room.

good food, company and conversation made for a great birthday.
author: Seong P.

description:
i came here last night for seong's bday dinner, and it was really yummy.  it was weird sitting in the side room, altho it was nice and private.  however, i had a tad of claustrophobia, since the room we were in only had enuf space for our table and chairs.  

food-wise, everything was good.  i particularly liked the seafood paella, which was gigantic, the potatas bravas, and the seafood platter.  the sangria here was also very tasty and dangerous.
author: Helen T.

description: Very tasty tapas, wicked sangria.  They get it right.  Almost like being in Spain.  Almost.  And cheap, too.
author: Asteridae A.

description: Good f'n times.  This is tapas at the right price...plain and simple...tapas priced right.  The blood sausage is awesome and surprisingly light, the quail awesome, green beans perfect, and the spicy potatoes are to die for.  Unfortunately, I found the sangria too sweet as it tasted like punch and not wine...but thats my opinion.  All and all I give it 3.8 stars as it is exactly what it strives to be and would get a full 4 if the sangria were better.
author: Ryan G.

description: You want great Sangria?  Come to Esperpento!  I was first introduced to this great Tapas/Sangria restaurant on the company tab at my old employer.  Of course, we ordered everything we could so we can taste all the different flavors of the variety of tapas they offered.  The Sangria was sooooo good and the bits of fruits gave you a nice special burst of alcohol to keep that smile on your face.  A lot of people like Cha Cha Chas, but personally, I like Esperpento.  Don't get me wrong, Cha Cha Chas is very good too and I'll write a review for that restaurant, but the food and sangria top Cha Cha Chas Bar none!
author: Manton R.

description:
Good, cheap tapas in the Mission.  The quality can be a little uneven, but it's a fun place to eat and an unbelievable value.

The clams with garlic and olive oil are delicious, as are the patatas bravas.

The only drawback is the incredibly loud mariachi music every 20 minutes.  The concept is ok, but in practice it's just too loud to be fun (or hear yourself think).
author: George O.

description: My husband and I recently went to Esperpento a couple of weeks ago and thoughroughly enjoyed it.  We were looking for Las Ramblas wh. has unfortunately closed, and re-stumbled on Esperpento. I say 're' because we remembered that we had gone there in '97 when we first moved to the City.  It was still marvelous.  The ambiance is lovely, it's very small and intimate....the service was quick and efficient, everyone very pleasant, and the food....well, we thought we were back in Barcelona...
author: Stevie N.

description: I think that the food here was better when I had the sangria. The paella is definitely a classic, although I liked the seafood paella more than the meat paella (too greasy). Paella for 4 was enough for 6 people for lunch (with leftovers). The mushrooms with garlic were very tasty, and the spinach was appropriately creamy (and deadly).
author: Dana L.

description: Having tired of waiting @ Cha x3, a friend & i decided to come back here. it'd been a year or two since then, so it was time to come back. the mainstays (calamari & potatoes) were actually better than before--and the snapper fillets and marinated pork kebabs were tasty as well. not sure about comparing sangrias w/other places, but the one here would probably hold it's own. the wait for a table wasn't too bad...maybe around 10 mins.
author: Chris C.

description: Delicious food and great wine. Try the Sangria. This is a fun place to come with a smallish group - say 4 people. That way you can still hear each other talk, but get to try lots of dishes. Beware the long wait on weekend evenings!
author: Pumpkin K.

description: You think it seems pretty affordable when you're looking at the menu, but then the plates arrive & you realize they're too small. The food was decent, but not amazing. Sangria was good, but not Cha Cha Cha's good. I've eaten here before, a few years ago, & I remember it being better. Maybe just an off night?
author: Pete J.

description: Apparently I have been here four or five times.  But due to the noise level inside and the consumption of a large amount of sangria, I have a hard time remembering.  The idea of going here again gets me excited anyway.
author: Brett N.

description: GREAT food, very casual and warm atmophere, kids frinedly, we come often with our 2 year old and he both likes the food and they really don't make feel bad about all the mess you leave behind...
author: Rafael M.

description: This place was great! I went there a couple of weeks ago and four people ate for under $60 total! I really enjoyed the grilled muscles and spicy potatoes. The only reason I gave this four stars instead of five is because the noise level in the main dining room was very high and hard to hear. Other than that we had great service, great food and WONDERFUL Sangria!
author: Andrea M.

description: Don't bother, this place is not good.  The Pan con Tomate was a piece of bread with an actual tomato and onion on top.  The tortilla was dry and bland.  The croquettes were like big balls of dough.  I'm not claiming to be an expert on Spanish food but I've lived in Barcelona for a year and had heard really good things about this spot.  Even Cha Cha Cha is better than this place.  But if you want real authentic Spanish food, check out Zarzuela.
author: Steven M.

description: Fun and funky tapas and paella caf with good inexpensive food and sangria. We had a party of 8 and I guess it was about the right size with two paella orders (one meat dish and the other seafood) and several tapas dishes and dessert selection. Great place to grab a snack and soak up the atmosphere. There were several large parties and I guess it's a common to celebrate birthdays and special occassions here. We were thankful to have a 730pm slot since it was a loooong wait for the other folks that were waiting for tables at 8pm onwards.
author: Yan M.

description: I've eaten here two or three times, and each time the service has been progressively worse. They don't really have a host, so you have to shuffle around by the door and feel awkward until a waiter takes pity on you and either finds a table or shrugs and tells you it'll be 'a while'. The food is tasty and pretty darn authentic, and the reasonable prices make up for the shitty service (which is also authentically Spanish, so maybe it's part of the ambiance).
